PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 19 March 1989, of the Hon. Nelson Lemmon, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Forrest from 1943 to 1949 and for the division of St George from 1954 to 1955.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 19 March 1989, of the Hon. Nelson Lemmon, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Forrest from 1943 to 1949, and a Minister of the Crown from 1946 to 1949, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to the members of his family in their bereavement.

I think there are one or two honourable senators on the Government side of the House who would like to say something about Nelson Lemmon, and for that reason I will be very brief. I think the important thing about Mr Lemmon was that he was the last survivor of the Chifley Government and a very respected member of that Government. I had the opportunity of meeting him on two occasions, and I must say that he struck me as a person of great commonsense, dignity and decency. It was a great pleasure for me to have that opportunity.

He was born on 22 March 1908 at Williamstown, Victoria. His father was a politician too, holding the Victorian State seat of Williamstown for 51 years until 1955. Nelson Lemmon himself was educated at Williamstown State School and Longerenong Agricultural College. He was married and he had a son and a daughter. He moved to Western Australia as a young man and was active in local government and farming activities and was a member of the Wheat Stabilisation Board of Western Australia from 1943 to 1944. John Curtin took an interest in the young farmer, as he then was, and worked to get him into Parliament. He entered the Federal Parliament in 1943. His maiden speech in the Parliament reflected a vision for a better Australia, a vision that was the hallmark of the Chifley Government in the postwar reconstruction era. He had a sincere commitment to caring about the poor and unemployed, he stressed the importance of opening up tertiary education opportunities to all those with the necessary ability, and he saw the importance of restructuring rural industry in the aftermath of World War II.

I have indicated that it was in his time as a Minister in the Chifley Government that he made his mark on the history of this country. He was Minister for Works and Housing and the Minister responsible for the commencement of the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme. He also foresaw the importance of environmental protection long before it became a political issue, and sought to minimise ecological damage in the scheme's planning. As part of his portfolio responsibilities he also put into operation a plan for the construction of war service homes. As well as being Minister for Works he assisted the Treasurer from 1946 to 1949. It is an indication of the regard in which he was held that he was given this important additional role.

He left the Parliament in 1949 and re-entered it briefly in 1954 as the member for St George, Sydney, amid press speculation that he was a likely contender for the Labor leadership. This was, of course, the period when Labor's political fortunes entered the trough they were to occupy for a long time. He lost his seat in 1955 and retired from public life at the age of 47. He returned to his occupation as a horse trainer and breeder and owner of a property in Robertson, New South Wales.

Mr Lemmon had a very short career in public life but it was a very distinguished one, given the time that he served in Parliament and as a Minister in that important postwar Government, particularly as the Minister dealing with postwar reconstruction issues. Ben Chifley regarded him as a potential future leader of the Labor Party. He was certainly regarded as one of the best debaters in the House. He died as the last surviving member of the Chifley Ministry and in that sense his death marks the end of an era. On behalf of the Government I extend to members of his family our sincere condolences in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I join the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in support of this motion and in extending the sympathy of the Opposition to the family of the late Nelson Lemmon. The Leader of the Government has given a good outline of the services which were provided by the Hon. Nelson Lemmon in his parliamentary and government capacities. I have little to add to that, except to say that with respect to the speech which the Leader of the Government referred to, the first speech made by Mr Lemmon in the House of Representatives, it is interesting to note just how much Australia has changed and how much the perceptions of what Australia's problems are have changed. Mr Lemmon, in his speech, expressed some positive views about immigration, saying that he realised that it was the obligation of the country to carry a greater population. He made this point:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . before we can take many migrants, we shall have to re-organize the whole of our rural industry, for we cannot feed people with the nuts and bolts of secondary industries.

The thought of there being some concern about the capacity of Australia to feed its population, and a population augmented by immigration, is one which seems very strange today. More significantly, there was a reflection of the idealism that Mr Lemmon brought into the Parliament when, in an earlier part of his speech, he lamented the outcome of the First World War and the failure of governments after that war to provide adequately for the population and for the men who had returned from war. He said:
We well remember what happened after the war of 1914-18, which was to have been a war to make Australia a land fit for heroes to live in.
He pointed out that after that war-and I quote:
. . . many Australians went short of the necessaries of life . . .

I think that Mr Lemmon's generation-not only those who were part of the Chifley Government but also those who formed the subsequent Menzies Government-can take very great satisfaction from the fact that the life which was provided for Australians in postwar Australia was significantly superior to that which was provided after the First World War. There was a much greater degree of success in managing not just Australia but the whole world. In that sense one of Mr Lemmon's premier ambitions was met. I think Australia in the post war period was a land fit for the people who had fought for Australia to live in. That ambition of his was certainly realised. I am sure that the people who are most grieved at the death of Mr Lemmon are his family. Again, the Opposition extends its sympathy to them and its thanks for the contribution made by Mr Lemmon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button has alluded to the historic nature of this individual, Mr Lemmon, as he was the last survivor of the Chifley Government to have served in the Cabinet. There are still some survivors of that Government. He was a Victorian. He was born in Victoria, and we take some pride in that. His father represented the seat of Williamstown in Victoria from 1904 to 1955. His grandparents were caretakers of the Trades Hall Council in Victoria. So it is fairly clear to anyone that Mr Lemmon and his family had a long history in the Labor movement. Like several other Victorians, such as Curtin, he represented the Labor Party in Western Australia. In Federal Parliament he represented the rather volatile seat of Forrest from 1943 to 1949. Subsequently, like Theodore and others, he went to New South Wales to seek a seat to return to the Parliament, which he did for some 18 months from 1954 to 1955. He served as a Minister for Works and Housing in the Chifley Ministry from November 1946 to December 1949. It is this public service which I think has attracted the most public attention surrounding the sad occasion of the death of Mr Lemmon. Obviously, the Curtin and Chifley governments occupy a fairly special place of respect among people in the Labor movement, somewhat akin to the Menzies Government to those opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: I never had the pleasure of meeting Mr Lemmon, although I did invite him to the fortieth anniversary of Australian citizenship ceremony this year. It was only with great regret that he declined owing to problems with health. It is always difficult to speak about someone one has not met and to go only on the written record. Nevertheless, Nelson Lemmon was obviously a talented and very respected politician. It is no mean feat, even today, to be elected as a member of Cabinet at the age of 38, having spent only three years on the back bench. In the era of Menzies and Chifley, youthful achievement was rare. It shows how highly the Labor Party regarded Mr Lemmon. According to Chifley's biographer, Mr Lemmon, together with John Dedman and William Scully, constituted a farmers' union caucus within the Cabinet.

Although he was born and raised in Williamstown, Melbourne, Nelson Lemmon was by occupation a farmer, first in Ongerup in Western Australia and later in Robertson in New South Wales. I note that newspaper reports quote him as saying, `Politics was something I did, but farming was my life'. According to the journalist Don Whitington, writing in 1955, both Nelson Lemmon and John Dedman were briefly members of the Young Country Party. Given Mr Lemmon's family background, I am not sure whether that report is right. It just shows the appeal that the early Country Party had at the time to some forward-looking young farmers.

Certainly Nelson Lemmon had a big passion for rural development. In 1949 he was appointed, as Senator Button has indicated, the Minister in charge of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority. It was a scheme that he pursued with as much vigour as possible, and it remains a testament to him and others. Mr Lemmon as Housing Minister was also responsible for the implementation of the war service homes housing loan scheme, again an ambitious scheme on a scale unprecedented in Australia's history. The close association of Nelson Lemmon and Ben Chifley was only one of a number that the then Labor Leader formed with younger parliamentarians in whom Chifley saw great potential. Together with Tom Burke, Fred Daly, Kim Beazley and others, Nelson Lemmon was identified by Chifley as someone who could be of vital importance to the future of the Labor Party in Australia. In Mr Lemmon's case that apparently went as far as Chifley seeing in him a future leader of the Labor Party. With Chifley's support, I understand, Mr Lemmon in fact topped the Caucus ballot for the Ministry in 1946. Following his defeat in Forrest, Mr Lemmon was apparently encouraged by Chifley to move to New South Wales in order to re-enter politics.

Unfortunately for the Labor Party and Parliament, Mr Lemmon had only a relatively brief stay in Canberra, although in later years he seems to have given every indication of being glad to be out of it. Certainly the Labor Party in the doldrums of the 1950s and 1960s suffered from the absence of talented people such as Lemmon and Burke, and the political isolation of others like Beazley and Daly. It is one of the imponderables of politics to know what impact one of these players may have had on politics if they had continued in it.

In conclusion, I appreciated his continued and intelligent assessment of politics until the time of his death. A recent newspaper report quoted Mr Lemmon as saying that the current Government had `the ablest and smartest Federal Cabinet in Australia's history'. I am not sure everyone in the chamber will concur with that. I am sure that I speak for all honourable senators in extending this House's condolences and respects to his widow, Ada Mary, whom Nelson Lemmon married in 1930, and to his son and daughter.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray; That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by the WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bolkus (from seven citizens), Durack (from 16 citizens), Giles (from 22 citizens), Lewis (from 72 citizens), McGauran (from 13 citizens), Newman (from 13 citizens), Vallentine (from 13 citizens) and Walsh (from 52 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Video Material has concluded that ``Adverse effects upon people, and especially upon children, of exposure to material containing various degrees of violence, pornography or obscenity have been demonstrated''.
The majority of the Select Committee strongly opposed the proposition for a new NVE (non-violent erotica) category, which would have entrenched X-rated video pornography.
All six State Governments have, through their Attorneys-General, expressed unanimous opposition to the circulation of X-rated videos.
We consider the continuing distribution of X-rated videos from the A.C.T. to be reprehensible and to be contrary to the wellbeing of the Australian community in general.
We strongly request urgent Government action to prohibit the distribution of X-rated and excessively violent video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them, for cost saving reasons only, on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra Bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senators in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate call upon the Government to implement a comprehensive plan to reduce the incidence of domestic violence in the community, which includes:
(a) the commissioning of proper research to determine the extent of domestic violence in Australia and its causes;
(b) providing greater support for families through taxation and other policies in an effort to reduce economic stress in families;

(c) vigorously pursuing programs designed to give women greater financial security and financial independence involving the related challenges of affordable housing, child care, education and training and worthwhile employment opportunities;
(f) providing adequate resources to support those who are forced from their home by domestic violence both in their time of crisis and in re-settlement;

(g) assistance to those Government and voluntary agencies which provide counselling, support or mediation for families in stress in an effort to prevent deterioration of situations which might result in violence;
(h) assistance to those Government and voluntary agencies which provide crisis services for women and children at times of domestic violence;
(i) particular support for those who suffer violence in situations of additional isolation such as rural or immigrant communities; and
(j) an education campaign which:

(i) emphasises that domestic violence is conduct which is intolerable in any circumstance and is a criminal offence which will be prosecuted as such and that the police deserve strong community support in this law enforcement responsibility,
(ii) teaches conflict resolution within the home by other than violent means, and
(iii) are directed to health, social, legal and other professionals who will come into contact with victims of domestic violence to better understand the issues involved and options available.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED SELECT COMMITTEE ON PAPER PULP MILLS IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, three sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Paper Pulp Mills in Australia, be established to inquire into and report upon:
(a) the environmental, economic and social impact of the establishment of additional paper pulp mills in Australia; and
(b) the feasibility of paper recycling and the use of alternative materials and processes to extend timber resources and reduce pollution.
(2) That the Committee consist of six Senators, as follows:
(a) three to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(3) That the Committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Committee elect as chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That the quorum of the Committee be three members.

(8) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and that the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(9) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of two or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be all of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(10) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That the Committee present its final report to the Senate on or before the first sitting day in October 1989.

(13) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may provide the report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy President, and, in that event
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate,
(b) the publication of the report is authorised by this Resolution,
(c) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report, and
(d) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. Is it a fact, as reported, that both the National Crime Authority (NCA) and the Australian Federal Police (AFP) have received information within the last two years raising concerns about the operations of the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia (NSCA), including an approach in November last year from the Council's Chairman, Mr Max Ieise? What was the nature of that information, from what sources did it come and, in particular, were allegations made that the NSCA and its missing Chief Executive, Mr John Friedrich, had been involved in international arms dealing and paramilitary training? What action did either agency take and what action are these agencies currently taking to investigate these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that both the National Crime Authority and the Australian Federal Police have had allegations made to them concerning the activities of the National Safety Council of Australia and Mr John Friedrich.
—When?
—I will answer this in my own way, without the honourable senator's help. As far as the National Crime Authority is concerned--
—I was trying to be helpful.

—I thought it was a serious question. The National Crime Authority has advised me that it became aware of certain allegations concerning the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia in October 1987. These allegations concerned possible involvement in arms deals in Third World countries and other arms dealings. That information was passed the same month to the Australian Federal Police because it was not relevant to matters being investigated by the National Crime Authority. In order to complete the picture on the National Crime Authority, which has not played a very great part in this, in late March 1989-in other words, just recently-the NCA received information concerning the possible whereabouts of Friedrich. That information was passed both to the Federal Police and the Victorian Police.

ANSWER.PARA: The main question is as to the matters raised in October 1987. I have indicated that the National Crime Authority passed those particular allegations concerning arms dealing, the employment of former military personnel and other activities apparently indicative of unlawful conduct to the Australian Federal Police. Those sorts of allegations were taken extremely seriously by the intelligence division of the AFP over the period October 1987 to March 1988 but nothing was found to substantiate those particular allegations.

The Australian Federal Police was first informed of possible fraud at the National Safety Council of Australia on 16 October 1988 when Mr Alex MacArthur, a former director of the NSCA, Queensland division, spoke with Assistant Commissioner Antill in Brisbane. MacArthur was advised that the matters raised were not for the AFP to investigate but should be referred to the Victorian Police if evidence of fraud was uncovered. It was indicated that perhaps independent auditors might be sought and it would be perhaps appropriate for the President of the NSCA to brief fully the Commissioner of the Victorian Police.

In the following weeks it was indicated that the Chief Commissioner of the Victorian Police had been briefed by the NSCA President, Mr Max Ieise, and new auditors had been appointed to look into the company's affairs. On 1 February 1989 Mr MacArthur again called on Antill and told him that he was concerned about information relating to John Friedrich's background and previous employment not checking out. For example, there was no record to confirm Friedrich's birth in South Australia as listed on his curriculum vitae.

Having regard to possible security implications, Antill then arranged for MacArthur to meet with the Queensland regional director of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO). The meeting took place on 2 February 1989, with Antill present. Documents were handed to both Antill and the ASIO representative which showed that Friedrich was born in Germany. I believe it was a self-generated document in the sense that it was a marriage certificate.

No investigations into the alleged fraud were undertaken by the AFP because no Commonwealth offences were disclosed. Advice had been given to bring the matter to the attention of the Victorian Police. On 23 January 1989 Ieise met with AFP officers in Melbourne in relation to his concerns about Friedrich's activities. He was again advised that the matter was one for the Victorian Police. None of the information given by MacArthur or Ieise disclosed offences against Commonwealth laws. The matters appeared to fall within the jurisdiction of the Victorian Police and that is why the continual references were made to perhaps the Victorian Police or that the Chief Commissioner might be the person to approach. The Australian Federal Police, as honourable senators will know, offered every assistance to the Victorian Police in their investigation of the matter. That offer of assistance has been made continually to the Victorian Police.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice for his answer. Arising out of the answer, Mr President, I ask the supplementary question: Was the Government advised at any time by the National Crime Authority of the NCA's concerns as to arms dealing, and was the Government advised at any time, either by the Australian Federal Police or the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, of the allegations that were made in relation to fraud?

—If by `the Government' the honourable senator means a responsible Minister such as myself, I certainly was not advised of these matters and I do not believe that any other Minister was. Perhaps I could check that out thoroughly. Certainly when the allegations came to my notice I sought a briefing as soon as possible. That is the first time that I received information along the lines that I have indicated to the Senate today.

—Can the Minister for Resources inform the Senate of the current stage of the North West Shelf gas project and, particularly, whether there are any indications of when the first export shipments will be made for this project? Further, can the Minister inform the Senate whether any formal decision has been made regarding the go ahead for the Goodwyn A development of North West Shelf gas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Beahan for this question. The first shipments of liquefied natural gas (LNG) off the North West Shelf were, according to plan, due to commence on 1 October this year. The joint venture partners for the project have advised us that they will be ready to ship from 1 July this year. That is well ahead of the original date for shipment. Indeed, a compliment must be paid to them for their management of the development of the project and to the work force with whom they have gone about that development in being ready so far ahead of schedule. The date of actual shipment is not yet designated. Price negotiations for the export phase are current, and when those price negotiations have been finalised and the export approval has been issued by the Government a firm date for export will be available. So in terms of that part of Senator Beahan's question, I think we can say that this project, which is arguably at the present time the biggest single resource project in the world and certainly the single biggest resource project in Australia, has proceeded remarkably well.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of Senator Beahan's question concerns the Goodwyn A platform. Honourable senators will know that discussion has been raging for some time as to whether Goodwyn A will be given the go-ahead by the joint venture partners. As I recall, that decision was to be made in February this year, but at that time the decision to give the go-ahead for the Goodwyn development was deferred. I can now announce that at 1300 hours Western Standard Time-I am announcing this ahead of the formal announcement-the joint venture partners, who have given their clearance for me to say this, will be announcing the go-ahead of the Goodwyn platform. The value of the Goodwyn A platform will be $1.63 billion. It will be the biggest single offshore platform facility in Australia since the mammoth North Rankin platform was constructed. Taken together with the commitment by the joint venture partners for the construction of a third LNG onshore processing train, it will take their total commitment over the last month to this project to $2.53 billion in total, which I believe is a commendable and, indeed, in anyone's terms, a massive commitment to development of our offshore gas and condensate reserves.

The Goodwyn A platform will be precisely located to take advantage of gas finds by the joint venture partners in the general vicinity of the North West Shelf and to maximise gas and condensate productions. It will feed the contracts they already have with Japanese utilities and with the State Energy Commission of Western Australia. It will have the capacity to produce 900 million standard cubic feet of gas per day and up to 80,000 barrels per day of condensate, making the project, as I have said, one of the most significant contributors in terms of Australia's liquid hydrocarbon production until the early part of the next century. Eventually 26 production wells will be feeding off the Goodwyn A platform. It will be completed in 1993 and it will eventually become necessary to have additional onshore gas facilities.

While I am on the subject, that is a remarkable vote of confidence by the joint venture partners not only in Australia's ability to manage its offshore production but also, given the very high Australian content in manufacturing and design that has gone into the production of the whole North West Shelf facility-some 73 per cent is sourced in Australia-in our ability to meet the demands of such a huge project.

In addition, the world market for LNG is very much on the rise. I visited Japan early in January. What is quite clear from the Japanese end is that they are seeking as an energy resource much more utilisation for power generation of LNG. It seems that in Japan there is some domestic concern about the problems of generating nuclear power. There is a desire to diversify their energy source mix away from coal as well. LNG, in terms of the Japanese power utilities, is seen as a growth fuel for the early part of the next century. It is premature to make speculative predictions about whether we will have a growing capacity to meet a growing demand from Japan because in the oil and gas exploration area one needs to be somewhat cautious about making predictions. In view of the oil finds in the North West Shelf area it is true to say that it seems that we have a fair reservoir--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The Minister need not lament about the possible loss of gas. His capacity to speak endlessly on this subject seems unlimited. I ask you to call him to order. He has answered the question that was asked and he is now simply, by his own admission, going on to make general observations. It is a gross misuse of Question Time.
—I am aware of the fact that the question was a serious one but the Minister's reply has been very long. I would ask him to take that into account.

—I certainly do intend to take that into account, Mr President, and I will shortly bring my reply to a conclusion. It was a very odd point of order to come from Senator Chaney. I know that he has just been endorsed for the Federal seat of Pearce and that his ambition is to lead the Opposition in the other chamber. When I am announcing a major resource project development in Western Australia, for Senator Chaney, as a Western Australian, to take such a point of order is a shameful development.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I did not take a point of order until the Minister had been giving his answer for a considerable period. I ask you to draw him to order.

—I was concluding my answer to the question by saying, before I was interrupted by the would-be member for Pearce, that I do not want to speculate too much on what the potential for natural gas discoveries off the North West Shelf would be but only to say that in recent drillings on the North West Shelf oil has been discovered. The potentiality of that field is to be, with further exploration, further proven up. I hope that we will make discoveries which will enable us to take part in exporting even more natural gas in the future from facilities such as this.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. When and under what conditions did the former Chief Executive of the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia, Mr John Friedrich, enter Australia to live? What security checks were applied to Mr Friedrich? Is Mr Friedrich an Australian citizen and, if so, what were the circumstances of his being granted citizenship?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not be known with any certainty when and where Mr Friedrich entered this country. Obviously we have been searching the files for some evidence of that but, of course, that presumes that he entered under the name of Mr Friedrich or some other known alias, and he may not have. The best possibility at this stage is that his entry to the country may have been on a transit visa for 72 hours. We are following up the leads and I do not want to explore them until we have some firm evidence. If that was the case security checks would be of a most minor nature. We should bear in mind that we are dealing with something that probably happened 14 years ago. It was quite common in the period from 1974 to 1976 for temporary visas to be granted while one was in transit, provided one could prove one was leaving the country with an outgoing air ticket, without any substantial checks.

ANSWER.PARA: On the third matter, a search of our files has not revealed that Mr Friedrich had Australian citizenship or was granted Australian citizenship. Senator Short would understand that there is some difficulty involved in searching records where at least three or four dates of birth are involved. We have found no evidence that Mr Friedrich was an Australian citizen. As I understand it he was not on the electoral roll and did not have a driver's licence or a passport. Investigations are continuing from our end but, again, I cannot guarantee that we will be able to find that material because we will not know, until Mr Friedrich is apprehended, how he arrived in the country. We have some leads and we are pursuing them right now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen an article in this morning's Australian newspaper in which comments by Mr Peacock on Australia's inflation outlook are reported? Has the Minister examined Mr Peacock's comments? Will the Government be modifying its economic policies in response to Mr Peacock's comments as reported? Are the 7.8 per cent actual inflation rate in the United Kingdom (UK) and the expected 8 per cent rate under Mrs Thatcher evidence that Conservative economic policies cannot cut inflation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the last part of the question, I do not think one fact in isolation proves anything, but it is clear evidence that the economic policies of Mrs Thatcher, whom I understand Mr Howard admires so much, have managed to produce inflation of the order of 8 per cent a year, in spite of an unemployment figure which I think is still in double figures, even after the UK Government has consistently fiddled the unemployment figures for about four years in succession. I have seen the article by Robert Hadler, and Mr Peacock is reported as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: The implicit price deflator of gross non-farm product, a broader measure of inflation than the CPI, increased by 8.9 per cent in the year to the December quarter.

That seems to imply that because of that figure Australians should not receive income tax cuts on 1 July. The figure which Mr Peacock has used appears to have been taken from page 11 of yesterday's national accounts release. I have not had an exhaustive look through that release, but if Mr Peacock had taken the trouble to look at page 11 properly he would have seen why the figure for the implicit price deflator was so high when the figure for private consumption expenditure was just over 7 per cent.

The figure was pushed up, or the discrepancy was accounted for, by a number of things. One of the major components was the increase of nearly 16 per cent in the housing price component, which refers to new housing only, in the gross domestic product deflator, and the second was a massive increase of nearly 23 per cent in the real estate transfer expenses component of the GDP deflator. Real estate agents, whose payments tend to be tied to house prices rather than the cost of the service delivered, were obviously major gainers during 1988 from the increased housing prices. Of course they are not wage and salary earners; they are by and large outside the wages system. But because housing prices surged in 1988 and real estate agents' incomes surged with them, Mr Peacock is proposing that ordinary wage earners who have abided by wage restraint policies should do without their tax cuts or make further sacrifices on the wages front. There does not seem to be very much sense in that.

The only other thing I would like to do is to canvass the possibility that Mr Peacock has received a limited and possibly misleading tutorial from Dr Hewson on the interpretation of the December quarter national accounts, and that until Mr Peacock learns how to interpret these accounts himself he should seek some other source of advice than Dr Hewson.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. With reference to the answer of the Minister to my question without notice on 7 March 1989 on the subject of Immigration Review Panel (IRP) fees, wherein he said, `. . . the Ombudsman's report provided an impetus to act now to cease Independent Review Panel arrangements . . .', I ask: Has the Minister read the Ombudsman's information bulletin on this matter, released under embargo on 19 March 1989, and the Ombudsman's report dated 17 March 1989 to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs on a complaint from Ms B on behalf of Ms D concerning the unlawfulness of Immigration Review Panel fees and the Department's attempts to recover almost $4,500 in Commonwealth legal costs from Ms D? With reference to the four recommendations at the end of that report, firstly, has the Department ceased collecting the IRP fees as from 7 March this year? Secondly, has the Department continued to provide avenues of review and, if so, how many reviews have been undertaken since collection of the fee ceased? Thirdly, is the Minister now taking all reasonable steps to refund IRP fees which had already been collected? Fourthly, has the Minister ensured that no action will be taken to recover the Department's costs of the litigation against Ms D?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Fairly obviously, I have read the Ombudsman's report. There remain a variety of matters in that report that I would contest. Rather than canvassing those publicly at this stage, I have arranged a meeting with the Ombudsman this week-I think that meeting will be held on Thursday-in which we will discuss many of the issues that Senator Jenkins has raised today. Certainly, I can state, as a general outline in answer to the honourable senator's question, that we have ceased to collect the fees. We are currently finalising the regulations for the second application. I expect those to be in operation within two weeks. As to any question of refund of previous fees or legal costs incurred by one particular litigant, I will discuss that matter first with the Ombudsman before I canvass it publicly any further.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister therefore equate a second application by a prospective migrant with a review of the first application?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —No. A second application will be judged on the circumstances applying at the time, not necessarily the circumstances that applied at the time of the first application. We are still working on those regulations, as I told Senator Jenkins earlier. We will finalise those over the next few days. They will then go to the Executive Council and eventually will be tabled here and Senator Jenkins can see them for herself.

—What information can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade provide about the recent incidents in Namibia, apparently involving a serious breakdown of the cease-fire agreement? Can the Minister explain the implications of these developments for the contingent of Australian troops committed to the United Nations Transition Assistance Group (UNTAG)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say by way of background that the cease-fire arrangements under Security Council resolution 435 provide for the confinement of South African and insurgent forces to bases while arrangements are set up for elections and the transition to an independent government. Those arrangements also envisage the deployment of United Nations (UN) Transition Assistance Group forces to ensure the disarming and monitoring within those bases of the former combatant forces. The transition period began formally three days ago, on 1 April, but since then serious clashes have occurred between elements of the South African Defence Force and Namibian police and forces described from South African sources as belonging to the South West Africa People's Organisation (SWAPO). The SADF and Namibian police elements have intercepted groups said to be moving across the Angolan border into northern Namibia in some of the most intense fighting that has occurred in the area for several years. According to South African figures, over 120 insurgents and 20 police have been killed in clashes.

ANSWER.PARA: The South African Foreign Minister, Mr Pik Botha, has held talks through the UN special representative in Namibia, Mr Ahtisaari, which resulted in an agreement with the UN Secretary-General that SADF personnel who, under the UN plan, were to be, as I have said, confined to their bases in advance of their withdrawal, may be used in support of the Namibian police as an interim measure to contain the situation. In a message addressed to me on 2 April the South African Foreign Minister has drawn attention to the serious situation and asked the Australian Government to condemn the alleged SWAPO incursions.

The situation on the ground in northern Namibia since 1 April is confused and the full facts on the reported incursions are still very unclear. The critical element that we have been waiting for, as I have said publicly, is the report of the UNTAG investigation team which visited the area on 2 April and which has forwarded its results to the UN Secretary-General. I am able to advise the Senate that informal consultations have just concluded in New York between the Secretary-General and Security Council members. I do not yet have the details of their outcome, beyond a short statement issued by the Council Chairman from the Soviet Union. That statement does not provide full information on the incidents and their origins and it is becoming apparent that it may be some time before complete accounts become available.

However, while reserving final judgment in expectation of further information, may I say quite explicitly for the record that the Australian Government does condemn any acts which are in breach of the agreements reached in the context of Security Council resolution 435 and which could lead to the breakdown of the cease-fire at this delicate stage. The transitional arrangements in Namibia can work only if all parties strictly comply with their provisions, particularly in a situation where the UN at the moment does not have sufficient personnel to observe and monitor all aspects of the arrangements until its three infantry battalions are deployed.

Incursions by armed elements moving south across the Angola-Namibia border, to the extent that they have occurred, are to be deplored. Against this must be set the possibility that the lack at this stage of full UN deployments in the north may have resulted in some confusion in the situation and the absence of a clear understanding as to where armed elements should report. It may take some time for the UN to untangle this delicate situation, and all elements for a solution may not be in place until full UNTAG deployments are effected in the north.

In the meantime, while appreciating the need to ensure basic security in the area, on behalf of the Australian Government I call on the South African authorities-as I already have in speaking yesterday to the South African Ambassador-to act with restraint and in full cooperation with UNTAG in restoring the situation. Likewise, I call on the former resistance forces to comply strictly with the accords and with the UN's efforts to bring the situation under control. Above all, it is in their interests that this plan should succeed.

I am sorry that this is a long answer, Mr President, but I need now to quickly address the final part of it, which relates to the implications of this for Australian forces. As to the question of whether this initial breakdown in the cease-fire will have longer term implications for the future of the transitional arrangements and UNTAG's role in them, I can only say that the Australian Government will keep the situation closely under review. An officer of my Department is currently in Grootfontein and we have established a liaison office in Windhoek to enable the Government to have first-hand information on the situation. Of the advance contingent of 80 Australian troops, none has been affected by the clashes of recent days. All of them are currently based in the town of Grootfontein in northern Namibia. The main contingent of 225 Australian forces is due to arrive in Namibia over the period 13 to 16 April. At this stage there are no plans to vary arrangements for the deployment of the main contingent.

Perhaps I should say finally that during my visit to New York two weeks ago I discussed the role of the UNTAG force with the UN Secretary-General, Perez de Cuellar, including the question of the size of the force. As a result of pressure from permanent members of the Security Council on budgetary grounds, a total deployment of 4,650 was authorised in the first instance as against the original upper ceiling of 7,500. However, the Secretary-General has retained the right to increase the force to the original number if he is satisfied that the situation on the ground requires it and I am sure, on the basis of my discussion with him, that he will be both able and willing to exercise his own unfettered judgment in this respect.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. I remind him that on 9 March in answer to a question from Senator Archer he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The fact is that we believe the Australian Federal Police has the capacity to absorb the cost of that-
that is, the Winchester investigation-
operation within the moneys that are appropriated for their particular purposes.

Yesterday the Government granted for Australian Federal Police (AFP) operations an additional $500,000 in funding which, according to the Minister's press release, is in part to alleviate pressure arising from the Winchester investigation. Is it not the case that the Minister knew on 9 March that other policing functions were having to be curtailed as a result of the cost of the Winchester and other major investigations? Why did he let the position develop so that, for example, one recent drug surveillance operation in Sydney ceased at 11 p.m. when the force ran out of overtime? Why did he not provide the funding on the initial advice of Commissioner McAulay rather than wait for the police to have to commence unprecedented industrial action before taking action? If the Winchester reward of $200,000 now offered by the Government is claimed, will it come out of Australian Federal Police funds, or is the Government making a genuine commitment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is making a very genuine commitment to the future operations of the Australian Federal Police, the premier law enforcement agency at the Commonwealth level, operating throughout Australia. Indeed, it has been very pleasing to have the support of my Cabinet colleagues in obtaining extra funding for the Australian Federal Police which will enable some relief to be obtained from the restrictions which were in place. I have never denied during the last several weeks nor in this place that some rather severe curtailments of overtime and consequent penalty rates were put into place by the Commissioner, directing the various managers of the Australian Federal Police, in order to achieve the proper management of the budget that the AFP was given.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is, as I say, that the Cabinet decided yesterday to make an additional half a million dollars available in funding for the operations of the Australian Federal Police around Australia. The difficulties of the Australian Federal Police in relation to its budget were twofold. One was the failure of the management of the Australian Federal Police to achieve the offsets in savings which were required under the second tier arrangements. There was a requirement, for example, that rosters be reorganised and that allowances which depended on position rather than performance be done away with. These matters, because they were not dealt with by management as speedily or in as timely a fashion as they should have been, led to some of the problems in the budget. Also, considerable resources were devoted to the investigation into the killing of Assistant Commissioner Winchester.

Because of those strains, the AFP naturally sought some relief and the Federal Government was pleased to respond. Indeed, the Commissioner has now been able to put out a statement indicating that he found the injection of an additional half million dollars very welcome and that it would `ensure that important operations which were in accord with the Government's priorities would continue to be met'. As I emphasised at the time, I had sought and received the advice of the Commissioner to the effect that no major operations of the Australian Federal Police nor the safety of its members were imperilled by the particular stringencies which he imposed in the various regions and in the Australian Capital Territory. The Australian Federal Police Association, in its response yesterday, said in relation to the Government:
. . . speaks well of their commitment to the AFP and to the public.

So I believe that the Government, not only in relation to the particular matter that has arisen over the last few weeks but also over the last three or four years, has shown a quite unequalled commitment to ensuring that the Australian Federal Police achieves the focus and attains the goals that have been set for it. For example, the Government approved an extra 294 staff for the AFP under the force development program over the three years 1985-88 at a cost of $9m per annum. A further $3m was allocated in 1988-89 to provide up to 85 additional staff under a new force development program. That is just one instance of many that I could give of the commitment of this Government in budgetary terms.

The final question was about the reward offer, which is still in place. The reward is a very important element of the investigation into the killing of Assistant Commissioner Winchester. It has three elements. The first is the money, the second is the offer of protection to an informant, and the third escapes me for the moment. But the reward offer, in so far as it embraces a money element, is to be funded separately if it is called upon by the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Does the strong capital expenditure figure in yesterday's national accounts indicate that the necessary investment is taking place in industry for restructuring Australia's economy?
—How long do we have to wait?

—The honourable senator will have to wait a few minutes while he listens to this answer. It is going to take a little while. The national accounts data for the December quarter 1988 confirm that the main driving force in the economy has been a massive increase in business investment, accounting for 1.5 per cent of the 1.9 per cent growth in the quarter.
—Are you telling everyone they are well off?

—No, I am telling everybody that investment is taking place; that is all I am saying. Business investment in equipment grew by 19.6 per cent in the quarter and, relatively speaking, consumption growth has been moderate. This pattern of growth is consistent with what the Government has been saying. Close examination of the data reveals that the strong growth in demand and in imports is generated by productive investment that will enhance Australia's industrial capacity, especially in the export and import competing sectors. By way of illustration, I will outline how this strong overall investment performance is influencing some key sectors such as the metals and engineering sector. The Metals Trades Industry Association recently released the results of its 1989 national survey of the metal and engineering industry which showed that over 80 per cent of firms are operating at busy or very busy levels of activity. The survey is the largest and most comprehensive of its type in Australia and covers more than 1,000 companies employing more than 150,000 people. The data shows a further improvement in the state of the industry as well as demonstrating an improvement in export sales. It confirms that the industry is actively restructuring and investing in new plant and equipment to provide a case for increased productive and export capacity. At the same time, Australian Bureau of Statistics data shows that the engineering construction sector's output rose by 15 per cent in the December quarter. A large proportion of that increase was in the heavy engineering sector, buoyed by the strong investment activity in the mineral based industries, especially in oil--
—What about our inflation? Let us talk about that.

—I suppose Senator Walters wants me to compare it with the United States or the United Kingdom as she did last year. I will do it for her if she wants. A large proportion of that increase was in the heavy engineering sector, buoyed by strong investment activity in the mineral based industries, especially oil and gas refineries, coal processing facilities and chemical plants. Of course, the Government is concerned about whether strong overall economic growth may not be sustainable over the long term because of the pressure this generates in balance of payments and prices. The composition of this demand, concentrated as it has been in capital expenditure, no doubt has been beneficial for economic restructuring. The correct mix of tight monetary, fiscal and wages policy is in place and will be maintained to address this pressure.

—My question is to the Minister for Justice. Is the Government seeking to resolve its Australian Federal Police funding problems by withdrawing the AFP's airport security function and transferring that role to the State police? Is not this step simply a further winding down of the Australian Federal Police and an abdication of the Commonwealth's responsibility in anti-terrorist operations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any decision by the Government to transfer the uniformed policing role of the Australian Federal Police at airports to State or Northern Territory police forces would not be undertaken with any budgetary motive impelling such a decision. It would be taken because the anti-terrorist report provided to the Government by Mr Holdich in 1986 indicated that the functions of uniformed policing conducted by the Australian Federal Police at certain security designated airports were threefold: one was community policing, which obviously could be well undertaken by State police forces; another was to act as something of a deterrent just by their mere presence; and the other was a holding operation in case of a terrorist incident. The advice to the Government in that report was that it would be better to have integrated lines of command with no difficulty whatsoever in transfer of responsibility for resolving an incident. A much clearer integrated response could be achieved if the uniformed police force conducting the holding operation was the police force that would actually help resolve the incident. It was in order to get that continuity that the advice was given that we should seek to place the State or Northern Territory police forces in the airports concerned. It would be those motives which would impel the Government to such a decision.

ANSWER.PARA: May I also point out that there is a separate operation by the Australian Federal Police at major airports, called Portswatch, which, as Senator Archer would recall, is a non-uniformed police presence which, of course, would not be affected by such a decision. Those are more detective type functions, rather than the community policing or anti-terrorist type holding operation functions in respect of which, as I say, the advice received by the Government back in 1986 was to the effect that they would best be undertaken by one integrated, uniformed police force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister advise whether the question is currently under consideration, and whether that also applies to the various surveillance functions of the AFP?

—The question of uniform policing at airports is currently a matter of consideration and deliberation by the Government. I do not quite understand what the honourable senator means by `surveillance functions of the AFP'. As the honourable senator will know, in his Party's own policy document there is talk of the AFP being involved in certain guarding functions, for example, in respect of Parliament House and so on, which is no longer the case. But, certainly, if by surveillance the honourable senator means detective type duties in relation to the importing of drugs or following up allegations of major fraud against the Commonwealth, there is no intention to transfer those matters to State or Territory police forces.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. In view of the disaster caused in the last few days by cyclonic and other adverse weather activity, claiming lives of persons and livestock and massive destruction of property, can the Minister advise the Senate of any requests for financial assistance from the various States or Territories involved? If such requests were received, what would be the financial response from Canberra?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under arrangements of, I think, some four years duration, the States and Territories are eligible for natural disaster relief payments for such things as cyclones, floods and storms, subject to certain criteria. The arrangements recognise that the States have the primary responsibility for limited disasters. Consequently up to a threshold level, which I think is 0.225 per cent of a State's total annual budget sector revenue and grants two years earlier, the States accept all the responsibility. For the tranche-I am going from memory here-equal to 75 per cent of that amount, the costs are shared dollar for dollar between the State and the Commonwealth. Beyond that second tranche of payments, the Commonwealth pays $3 for every State dollar.

ANSWER.PARA: There are guidelines which are agreed for the declarations of those disasters or adverse storms, floods and so on which qualify for relief. The relief includes grants for the relief of personal hardship and distress, that is, for the provision of emergency food, clothing and accommodation; and concessional loans to farmers and small businesses, and needy persons and voluntary non-profit bodies whose assets have been significantly damaged and who have no reasonable access to commercial finance. I might say at this point that that particular condition appears to have been repeatedly breached by the Queensland Government over a number of years, not so much with respect to flood or storm damage to my knowledge but with respect to so-called drought. There are also grants for public undertakings for restoration of essential public assets such as roads, buildings and bridges. But the guidelines do not normally include damage to State government business enterprises.

The Commonwealth will continue to apply these conditions for the current flood and storm damage in Queensland and New South Wales, but as yet I am in no position to make an estimate of the payments that are likely to be made-although in the case of Queensland I understand the second tranche of the cost sharing arrangements has already been passed and any additional payments in this financial year will be shared $3 Commonwealth dollars to one Queensland Government dollar, which is of course a quite generous arrangement. The Commonwealth will stand by those commitments for the present flood and cyclone damage.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Does the Minister agree that in his press statement of August last year on incentives provided by the Commonwealth to encourage the Wesley Vale project and his joint statement with the Prime Minister in October there was no suggestion or hint of any impediments in the way of a pulp mill? On the contrary, the language used by the Minister and the Prime Minister was extremely positive and enthusiastic. Was there any doubt in the Minister's mind at these times that the project would proceed? When did the Minister become aware of the danger of rejection of the project on environmental grounds?

—At the time when the joint venturers announced their intention to proceed with the pulp mill I certainly welcomed that decision and I was not aware of any impediment to the pulp mill at that time. I thought that my colleague Senator Richardson would be able to rely on the Tasmanian Government to provide appropriate environmental guidelines because that was what the Commonwealth had sought from the Tasmanian Government. It was my belief at that time that the Tasmanians would provide appropriate environmental guidelines. I think Senator Richardson would probably say that in their first go at it they got pretty near to it, but then they changed their minds about that. At that time, if I cast my mind back, I would think that there were few inhibitions because I thought that issue had been resolved and that the Tasmanians would do an appropriate job on that matter. I am sorry, what was the second part of the question?
—When did you first become aware of the danger of rejection?

—It was not a question of rejection; it was a matter of whether the Commonwealth would approve the foreign investment in the mill. Under the foreign investment legislation there are provisions that if a proposed investment is environmentally unsound or not acceptable then the Government will not approve foreign investment in the mill. That was a decision which was reached ultimately. It was not a question of any other inhibition. It is very hard to say when I first became aware, but I suppose it was at the time the Commonwealth first got into discussions with the Tasmanian Government about the environmental issue in a serious way, which was towards the end of last year. That would have been the time that I and others were first aware of it.

—Mr President, I would like to ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that Simon Crean had some very critical remarks to make about the failure of the Government to bring together an environment strategy and effective industry development strategy. I ask the Minister why it is that the Government did not manage to bring together its environmental and industry development strategies to ensure that this thing would not be knocked on the head at the last minute.

—I think I have really already answered that question. In so far as the financial aspects of the mill and Commonwealth involvement in that were concerned, those matters were resolved at some date late last year. At that time the Commonwealth believed that it would get some satisfactory environmental impact statement from the Tasmanian Government. It did not do that. I have explained that in the original part of my answer. That was an act of faith, I suppose, on behalf of the Commonwealth, and we were let down in that respect.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources. I note the allegations in the Australian Financial Review concerning the alleged failure of the Government to offer any exploration acreage in the Timor Gap region in the latest release of exploration permits. What is the Government doing in regard to the release of areas for exploration? Further, in light of the full page advertisements by Esso Australia Ltd concerning alleged constraints on the industry due to excise, what is the Government doing to address this industry concern?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article in today's Australian Financial Review headed `Timor Gap remains off limits'. I think there is a fundamental misunderstanding by the writer of what the Government did. Yesterday I announced the release of oil exploration acreage for bidding for oil exploration companies, and the bids are now open. Maps and seismic data are available from the Department. Those areas for bidding are in the Timor Sea, Bass Strait and western Tasmania. The purpose for those biddings is that they are areas of reasonable prospectivity. It is part of our annual program to release, sequentially, areas of offshore Australia for private companies to bid for the right to explore for oil. The basis of determining those bids is on which company is going to put together the best work program which would justify us releasing those areas for their exclusive exploration for the particular period.

ANSWER.PARA: That is a normal, regular and routine procedure by the Commonwealth. To confuse that with the Timor Sea joint development zone between Australia and Indonesia is to make a fundamental error. The negotiations for the joint development zone with Indonesia are on track. They were never thought to be available for exploration by this time. It was announced in October last year that it was hoped that within 12 months the negotiations would be concluded. The expectation is that the negotiation will be concluded this calendar year. The negotiations are proceeding well and the prospect is that we will meet that target. There is this fundamental misunderstanding because the speculative hype that has been developing over the Timor Sea has obscured the fact that there are still a lot of offshore areas available for exploration which should be taken up by Australian or overseas companies to explore for oil, and they hold reasonable prospects of finding oil or hydrocarbons. That should not in any way be confused with the Timor Sea.

The second part of the question was about Esso. I have only a few words to say about Esso's latest excursion into advertising. Last year Esso approached the Commonwealth for a reduction in excise because the price of oil had fallen. The price of oil was looking as though it would fall below $10 per barrel. We are now seeing, for West Texas Intermediate, a benchmark crude of above $20 a barrel. We offered Esso a reduction in excise because of the falling price last year. Esso knocked back that reduction. What it is now doing is advertising that the tax regime should be reduced or lessened in some way in order that there be an incentive to encourage it to do more. What Esso would be better doing, rather than wasting its money on a non-productive advertising campaign, is to spend some of that money on doing some of the things that it said it would do if the excise were reduced. It has had its opportunity to get a reduced excise. It refused that, and now the price of oil is so sufficient as to not require the Commonwealth to make that offer a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Why did the Prime Minister attend a special Australian Labor Party function for the rebel East Timorese Fretilin movement in Darwin last weekend? Did the Prime Minister deliberately snub Indonesia by this peculiar social function? Did the Prime Minister invite the Indonesian Consul to the Northern Territory to any other function during his visit or meet with Dr Halim? Is it the policy of the Labor Federal Government, with its left wing socialist bias, to show favouritism to the breakaway Fretilin movement rather than the official Indonesian representatives?

—I have no knowledge of the particular function to which Senator Tambling refers. I find it wildly implausible that the Prime Minister would have administered any snub, deliberately or otherwise, to any representative of the Indonesian Government. I will seek his response to the question in order to respond more fully to it, but I am glad to acknowledge that at least someone still thinks that we do have a left wing socialist bias.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It refers specifically to the full-page advertisement that the Government had placed in the Australian at the weekend dealing with the declaration at The Hague. Did the Minister say at The Hague on 11 March, `Climate change and the protection of the atmosphere is the biggest problem, the biggest challenge, faced by mankind in this or any other age.'? Is the Minister aware that climatologists predict that, as a result of greenhouse warming, tropical cyclones are likely to become more intense and move further south in Australia? Is he, therefore, aware that the cyclone presently approaching the Queensland coast is consistent with greenhouse warming and that this phenomenon is likely to become more intense and more frequent? Does the Minister still support Australia's strong and continued dependence on coal and forest exports? In the light of his expressed concern that this is the biggest challenge faced by mankind in this and any other age, will he now be advising his colleagues to change Australia's present export policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did say at The Hague on 11 March, in signing the declaration for Australia, the words Senator Coulter retails about the atmospheric problems being the biggest challenge that we confront in the decades ahead. In that speech I was referring not only to the greenhouse effect but to the question of the depletion of the ozone layer and the whole series of related climatic phenomena which together constitute such a problem. As to the second part of Senator Coulter's question, I am aware that some studies suggest that tropical cyclone activity may become more intense and move further south as a result of the greenhouse effect. I am also aware, as I said in another part of the speech I gave in The Hague, that it is not possible to predict with certainty the likely impact of the greenhouse effect on the global climate, and it is even more difficult to predict climate changes on a regional basis.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the third part of the question, while the cyclone approaching the Queensland coast may be consistent with some predictions of the consequences of the greenhouse effect, I believe that there is general agreement among the scientific community that the various scenarios of climate change that have been developed in recent years cannot and should not be tested against current actual climate. If we base our perception of climate change on short term variations in the climate there is a very real danger that our recognition of the importance of the greenhouse issue may be reversed as a result of subsequent short term climate pattern variations of that kind. It is for that reason that the declaration adopted at The Hague, with strong support from Australia, stressed the need for more scientific work and more research on the causes and implications of climatic change and, indeed, warned against the kind of instant coffee analysis that we get from people such as Senator Coulter on occasions such as this.

Finally, as to the last part of his question, about coal and forest exports, it is wildly premature at this stage to be contemplating any unilateral action of the kind that Senator Coulter recommends, with his feet firmly planted in mid-air as usual. Atmospheric protection is a global problem which demands a global response. Obviously, fossil fuel burning and the preservation of forests, which as has been well said are the lungs of the planet, are important issues that will have to be addressed by the world at large over the period ahead. They are issues with which we are all going to have to grapple, but on the basis of fair and equitable international burden-sharing, which is another theme of The Hague declaration, which I am glad Senator Coulter read in the advertisement which appeared in the newspapers over the weekend, I simply make the point that the beginnings of a rational response to these questions, and in particular, the question of fossil fuel burning, would be for us to reduce our dependence on fossil fuel burning in favour of much greater reliance on nuclear energy in the period ahead. But I suppose getting Senator Coulter, or any other Australian Democrat, to espouse that little bit of rationality in response to this huge international problem is more than we can reasonably expect.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am very interested in the Minister's reply and the indication that he has very little understanding of the nuclear inability to solve that problem. I draw his attention to one of the sections of the declaration of The Hague, to which he is apparently a signatory, because his signature appeared on that page-unless, of course, he regards Australia as a banana republic. The Declaration of The Hague says, among other things:

QUESTION.PARA: Most of the emissions that affect the atmosphere at present originate in the industrialised nations. And it is in these same nations that the room for change is greatest, and these nations are also those which have the greatest resources to deal with this problem effectively.

Is the Minister aware that Australia, with only 0.3 per cent of the global population, nonetheless contributes to 1.5 per cent of global carbon dioxide? In view of Senator Button's reply to an earlier question and Senator Cook's replies to two questions earlier with respect to coal, petroleum and natural gas, I ask the Minister again: will he press his colleagues to shift the Government's emphasis away from encouraging the export of coal, petroleum and gas into other areas?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter acknowledges that the rest of the industrialised world contributes something like 98.5 per cent to the problem, so any contribution that we might make to its resolution is not going to make much difference unless it is done in unison with the other industrialised nations of the world. It is a global problem which demands a global response. It may well be that part of that response is to reduce dependence on the particular kinds of fuel burning that are particularly harmful in this respect. That is cheerfully acknowledged, but to hare off on wide-eyed unilateral action of the kind that is promoted by the Australian Democrats, with utter and total disregard for the economic implications of what they are proposing and the context in which these things have to be addressed, is, as I say, to follow the prescriptions of those who simply do not have their feet on the ground.
