—On 15 December last year Senator Knowles put a question without notice to me as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The answer to the four points of that question, relating to the band known as Scrap Metal, are as follows; first, no, loans totalling $60,000 have been approved. Secondly, after an initial submission by Mr Yu, these loans were approved following an assessment of projected income for the band. Thirdly, the minutes for the meeting do not indicate any declaration of interest by Acting Commissioner Yu. He remained at the meeting during the debate and participated in the framing of the decision. Fourthly, this question does not arise as moneys were made available following assessment of the viability of the project.

—On 28 February Senator Tambling asked me a question relating to the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Auditor-General. In response, I am advised as follows. The Commission has not sent a letter to the Auditor-General's Office accusing the office of racism, incompetence and unprofessional conduct. Comment was provided to the Auditor-General's Office on audit reports made as part of its special audit. Such comment is part of the `Audit in confidence' correspondence and as such it is not appropriate to table such documents. All matters requiring major comment have been approved by the board of the Commission.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION: WODEN TOWN CLUB LIABILITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling asked me a question without notice on 2 March concerning the Woden Town Club. The relevant parts of the answer are as follows. The Aboriginal Development Commission has agreed in principle to support the establishment costs of a scheme as arranged by the provisional liquidator, to a maximum of $40,000. The total indebtedness of the Woden Town Club is being investigated by a provisional liquidator and will be determined following a series of meetings with all creditors as part of the proposed scheme of arrangement. It is considered that the actual amount of indebtedness falls within the commercial in-confidence category and therefore will not be released by the Commission. The Commission guaranteed a loan of $415,000 to the National Australia Bank at Belconnen.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne asked me a question without notice on 9 March 1989, and I sought an answer from the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), which provided the following information: the Western Australian region of the ADC requested an additional $30,000 for its 1988-89 administrative budget on 18 January 1989. This request was amended to $224,000 on 3 February 1989 following discussions with senior head office (HO) staff.

ANSWER.PARA: I was then asked whether the Acting General Manager of the ADC, Mr Cedric Wyatt, refused this request. The answer is that Mr Wyatt did not refuse the request at any stage. He did in fact refer the resulting recommendation by HO staff for supplementary funding of $128,000 to the Management Committee of the ADC for consideration in the context of the state of the Commission's overall administrative budget, including bids from other regions.

I was then asked whether the Western Australian office would close down the following week. The answer is that the Regional Manager of the Western Australian region sought approval from the Acting General Manager on 7 March 1989 to advise branch managers to cease field operations at close of business on 7 March 1989. The Acting General Manager did not approve the request and the Western Australian offices did not close down. The Acting Assistant General Manager (Administration) had informed the Western Australian Regional Manager, in a number of telephone conversations that, notwithstanding serious concerns expressed about financial administration in the Western Australian region, the recommendation for supplementary funds of $128,000 would be considered on the merits of the case at the proper time. In the event, the Acting General Manager approved the recommendation on 15 March 1989.

I have already responded to the other parts of the question. I was asked: is the Minister aware of the fact that $128,000 has been sought and denied? Obviously I have provided an answer to that already. Finally, I was asked: is that a concern to the Minister, and what does he intend to do about it? The answer provided is that, although the Commission believes that the question has already been satisfied, where there is any administrative problem which affects the delivery of services to clients or the staff delivering these services, then this is of concern to the Minister. In this case, however, the matter has been handled appropriately by the ADC senior management.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of honourable senators the imminent retirement of Mrs Joan Frost, who has loyally served this and previous parliaments continuously since 1952. Joan began her career as a casual waitress during the first session of the Twentieth Parliament and worked in the dining rooms in casual and sessional capacities until 1968, when she became senior waitress in charge of the members' dining room. Joan continued as senior waitress for 10 years until she became a full time office assistant in 1978. Joan's career culminated in her frequently acting as Food Service Manager from 1983 onwards and she was substantively promoted to that level in 1988.

INTERJECT.PARA: Her 37-year record of service to the Parliament forms part of a longer family tradition. Her father was Chef at the Hotel Canberra for many years and Catering Manager of the Parliamentary Catering Service until his retirement in 1965. Her late husband, Reg, originally a bellboy at the Hotel Canberra, subsequently became a barman in the members' bar before becoming a Senate attendant. Their four children also did some casual catering work in the old Parliament House. Senators may wish to make their personal farewells to Joan at a reception being held in her honour in the members' guests lounge at 6.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 5 April 1989. I am sure honourable senators all join with me in wishing Joan well for a long, happy and well-merited retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I rise to speak briefly on the 1987-88 annual report of the Young Endeavour Youth Scheme. My actions today have been prompted by the opportunity which I had to examine the Young Endeavour during its visit to Hobart for the tall ships race. I can certainly tell those who have not had the opportunity to see this vessel under full sail, apart from the photograph on the front of the report of course, that it is a magnificent sight. The grace and beauty of tall ships evoke memories of the old sailing ships which once sailed the world's trade routes and contributed so much to Australia's early development.

When the Young Endeavour was in Hobart, I spoke to some of the officers and crew members, and it was obvious that the concept of involving young people in sail training programs was very well received by all concerned. The Young Endeavour, as honourable senators are probably all aware, came to Australia as a bicentennial gift from the United Kingdom. It provides an opportunity for young people to develop, to mature and to equip themselves for their later role in modern society. In addition, crew members also have the opportunity to learn sailing and nautical skills.

It is also appropriate that I pause briefly to make a quick remark about the Lady Nelson project. This ship is to become a sail training vessel in my State of Tasmania. The Lady Nelson will seek to provide young people with experiences similar to those which they may get on the Young Endeavour. The community support for the Lady Nelson project has been outstanding, and I believe crews are now being trained so that an intense sail training program can be undertaken.

I note with interest that crew for the Young Endeavour are selected from all types of backgrounds, and I believe this principle should be adhered to if the aims and objectives are to be best realised. One aspect of the vessel's program which has not received much publicity has been the number of one-day cruises which operate each year for groups of disabled people. Whilst these individuals participating in these voyages are unable physically to involve themselves to the level of other participants, they are nevertheless encouraged to take part as much as possible in the practical training and sailing of the ship. Three one-day cruises for the disabled were held in Port Phillip Bay in March and another four in Moreton Bay in May and June. I am confident that the Young Endeavour will fulfil a vital role in introducing young people to the life skills which they will need to be successful in their later years. Let us hope that before too much longer the vessel will have the opportunity to visit some of our more isolated ports so that the spirit and purpose of this venture can be relayed to those communities.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I raise the very real concern which came out of what has been known as the Zemskov affair. Not surprisingly, the Government seeks from the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO), as we understand it, security assessments before Australia grants visas to foreign diplomats who are due to arrive in this country. As I said, that seems to be a sensible approach. However, what does not seem to be sensible is the fact that we saw in the Zemskov affair the granting of a visa before ASIO made, and delivered to the Government, its assessment. I ask: What is the point of seeking from our principal security intelligence organisation advice as to whether a visa should be given to a foreign diplomat to enter this country if the Government is not prepared to wait until it receives that advice and take it into account in determining whether or not to give the visa?

In the case of Mr Zemskov it seems that information produced by ASIO and delivered to the Government was such that the Government may well have had to give very serious consideration as to whether the visa should have been granted. Of course, it was pre-empted from doing so by the fact that Mr Zemskov was already in Australia. I suggest that that practice of the Government undermines ASIO's confidence. It would also have the effect to some extent of undermining the community's confidence in the work that ASIO does. This area is of principal importance to the security of this country. ASIO is skilled and is now well-resourced. Its views should be properly taken into account by government. I hope that a repeat of the Zemskov affair, when the Government did not wait for a security clearance before granting a visa, does not occur again.

That is the only matter I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate. I am sorry that I did not find reference to it in the report because I think it would have been reasonable for ASIO, which we now know has privately complained to the Government about its practice in this regard, to have put on the public record so that we all would have known of that deficiency in government practice and would have been able to use our endeavours to express to the Government the importance of awaiting security clearances and seriously taking them into account in a decision to grant or not to grant visas. I understand that my colleague Senator Michael Baume wishes to raise a matter on the Auditor-General's assessment of ASIO. I defer to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) has a special responsibility to conduct its affairs, particularly its financial affairs, in a squeaky-clean way. After all, it is not obliged to provide copies of its reports to this Parliament. We have to depend on an auditor's certificate to establish that the No. 1 account, which is a relatively public account, is kept properly, whereas details of the No. 2 account, which involves expenditure directly related to intelligence service activities, is a private account. Details are certainly not disclosed and it comprises only a small proportion of the total Budget allocation which, in the latest year, was $35.73m.

SPEECH.PARA: I am most concerned about this report to Parliament by ASIO for a couple of reasons. In the first place, it is another manifestation of the sloppy management of this Government in its manner of advising the Parliament of what has actually happened among its agencies. This report for the year ended June 1988 was dated 13 February by the Director-General in his letter to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and is now presented to the Parliament in April. There remain only three months of the current financial year. So we have received this report nine months later, which makes a mockery of the comment towards the end of the report about the year ahead. During 1988-89, among its major emphases ASIO expects to do a whole range of things. Naturally, it would be able to say that with some confidence because the year is three-quarters over. It would certainly have some knowledge of what it expects to do in the year ahead when the year is almost completed.

Let us look at the question of the audit, because I believe this a matter of some significance. As I said, ASIO, being a secret organisation and not being obliged to provide accounts in its annual report, has a special responsibility to behave in the most careful and proper way in the handling of finance. Page 47 of the report reads:
Audit
Officers of the Australian Audit Office examined ASIO's No. 1 Account and its supporting records during the year.
They are the matters we do not see, by the way. It continues:
Matters brought to the Director-General's attention by the Auditor-General included:
Weaknesses in procedures for the examination and payment of accounts;
Delays in implementing improvements to the maintenance of photographic and electrical equipment asset registers-
and this one grabs me-
Continued inability to reconcile a Central Office bank account.

We have no idea of the magnitude of these problems. All we know is that the Auditor-General says that ASIO has not done its job properly in this area. It has a special responsibility to do the job properly because of the secret and confidential nature of what it does. I am not pressing for this information to be made public. I am simply pressing for a better job to be done and for this Government-particularly the Department of Finance, which is supposed to supervise these things-to take a stronger and more effective role in government which, of course, it is not too good at. It should make certain that its operations work properly. The report continues:
The Director-General-
that is, the Director-General of ASIO-

advised the Auditor-General of action taken or planned to resolve these matters. When these actions are accomplished, ASIO will have achieved a considerable improvement in the administration of its expenditure . . .

We have no indication of when these actions are likely to be accomplished. Have they been accomplished? What are the actions, anyway, and can we have confidence, at this stage, nine months after the end of the financial year, that ASIO has its financial house in order? If ASIO expects to be treated in the manner which I am certain that members on this side would like to treat it-that is, with respect-it must respond effectively and properly in its financial management. According to this report, it appears to have failed to do so. We have no idea of the magnitude of the problem. I hope for ASIO's sake that it is small, but we have no way of telling. That gives ASIO a special responsibility which, unfortunately, on this occasion it has not lived up to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the annual report of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO). I remind the Senate that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation was a creation of a Labor Government in the late 1940s. However much one might dislike the idea of intelligence organisations probing into the affairs of a country, they are absolutely necessary from a security point of view. It would be no overstatement to say that those on this side of the chamber have some grave reservations as to how efficient ASIO has become under the present administration. We have seen three directors in the time that Labor has been in office here. We have seen an evangelistic ideologue, in the form of Senator Evans when he was Attorney-General, who apparently dramatically changed the operational parameters under which ASIO worked without affecting the legislation; but, in practice, the way the organisation pursued its activities allegedly was changed dramatically. Whether it was changed for the better is a point that has never been established. Sadly, Senator Evans has now gone on to the ministry of Foreign Affairs, where he controls the other security body, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. It is presumed that significant changes have been made to the only two security bodies we have in this country. We simply do not know whether those changes have been for the benefit and the welfare of the Australian community at all, and some of us suspect that they may be for the worse.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation report by Mr Moten, who is the new Director-General, is an interesting and worthwhile report to have before us, but it is really an administrative document. It tells what ASIO's functions are and, in simple terms, how it goes about what it sets out to do. Unfortunately, it does not give any details at all as to what it is actually doing, beyond listing the number of people who applied for security clearance during the year, which really is an irrelevant and meaningless statistic. It would be possible, in my judgment, to have a more comprehensive report of its field activities without compromising security in any way. I believe that the Parliament and the Australian community would support bodies such as ASIO and their activities if the community were better informed. I do not believe that in the modern age the absolute cloak of secrecy aids the acceptance of these bodies in our society in any way.

I refer to the point that Senator Hill raised in relation to the Zemskov affair. What is the point of having a body such as ASIO if the Government goes ahead willy-nilly and appoints diplomats before the security clearance is received? Like it or not, it happens to be one of the standard procedures that one looks at diplomats before their credentials are accepted in the host country. It is not something that only Australia does; every country does that. People known to have been engaged to varying degrees in spying activities are not accepted on the diplomatic list. In the case of Mr Zemskov, the Government went ahead before the ASIO report came in. The ASIO report identified Mr Zemskov as a member of an ultra-secret group, an elite group, of the KGB. Senator Hill did not say this, but it would have been quite possible for the Government to have withdrawn Mr Zemskov's visa. That would have been the correct procedure for the Government to have followed. It has been an absolute rule, whether a Liberal government or a Labor government has been in power federally in Australia, that anyone identified as a KGB agent has not been allowed diplomatic entry.

In conclusion, I reiterate the request I made earlier-that Mr Moten in next year's report give us some insight into the broad areas in which ASIO is operating and what difficulties it has in operating so that we in the Parliament can support it in its essential function.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The annual report of the Department of Industrial Relations is a curious document, particularly in the context of the present situation with Australian wages growth, which is running at about 7 per cent on the latest survey estimates, far above the Budget estimates and far above all the measures which are reasonable. This indicates to us that Australia is doing badly on the comparative costs scale and particularly on the scale of productivity. At the same time as wages growth is running at around 7 per cent, labour productivity in Australia is estimated by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development to be running at an annual rate of only 0.3 per cent, only about a quarter of the average for the OECD countries, which at present average around 1.2 per cent. Looking at a table of productivity growth, one will see that it is hard to find any country of any substance with a lower productivity increase than Australia. To measure productivity the Government uses a curious measurement which is totally misleading. The figures in the OECD economic survey are the accurate ones, for those who do not want to be fooled by this Government. Certainly labour productivity is estimated to be running at an annual rate of 0.3 per cent, compared to the rate for the OECD of 1.2 per cent. The rate in the United Kingdom is 1.8 per cent; the rate in Japan is 2.2 per cent; and the rate in the United States is 0.8 per cent. I refer to those countries because they are our major trading partners. It is clearly unsatisfactory that we are having that appalling productivity rate at the same time as we are having a large wages growth. Taken together, nominal unit labour costs growth in Australia has accelerated and has been consistently double the rate of our major trading partners. As Syntec noted recently:
We have drifted higher and higher in relative costs, which tells us that the much-vaunted Accord is not yet doing its job.

We are told that the accord is the answer to all problems. If this is the outcome of the accord, it appears to have helped create problems rather than resolve them. The cost of the Government's failure to control nominal unit labour costs is high inflation, deteriorating competitiveness, lower living standards and, for all those people who are unable to meet their mortgage repayments, much higher interest rates. The solution is not to lower wages-and the rigid system the Government supports seems to offer only that solution-but to increase productivity by encouraging investment and more efficient workplaces. That is what is clearly needed in Australia. It is in this latter area that the Department of Industrial Relations has failed. Its major contribution in recent years has been the Industrial Relations Bill, which represents a missed opportunity for genuine reform, although it claims on page 3 of the report that the Act `overcomes deficiencies and sets the direction which the Government believes Industrial Relations should take'.

The report's comments on page 3 also make interesting reading, claiming that wages policy `has been able to provide appropriate responses to a rapidly changing and difficult economic environment'. That is a curious conclusion in view of the disastrous growth in nominal unit labour costs and the productivity figures which show a lack of adequate growth. Overall, this annual report does little more than outline the basic failure of this Government in its major area of industrial relations, an area in which it claims to have succeeded. When we look at the facts, look at what is happening internationally, look at what is happening to our productivity, and look at what is happening to our comparative wages and costs compared to the rest of the world, it is revealed that this report is simply the report of yet another governmental failure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfair to talk about productivity in the round. There are certain very efficient industries and services, and there are some very inefficient industries and services. My concern is that the Government's policy on wages at present-and indeed the policy of the Australian Council of Trade unions (ACTU) at present-is discriminating against the efficient industries. It is discriminating against those workers who over the years have ensured that there was no featherbedding and that their industries and services were in fact efficient. For example, offsets were required under the 4 per cent second tier arrangement. Some workers did not get that 4 per cent second tier increase until many months after the inefficient industries received it. Those inefficient industries could offer employers trade-offs and therefore immediately gain the 4 per cent increase. The efficient industries and services which had no fat to give away were thus denied that increase for many months.

SPEECH.PARA: This situation is arising again because of the policy of the Government and the Department of Industrial Relations. They are about to say that workers will be able to get an increase in wages in return for award restructuring and multiskilling. What about those industries and services which are efficient and which have already achieved multiskilling and award restructuring? Are employees in those industries to be denied again for many months the increases in wages to which they are entitled? Is this Government being fair in imposing that sort of policy on the trade union movement, particularly on that section of the trade union movement that has played it fair all along the line?

I get a bit sick and tired of hearing about the inefficiency of Australian workers. Some workers are efficient and some are not. At present the policy of the Government and the Department of Industrial Relations is to favour those industries which have been inefficient and to give the money to the workers in them. These industries, because they have the ability to trade off, have the ability to have some of their feather bedding unfeathered. But the workers in those industries which do not have that ability, who have done the right thing over the years, are going to be made to suffer again. This is not the last time that honourable senators are going to hear me speak on this matter in this chamber or outside of it.

No-one in the Australian Council of Trade Unions is prepared to get up and say what he thinks. Plenty of unions in the ACTU and members of the Australian Labor Party know that they have been sold down the river by this Government in respect of the shoddy deals that have taken place and the fix-ups that have involved the Department of Industrial relations, the ACTU and the Government. The accord is an accord only for the fat cats and others who are able to give way in order to get their increases. I am concerned about workers in those industries which have done the right thing over the years. I am concerned that they have been sold a pup.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present reports relating to the following projects:

SPEECH.PARA: Construction of National Biological Standards Laboratory, Symonston, Australian Capital Territory;
Commonwealth Scientific Industrial Research Organisation North Ryde laboratories site redevelopment, stage I;
Construction of a shell filling facility for St Marys Munitions Filling Factory, New South Wales.
I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the reports.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reports I have tabled relate to three projects considered by the Public Works Committee in December 1988 and brings the number of reports presented by the Committee this year to six. In relation to the proposal to redevelop facilities at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Organisation (CSIRO) North Ryde site, the Committee has concluded that to support Australia's research performance in the areas of biotechnology, mining and minerals and energy there is a need to construct new research facilities and to replace existing inadequate structures. The cost of the work is estimated to be $18.5m at August 1988 prices.

SPEECH.PARA: CSIRO informed the Committee that the current proposal is the first stage of the redevelopment of the North Ryde site. Future works are expected for the divisions of Exploration Geoscience and Coal Technology and include:
progressive demolition of 1500 square metres of substandard buildings;
refurbishment of 2000 square metres of existing accommodation;
construction of 8500 square metres of new accommodation; and
improvements to roads, site entry, car parks and landscaping.
These works are expected to be undertaken by the year 2000 at an estimated cost of some $40m at current prices.

The Committee's final report in relation to the National Biological Standards Laboratory (NBSL) is for the construction of a laboratory complex of some 17 900 square metres and the conversion of an existing laboratory at Symonston, ACT at an estimated cost of $51.4m at July 1988 prices. The Committee tabled an interim report relating to this project on 30 November 1988, indicating that it would be recommending in its final report the construction of the works in this particular reference.

The Committee's inquiry into the NBSL project is the second time that a proposal to upgrade NBSL accommodation has been examined by the Committee. In its ninth report of 1979 the Committee recommended the construction of a purpose designed complex for the NBSL at an estimated cost of $26 billion at June 1979 prices. Preliminary site works were completed but the project did not proceed beyond that stage due to a series of reviews and inquiries into Commonwealth functions, including the NBSL.

Having examined a number of laboratories occupied by the NBSL in Canberra, the Committee has concluded that there is an urgent need for the construction of a single purpose building complex for the NBSL. The Committee believes the work is necessary to overcome the problems caused by the poor state of much of NBSL's present accommodation and its dispersed distribution over many sites and buildings, which has resulted in a number of operational, managerial and scientific inefficiencies.

The final report I tabled refers to the construction of a shell filling facility for St Marys Munitions Filling Factory, New South Wales, at an estimated cost of $7.7m at April 1988 prices. The new facility will replace facilities which have been operating since 1958 and which have not reached the end of their economic life due to high usage and general wear and corrosion. In addition, fume, dust and noise levels exceed current regulatory standards. The existing facility also fails to meet North Atlantic Treaty Organisation safety principles, particularly in respect of safety distances from inhabited buildings.

The Department of Defence advised the Committee that it expected the urban encroachment in the longer term-that is, beyond 25 years-would require the transfer of the Munitions Filling Factory to another location. This is estimated to cost half a billion dollars. Following assurances from the Department of Defence and in view of the excellent safety record of the St Marys Munitions Filling Factory, the Committee is satisfied that safety risks posed by the proposed facility are minimal. The reports are recommended.

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is twofold. It aims firstly to streamline reporting arrangements for higher education institutions under the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986, and secondly to adjust the Act to reflect the circumstances of institutions planning or undergoing amalgamations in accordance with this government's policy on higher education.
The Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986 covers higher education institutions and all private sector organisations which employ 100 or more people.
The Act requires employers to introduce an affirmative action program to eliminate discrimination in employment against women, and to ensure equality of opportunity in employment for women.
Employers are also required to report annually to the Director of Affirmative Act on the progress of their programs.

The Act became effective for higher education institutions on 1 October 1986. Coverage of the private sector was phased in over a period of three years, with employers of 1,000 or more persons covered from 1 February 1987, employers of 500 or more people from 1 February 1988 and employers of 100 or more people from 1 February this year.

There has been an excellent response of the Australian employers to the legislation in the first year of the Act's operation. One hundred per cent of higher education institutions, and ninety-nine per cent of the largest private sector organisations met their reporting obligations under the Act.
This excellent level of compliance reflects the high degree of support for the Act and its objectives across all sectors of Australian industry.

It also reflects the professional manner in which the Affirmative Action Agency has carried out its responsibilities and the co-operative relationship it has established with industry. This Government has held to its commitment, in turn, to ensure that administrative tasks associated with the requirement to report under the Act are minimised.
A range of initiatives have been taken to standardise reporting and to inform employers in clear terms of their obligations.
This Bill builds further on this commitment.

Higher education institutions in New South Wales and Western Australia are currently covered by both state and federal legislation requiring the development of programs designed to provide equal employment opportunity.

The Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986 relates to women, and the state legislation in both states to aboriginals, people of ethnic background and the physically disabled.

Currently the reporting periods specified in these Acts are different. The object of this Bill in its first aspect is to move towards a common reporting date of 1 January for institutions in respect of both their federal and state reporting obligations. Under the proposed amendment, institutions would report for the period 1 January-31 December on 1 January in the following year. Relevant authorities in New South Wales and Western Australia have agreed in turn to bring their statutory reporting date into line with the 1 January reporting date proposed in this Bill.

The choice of a calendar year reporting period of 1 January-31 December reflects better the administrative arrangements of the institutions themselves. It would bring the processes of program development and reporting closer in line with the normal cycle of the institution.
The proposed Bill would therefore greatly assist institutions in meeting their obligations under the federal and state legislation.
The Bill further provides for transitional arrangements to preserve the reporting arrangements of institutions on the changeover to the proposed 1 January reporting date.

The higher education sector, like other industries throughout Australia, is undergoing significant restructuring. As part of this restructuring many institutions are considering or planning amalgamations. The creation of fewer larger institutions reflects the Government's commitment to the consolidation of institutions as set out in Higher Education: A Policy Statement-The White Paper-July 1988.

The Bill in its second aspect seeks to adjust to the changing circumstances created through amalgamations. It would ensure that institutions that amalgamate will not be regarded as new employers under the Act following the amalgamation.

Under the Affirmative Action Act, there is a hiatus between when an institution is created and when it is covered by the legislation. This hiatus is especially problematic when that new institution is created as a result of the amalgamation of existing institutions covered by the Act.

The interruption to the affirmative action program caused by this gap in coverage is not in the interests of the program and its objectives. Further, it needlessly complicates the requirements on employers by presenting changed circumstances with which they must deal.

The Bill in this aspect therefore seeks to ensure continuity of the program and to preserve reporting requirements. The proposed amendments offer certainty to institutions of their obligations under the Act at a time of major upheaval.

The proposed amendments to the Act will facilitate the implementation of the Act in the higher education sector by streamlining reporting requirements, and by ensuring continuity of coverage for institutions going through amalgamations.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed amendments have negligible financial impact. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) That the Senate take note of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Legislation Procedures.
(b) That the Senate supports in principle the recommendations contained in the report; and
(c) That, unless otherwise ordered, consideration of the recommendations be a Business of the Senate Order of the Day for 25 May 1989.

This particular report is from a select committee that this Senate established on, I think, 21 August 1988. The Select Committee on Legislation Procedures was tasked with the responsibility of looking at two major factors relating to the procedures in this chamber. One was how we could facilitate the passage of legislation without the farce of long hour sittings right on Christmas Eve when not enough proper or balanced consideration could be given to legislation. At the same time, the Committee looked at the role of committees in examining legislation-something that has been promoted in this chamber on a number of occasions but has never been formalised in procedures. From time to time and on an ad hoc basis legislation is referred to a committee and eventually a report is brought back.

This particular committee, chaired by my colleague Senator Colston, looked at a number of possibilities. It strove to come up with a balanced recommendation that would not unevenly balance the procedures of this chamber either in favour of the Government or the Opposition. I must say that I did not embrace its initial report with immense enthusiasm because I could see difficulties in it for the Government. But then again, I dare say, some of the recommendations may cause some difficulties to those in opposition or with an opposition mentality. It is certainly my belief that if we are to make these structural changes they should come into operation the day after the next election. By adopting that procedure we, on this side of the House, would be thinking of how much easier it would be in government with these procedures or how much more difficult we could make it for the changed government if we were in opposition. The same sort of thinking could apply to those opposite. I know how easy it is to get into an opposition mentality.

In terms of our credentials on this issue, when Standing Orders changes were moved in 1981 and 1982 I enthusiastically supported them. However, I ran into a fair deal of criticism in my own Party-from my good colleague Geoff McLaren and others who said, `Don't give up any rights. We have the Government over a barrel. How dare you cut speeches back from one hour to half an hour? How dare you stop the reading of petitions?', and many other superfluous proceedings that were used to waste time in this Senate.

I turn to the third recommendation I have made here and that is that we bring this matter back before the Senate on 25 May. I put a specific date in. It will be Business of the Senate. Therefore it will take priority. This is to give an assurance that we are not trying to bury it. I do not think it is possible to make an absolute conclusion on these issues today. On our side of politics we have discussed it on two or three occasions but have never come to a conclusion. I understand that probably a similar situation exists with the Liberal-National Party coalition. It has been discussed but probably no overall view has been formed on it as yet. We seek to debate some of these principles today to try to establish the position of honourable senators. Then, maybe, with some bilateral discussion before 25 May, we can draw up the Standing Orders, work out a timetable for implementation and then proceed on that basis. That would be the best procedure we could adopt here today.

I now move to the major features of the recommendations. There are really 18. They are all broken up into various sections. The first Committee recommendation was that more Bills than at present be referred to committees. I see that as having both advantages and disadvantages. It requires some goodwill; otherwise we may find that far too much legislation is just bottled up in committees. However, later procedures that set aside one day a week for those sorts of hearings will tend to overcome that. I also find it a matter of regret that if we are to refer Bills to committees, study them at great length and then proceed to the same amount of debating time at the committee stage, we would replicate the current Estimates committee system in which we might sometimes spend three days on something and find ourselves coming to the Committee the Whole, asking the same questions and getting the same answers.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a procedure to deal with that point, though.

—Yes, I think there is later on-especially that particular set of committees. I just say that for these sorts of things to work some goodwill is needed. The setting up of a selection of Bills committee is, of course, a necessary corollary to referring Bills to committees. That committee, of course, would not have a Government majority on it. I am not too concerned about that. We do not have a majority in this place. That only recognises in a de facto sense what the end result in one of these committees would probably be. Without trying to typecast senators, I think it is fair enough to say that on nearly every occasion they follow the lead of their party.

SPEECH.PARA: The next two recommendations, 1 (d) and 1 (e), really just go to the machinery matters associated with the selection of Bills procedures. I really do not have any comment on them. Recommendation 3-and this is subject to making an appropriate adjustment to broadcast time-would have us go into the committee stage with these committees on a Wednesday, in the middle of the week. There is no doubt that such a proposal could not get support if it meant vacating a broadcast day. So probably the Government would envisage-and I would be interested to hear the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and others comment on this-moving to a five-day sitting week; that is, we would sit Monday and Tuesday, we would have a committee on Wednesday, and we would sit on Thursday and Friday. So there would be ample time and there would be a protection of Question Time; we would still have four Question Times per week and we would still have the same broadcast time available.

There is really not a lot of detail of what is envisaged at the committee stage. I would envisage something like this: Bills would be referred to the standing committees; and it would be optional for a Minister to appear or not appear, but it would certainly be in the interests of the Minister to make a variety of officials available to answer questions on the technical aspects of the legislation-something that is not always done, in my experience in the Senate, sufficiently well by Ministers, simply because of the complexity of the task involved.

The second issue coming out of this is the question of delay. If a Bill is referred to a Senate committee one would not necessarily expect the result to be produced straight- away. On the other hand, one would not expect a Bill to be bottled up in a committee for a year. I would think that this also raises the question of failure to pass and the double dissolution requirements. So we might have to do a bit more thinking about exactly what is failure to pass in that context. I know that this really goes back to the McKell decision of 1951, but we would have to give that matter some consideration.

The fourth point really goes to the question of whether when every senator supports the second reading of a Bill we need to have second reading speeches or whether we can just proceed through, allowing senators to speak for five minutes on the third reading to make some general points. Again, I think that is a fairly balanced approach.

Probably one of the more dramatic changes suggested by the Committee is that, when we come to the Committee of the Whole on the Estimates, we debate what is in Estimates Committee reports and not just regurgitate the debate that has occurred in the Estimates Committee hearings.

I have no difficulty with recommendation 6. Recommendation 7 is a matter that has already been to the Procedure Committee, which used to be the Standing Orders Committee. It refers to how much time may be spent on a motion to suspend Standing Orders. I suspect that there are really two aspects to this: the first is that it is possible to disrupt the proceedings of the Senate enormously by such motions, but the second is that the great difficulty with such motions is for the Chair to determine whether the content of the speech is indeed relevant to the motion to suspend Standing Orders. That puts enormous and unfair pressure on the Chair, in my view, because there is a very fine line between arguing why Standing Orders need to be suspended and covering the substantive aspects of what one would be discussing if in fact Standing Orders were suspended. Those difficulties are, to some extent, resolved in this proposition. Even if someone does stray for the whole five minutes, it does not really cost us a lot of time or cause a lot of aggravation to the Chair.

The final matter is whether the quorum of the Senate should be reduced from one-third to one-quarter of senators. Because of a provision in the Constitution, this would require legislation to be passed by this chamber. The House of Representatives has already passed similar legislation which is now on our Notice Paper. Later this week I intend to give notice of motion for a similar provision-it is not identical-to reduce the quorum of this House. People ask, `Why is it necessary to reduce the quorum of the Senate?'. My simple answer to that is the geography of the House. I do not think it is productive for government-and I ask honourable senators on the other side of the chamber who aspire to government to think about this-for all Ministers to have to attend on all occasions when a quorum is required. That is essentially the case at the moment. With a quorum being in the order of 24, 25 or 26-I have never been certain-basically, with pairs, every Minister has to attend.

It is also true to say that calls for a quorum are a right accorded to the Opposition, if not by the Standing Orders then by tradition, to punish a government that has misbehaved. I do not see that by reducing a quorum we will in any way blunt that weapon, because the people that the Opposition will then punish are the Government backbenchers, who in turn will very quickly adjust to the behaviour of Ministers if the Ministers do not have to bear the consequences of their own actions. It is true that the geography of this place, with a three-minute walk to the chamber, means that on occasions-I have experienced this myself in the very early sittings here-a Minister may fly in the members of a committee from all around Australia to see him or her between 11 and 12 and by the time three quorums are over there is no meeting any more. I do not think that is productive for government. By advocating that I in no way imply a criticism of the Opposition's behaviour in this chamber over the last six years. Every Opposition has done it, some more mercilessly than others, I must say. Nevertheless, reducing the quorum from about 24 to 18 or 16 will not be the end of the world; it will not, in my view, in any way diminish Opposition rights in that regard. But it will recognise that we are in a new structure. The days when a Minister was within half a minute's walk of the chamber are well and truly over.

They are the eight major points. They are, I have to stress, a package. It would be very possible, I dare say, to cherrypick out the ones I like and dump the others. I have not done so, and I urge honourable senators on the other side of the chamber not to do so, because this is a balanced package. If one just grabs enough turkey for one's own plate and gives no turkey to anyone else, one does a great disservice to this chamber. If we adopt these procedures honourable senators have to understand that they are dynamically changing the committee system, and it will never be the same again. General standing and legislative purpose committees will become real legislative purpose committees-not just wide-ranging inquiries into wheat stabilisation plans, oil prospectivity or drugs in sport; we will be involving these standing committees in a very close look at legislation, often clause by clause. So it will take time and it will take resources. It will change the nature of those committees. If we impose on top of that the Estimates committees, which we have-and we do not in any way seek to remove them-and endless select committees, these committees will not be able to carry their workload.

The biggest danger I see in this regard is that if we overload the committee system too much senators will not do the work and their staff will do it, and we as a Senate will lose control of the results. It is true of any committee, but it is true that this will happen if we overload the system and have too many committees for this chamber. If honourable senators support the committee system in a genuine sense, when they approach these matters they really need to make sure that these procedures will work. The clearest way to ensure that they work is to devote a whole day, Wednesday, to them. On Wednesdays the committees would start in the morning and do their work.

I do not really have much more to add to what I have said. The general view of the Government is that, as a package, these proposals are balanced and they will enhance this chamber. There are pluses for the Government; there are minuses for the Government. As I said, earlier in the piece I thought there were too many minuses, but I have come to the conclusion that it is a much more rational way of dealing with legislation. This last minute rush that seems to occur at Christmas and in the middle of winter may well be avoided if we can adopt these particular procedures. Once again I say that I do not believe we are in a position today to resolve finally and fully all these issues. By getting the general flavour and tenor of the debate today, we will be in a position to start having discussions amongst ourselves to see where we are heading, to draw up the appropriate Standing Orders and to come back to the matter on 25 May in a much more organised fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —For some reason or other Senator Ray has attributed the long hours and the late Christmas sitting in which we excelled ourselves last year to the way the Senate is run year after year. That is not so. I believe that last year was just an example of very bad administration by the Government. When one has a look at the numbers of parliamentary sitting days in 1987 in Canada, the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Australia, one finds that the Australian Parliament sat for only 84 days and passed 184 Bills. In the Australian Parliament 2.19 Bills per day were pushed through-guillotined through by the Government, if you like-particularly in the lower House. The United Kingdom Parliament sat for twice the number of sitting days that we do. We sat for 84 days; in the United Kingdom the figure was 167. In the United Kingdom only 66 Bills were passed-not 2.19 per day but 0.39 per day. In other words, the British Parliament works in a truly democratic way and allows its members to debate Bills as long as they want to. The situation in the Canadian Parliament is very similar. In 1987 it debated fewer Bills per day than was the case in the United Kingdom. It sat for 167 days and passed 39 Bills, 0.23 Bills per day. The United States of America Congress sat for 170 days and passed 242 Bills or 1.42 Bills per day.

SPEECH.PARA: So it is a lot of rot for Senator Ray to stand up here and say that what is proposed here as a package will overcome the long sitting hours and the late Christmas sittings. All that has to be done is to start earlier in the year, get through the legislation and not let it bank up until Christmas. I have been here a considerable time and I know that each year there is a bit of a bank-up. Unfortunately in the Senate, no matter who is in government, guillotining takes place towards the end of the session. But last year we excelled ourselves. It was a ridiculous state of affairs that we were passing Bills numbered in tens each day.

I do not believe the proposal is a package. I believe it can be divided into two parts. One involves committees and the other Estimates committees. There is no need to look at it as a package in terms of our having to pass the lot or none at all. I do not believe there is any need at all to do away with the rights of senators in the way we have done it, and I am certainly looking at this as a government member after the next election.

But let us have a look at dividing the proposals into two. It has been suggested, as Senator Ray has already said, that a committee be set up to select the Bills that come before the Senate to be sent off to committees and that those committees should be the present standing and general purpose committees. That would certainly alter things considerably. We would no longer be able to have our terms of reference covering matters of general interest to the Senate because much of the time would be taken up inquiring into Bills.

But if we are going down that road-and I think that it has its attractions-I do not see that a new committee should be set up giving the Whips all that added work. I do not understand why we could not give that work to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. It could decide which Bills should be looked at and we could start off in a trial way by not putting up too numerous groups of Bills. We could see whether the Senate would rather stick to its original type of committee work and the terms of reference that it has to date found most interesting.

I would like to try the suggestion that more Bills be referred to committees. But it is ridiculous to suggest that we must consider this as a package, that nothing can be interfered with and that we must cut senators' speaking times to five minutes when we debate whether we should send Bills to that selection committee. No in-depth or sensible debate can possibly take place when a senator is limited to five minutes speaking time. That is one of the things I object to very strongly.

The next objection is in relation to recommendation No. 2 which again limits speaking time to five minutes. A senator who speaks in relation to sending a Bill off to one of those committees or to other motions and amendments again can speak for only five minutes. I object very strongly to limiting senators' debating time in this way.

In relation to proposal No. 3, Senator Ray has answered the question I have written beside that: What sort of arrangements are we going to make to find the additional hours necessary to get through the legislation in the Senate? He suggested a five-day sitting week. That will certainly add to the number of sitting days we have but when you have a look at the number of sitting days that the Australian Parliament sits compared to other parliaments, that may not necessarily be a bad thing.

I do not really understand recommendation No. 4 because at the present time if nobody wants to speak in the second reading debate nobody gets up. We have seen it happen many a time in the Senate chamber that the Minister will incorporate his second reading speech, while the person who is leading for the Opposition on the particular Bill will say, basically, `The Opposition is in agreement', and make a short speech. Nobody else takes part. What on earth is the difference between that and what is suggested? Is it that the Minister does not make a second reading speech but incorporates his second reading speech on every occasion? Is that a prerequisite?

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be no incorporation of second reading speeches at all.
—Senator Hamer fortunately was able to answer that question for me. I gather that the Minister who is putting down that second reading speech would not incorporate his second reading speech.
—As the proposal stands.

—He would deliver that second reading speech. Why is that different from what occurs now? At the moment, if nobody wants to debate a Bill, the Minister incorporates his speech, the shadow Minister says a few words and the Bill goes through very quickly. I see absolutely no difference between what is proposed and what occurs at the moment. I would like someone to explain to me what the big advantage is.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, in recommendation 4 (b), when the motion for the second reading speech of the Bill is put without debate, I gather we go straight to the committee stage. Then when the third reading stage is reached, if something has occurred in the committee stage that one is particularly concerned about, one is still not allowed to debate it fully; one has got only five minutes. Something might occur in the committee stage that has grabbed one's attention. One whips off and does a little research about it. It occurs regularly in this place that in the committee stage something comes up that the Government has really mucked up in its drafting procedures. People have become aware of the problem. Research is done on it, and one is allowed to talk about it in the third reading debate for only five minutes. In a considerably longer debate, a proper and serious speech by each senator would take longer than five minutes. I believe that is a rubbishy recommendation.

Any government would obviously like recommendation No. 5. Senator Ray said that it should be looked at from two perspectives: what is best for the Government and what is best for the Opposition. He elaborated a bit and said that we should wait until after the next election when, both sides of the Senate believing that they are going to be in government or considering how they could be obstructive in opposition, it can be looked at very clearly. There is a third perspective, and that is: What is best for the Parliament; what is best for the Senate? If we interfere with the present Estimates committees, I believe that we will do a great disservice to this Parliament. The Estimates committee system is unique in the way that it carries out its work. It is a most efficient and very good system. Should a senator be on an Estimates committee for a whole day but would like to visit another Estimates committee and ask questions, the only way to do it at present is to stand in the Committee of the Whole and ask questions at that time. This recommendation takes away that right. This recommendation says that the only things that can be debated in the Committee of the Whole are matters referred to in the committee reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or attach- ments.

—Yes, attachments, amendments or whatever. That still does not necessarily cover the concerns that one may have. I would have thought that the chairmen of Estimates committees would be particularly concerned in this area. Senator Colston would know that during past Estimates Committee hearings I have whipped off to another committee, even though I am a member of his Estimates Committee; but, as chairman, he is not able to do that as readily as I am able to. Sometimes it fits in and a member of the Committee can whip off for half an hour and go to another committee and ask questions. That is not always possible because of conflicting interests; but a chairman can never do it. I would have thought that he would have cherished his right in this place, if he has interests in other committees which he is unable to attend, to be able to ask questions of the Minister and be able to follow up those questions in the Senate. According to these recommendations, he certainly could not do that.

SPEECH.PARA: We get down to a five-minute speech again when we look at No. 7. I do not believe that senators can make a point, unless it is a minor point, well or throughly or are able to convince people of the sincerity of their argument in a five-minute speech; it is impossible. Speaking as a senator who, when we were in government, responded to Senator McLaren's calls for quorums, it seemed to me, every five minutes, I believe that a quorum ought to be maintained and that every senator has a right to say that members of this Senate should come into the Senate and have their numbers shown whenever a senator chooses to so call them here.

I am very disappointed in the recommendations of the Committee. I know that the report was well researched and that a lot of time was spent on it. I would be interested in the new idea of the committees looking at more Bills. I think it would be very productive. It would overcome a lot of the traps that some of the drafting presents to both Government and Opposition members. I would like to go down that road but not limit the rights of senators. I do not agree with Senator Ray at all that the method of running the Senate at the moment results in long hours and the late sittings that we have experienced in the past at Christmas. If the business is administered by the Government in a sensible fashion, there is no need for late Christmas sittings.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the War Crimes Bill they couldn't make their own minds up.

—That was a very good example. We spent a long time on war crimes legislation, but the Government would not bring it forward last year. We do have those problems, but that is nothing to do with the way that the Senate is run. I am glad that Senator Ray is not wanting a decision today and is willing to bring this matter back on 25 May. It would be a pity to rush through these very important recommendations with the feeling that we can get up a bit earlier for Christmas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Senate is debating its own procedures there are always concerns expressed by senators, such as those expressed by Senator Walters, that the rights of senators should not be taken away. As a member of the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures, I can say that that was always in the forefront of its deliberations. Indeed, the Committee operated unlike other committees, inasmuch as it was given leave by the Senate to consult with all members as it proceeded through its deliberations, because we knew it would be pointless to go down a track of trying to make recommendations that did not have widespread acceptance. A large number of recommendations came forward, but very few actually made it into the report, simply because there is a great deal of difference, both within and across the political parties, about what ought to happen in regard to procedures in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I would like to say-in fact, I got together the material which appears at page 40 of the report-is with regard to what other comparable legislatures do and the legislation that they deal with. Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States sit on 165 to 170 days, which is almost twice the number of days that this Parliament sits. They sit twice as long as we do. Yet when one looks at the number of Bills, one discovers that we manage to pass about twice the number of Bills that they do. So either we are four times as efficient or something else is different. In interpreting that point about legislation, one should remember a couple of caveats. Senator Walters referred to the United Kingdom as an example. Australia has a particular problem with regard to legislation that is not shared by any of those other three legislatures; that is, our constitutional prohibitions with regard to taxation Bills. Hence, we tend to have a lot more smaller Bills than those other legislatures have. One should also recognise that Canada makes use of portfolio Bills to a greater extent than we do. So there is some deception in those figures. Nevertheless, even taking those two considerations into account we are still putting through a lot more legislation, certainly in a lot less time.

There are a number of ways out of this problem, and it is a problem. I think that those of us who have experienced the end of parliamentary sessions for a number of years believe there has to be a more sensible approach. This Committee was appointed in an endeavour to come up with some ideas as to how it might unclog the log jam. There is one simple method which seems to endear itself to hardly anyone; that is, that we double the number of sitting days. In doubling the number of sitting days we would obviously unclog the log jam. But one has also to acknowledge political realities. In Australia there is a very strong demand on members of the House of Representatives and senators to service their electorates. That means that they need to be in the electorate, not in Canberra, be readily available in their offices or, in the case of senators, travel around their electorates, and appear at different places, speaking to people and finding out what is going on. I for one strongly endorse that idea because that contact with the electorate is a very important element of our democracy, but at the end of the day we cannot be in two places at the same time.

We cannot have the luxury of all members of this chamber speaking as long as they like on any topic they like whenever they like and also be in the electorate. Something has to give. What we were trying to work out in the Select Committee is how we might proceed in a way which met the other political reality. Senator Walters said that there is a third way of looking at the matter, and in fact we did look at it. But the political reality in this place is that government and the major opposition parties play the dominant role in the passage of legislation. That being the case, it is fairly obvious that Government members in this chamber would look somewhat aghast at the suggestion that we send more Bills to a committee. The last thing that any government wants is for its Bills to go off to a committee-not this Government but any government. The Minister will have done all his fine work with his bureaucrats and Government members will have passed the legislation through the party room, because after all they are in government; this is part of their legislative program, which they want to see implemented and not held up. That is a legitimate aspiration of government parties. On the other hand, opposition parties have a democratically appointed role to look carefully at all legislation and to scrutinise government operations.

In attempting to weigh those two things up, governments would not like committee references but oppositions generally would. It is no secret that most of the Bills which are referred to committees from this chamber are sent there because the Opposition parties and the Democrats want them to go there, not because the Government is absolutely delighted and delirious and really wants to get them there. At the end of the day this Government, quite sensibly, generally throws up its hands and ceases to resist once it manages to count the numbers, because there does not seem to be a great deal of point in making a fuss.

They are the realities we have to deal with. The Committee tried to deal with the realities of politics within the chamber and the realities of politics outside the chamber. Once we take all those realities into account the room to move is very small. Senator Walters made some fun of one of the recommendations and said it was a shoddy suggestion. The one she referred to reflects the very small amount of room that that Committee had to move in. We were attempting to take a small step. From the point of view of the Australian Democrats the first recommendations of the Committee-that is, 1 (a), (b), (c), (d) and (e)-are not advantageous. We have seven members in the Senate and it is proposed that the committees meet on one day. It is fairly obvious that we are able to cover the sittings in this place because it is one focal point. It would be a far more difficult task to cover all the committees discussing different Bills in various committee rooms of this Parliament House. Nevertheless, our Party's point of view and our Party policy is to try to develop greater scrutiny powers on the part of the Parliament, and this is one way in which it might be able to be done. The reason Senator Robert Ray talked about this proposal as a package is that certain elements do not have anything to offer certain political viewpoints-only disadvantages. The idea is to try to pick up at least something on the swings that we are going to lose on the roundabout. I express, on my Party's behalf, the view that those first recommendations would make our task a lot more difficult.

Senator Walters asked why recommendation 1 (c) did not refer to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. This recommendation is included because it was proposed in the motion that Senator Chaney moved in this place on behalf of the Opposition parties with a view to making use of that Committee's ability to deal with references. It seemed to us to be a very sensible suggestion. It was picked up from that particular quarter. Senator Chaney's suggestion was modified to reflect the numbers in this place. We believe it will have the added advantage of representing what is likely to occur here. There is a third advantage in that the committee meets every day. Its members are a group of people who are well versed in terms of what is going on, how the Bills are progressing through the place and where the particular pressure points are likely to come from. They form a group with a unique set of qualifications in that they are already very much in tune with the flow of legislation and the likely pressure points. Since they meet every day it was felt that in terms of giving some trial to the recommendations before us an additional meeting would not be required, that it would be part of the committee's general overview that takes place each morning.

There are a number of other recommendations. The recommendation with regard to Estimates committees illustrates how Bills referred to a committee can start to move in a rather odd direction. The Estimates committees do an excellent job. When one reads their reports one realises that they often uncover things that the Committee of the Whole probably would not have managed. But there are some quite considerable costs in the way that we then duplicate that exercise in the chamber. I believe that the Estimates committees ought to be similar to other types of committees. We ought to be inquiring into the Estimates committees reports. These committees have been delegated the task on behalf of this chamber to inquire in detail into a whole range of matters. A very large number of bureaucrats are available to come before these committees. Very large costs are incurred in this respect. If we seek to duplicate that process in this chamber I believe we have to do it with good reason because there are significant costs built into the exercise. I am not at all sure that duplicating those exercises is really the best use of our time. I hope that the detailed scrutiny of a piece of legislation will take place in the Estimates committees, and matters not raised at a particular sitting would have to be taken up at subsequent Estimates hearings, which of course occur twice a year. So those opportunities would not be lost, merely deferred.

We can say, `No, we are not going to do that', and we can say no to all of these recommendations. Those people who wish to say no have to declare themselves at least in favour of increasing the number of sitting days. I do not really believe that we can continue the way we are going. It is probably all right for people in opposition because at least in that situation they can always blame the Government. In part it has been the Government's fault. It has not been able to give us a legislative timetable at the end of each session. But the Government is not the only player on the field. Indeed, the Government can legitimately say that it does not have the numbers in the Senate. So how can it carry all the blame for the problems in the legislative program? The numbers in this place are outside the Government's control, and hence the chamber has to accept responsibility for the problems that occur at the end of the session. I believe that what occurs at the end of the session brings only disgrace upon this chamber.

We have to devise better methods. I invite honourable senators who are opposed to these propositions to make suggestions between now and May, when we debate this again. We need to find some way of handling this matter. I have put up a range of suggestions which have not been accepted. This is another range of suggestions. Senator Hamer and quite a number of other honourable senators have also put up a range of suggestions but they have not been accepted. They have all been attempts to come to grips with getting a reasonable flow of legislation through the chamber in a way that does not prevent senators from expressing their views, having those views recorded, having an argument take place or having detailed scrutiny of legislation, as this chamber wants.

I offer a couple of suggestions. One, which will probably upset a lot of people, is to delete the second reading stage on the grounds that it is a more political stage. All the Bills that come from the House of Representatives have been debated, at least by all political parties in the Parliament except our own-and that will be rectified after the next election, when Senator Haines will be able to contribute to debate in the House of Representatives. Those Bills have been debated in a political way in the House of Representatives. Our forte, I think, ought to be increasing scrutiny of the detail of legislation. Therefore, I would like to delete the second reading stage, and all the time saved there could be devoted to the committee stage of Bills, thus allowing more scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not know whether there will be a committee stage.
—Every Bill has its committee stage under these recom- mendations.
—For the whole of the Senate?
—Yes, the whole of the Senate.
—How?

—Under these recommendations there would be no change to the committee stage. The proposal I am putting forward would provide more time. We would not have the second reading stage. All sorts of other proposals are floated around from time to time to try to come to grips with the problem we face. But at the end of the day we have to decide on something. These were the suggestions that seemed to have reasonable support across the board. They were not supported as a whole by everybody; nor were they supported individually by everybody. I am not sure whether even one will be passed. If no suggestion is supported by this chamber, if we cannot come up with a sensible way of doing this, then we stand condemned. What I mean by a sensible way is one that is acceptable not only to oneself but also to people in other political parties and in other positions in the Senate. That is finally what we have to come to grips with.

SPEECH.PARA: If people who wish to speak in this debate do not like these recommendations, that is their prerogative. Let them say where the problems are, what is likely to occur and so on. But I hope they reserve a little of their time to give us some positive suggestions, because I am sure that those members of the Committee who sat down and racked their brains on this would dearly like to hear some other positive suggestions as to how we deal with that time. If there is no other structural way, then I suggest those people commit themselves to the inevitable proposition, which I am happy with-and on behalf of my Party I have acknowledged in the past that we are happy with it-to increase the number of days that this chamber sits. I think at the end of the day that has to be it. Unfortunately, we have not been able to secure agreement across the board on that, so that has been ruled out. But we have to go somewhere and we have to deal with the problem, so I hope that those people who do not like these recommendations-and I can understand why, because they do curtail various avenues that are currently available to senators-come up with other suggestions.

My Party in particular has a certain amount of difficulty with this set of proposals-and I am sure that the Independents in this place would find difficulty with them-because our small numbers cover a large number of points. Smaller parties and groups in this place have legitimate concerns, but we are willing to give the proposals a try. We believe these should become Sessional Orders and should be tried out and then there should be a review to see how they have gone and what difficulties have occurred. I hope that after such a review people will be generous enough to try to correct any problems that may occur. At least that is the type of response the Committee was getting from members of all political parties. It is less a party problem and more a Senate problem, and I think it should be dealt with in that fashion.

There are some other recommendations in the report. For example, one way of dealing with the counting procedures in this place is to allow the Whips or other people to record the names of senators as being in support of or against a proposition without calling a division. I hope that honourable senators will look at that. That is another option available to us.
