Another suggestion is that Bills normally be referred to the legislative and general purpose standing committees rather than to special committees of the Senate so that those general purpose committees can hopefully develop an expertise in this area. Along with that suggestion is a suggestion that we ought to look at the Chair of those committees as being another avenue for expertise development in this chamber. In other words, someone may wish to devote a considerable amount of his or her available legislative time to chairing a particular committee and becoming an expert in a particular area, say, tax, defence or whatever else.

I believe that the proposals that the Committee put forward would allow more Bills to go before a committee. I think they would allow committees more time to consider legislation. The time saved in the Senate could then be allocated elsewhere, because we are certainly not going to sit for fewer days. In other words, there would be a freeing up of time for other matters. I think that would allow for maximum flexibility. One must remember that the ultimate decision would always be in the hands of the Senate. That is why our recommendations preserve the rights of individual senators either to have a Bill debated or be able to seek to have a Bill referred to a committee, even when this has not been accepted by other groups of senators. That was done specifically to preserve the rights of Independents who would not be represented on the Selection of Bills Committee or of many members of political parties who dissent from their parties' stance on a particular Bill and whose rights need to be protected in that regard.

This was an attempt to meet those concerns. It was not an attempt to steamroll anybody, or to trample on the rights of senators. I hope that honourable senators will approach these recommendations in that light. It was an attempt to deal with a problem that we all face. If these recommendations are not acceptable, I hope that some other practical suggestions will come forward in the time available to us so that we are not faced at the end of this session and at the end of the year with a situation which only brings disgrace upon this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that the Senate Select Committee on Legislation Procedures did not deliberately attempt to undermine the rights of individual senators. I acknowledge that the work that was done by Senator Colston and his Committee has been quite considerable, onerous and painstaking. But at the end of the day its proposals will impinge upon both the legislative function and the representative function of individual senators in this place. I believe it is inappropriate for the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) to have moved a motion in this form. I think it is unfair of him to have suggested that the Senate today should endorse in principle the matters contained in this report. I have had this report for about three-quarters of an hour. It is not possible to give the required consideration in order to come to a firm view as to whether we should support it in principle at this stage. I appeal to the Minister and to the Senate to adjourn this debate until a later stage.
—The report was brought down on 1 December last year. It was presented in this chamber.

—This is the first time that I have seen it. It concerns me that the motion has been moved in its present form. I have had a brief look at the report. I am convinced that, on the face of it, the report will impinge upon the legislative and representative functions of individual senators. It will particularly affect the individual Independent senators-more so than it will affect members of parties. I will give an example relating to the appropriation Bills. Recommendation 5 states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . debate on appropriation bills in the committee of the whole be confined to matters referred to in Estimates Committee reports for further examination.

That is an unjustifiable restriction on the right of individual senators to have their say in the Committee of the Whole to question Ministers publicly in the Committee in areas relating to their portfolios, relating to Budget matters. Not many more important matters are considered by this chamber than the expenditure of taxpayers' money, yet it is proposed that we limit consideration in the Committee of the Whole to what might be contained in Estimates committee reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is nothing sometimes.
—Senator Walters says, `Which is nothing'. Let me ask you-I do not know whether the Estimates Committee--
—Senator Harradine should direct his remarks through the Chair.

—Let me ask you about this, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am not sure whether it was a fact, but Estimates Committee E dealt with Aboriginal Affairs. I have a feeling that the Committee made some reference to Aboriginal affairs, but had it not done so, under this proposal the Senate would have been unable to undertake the further examination of that matter in the Committee of the Whole. Admittedly, it might be said that a considerable number of questions were asked about this portfolio during the Estimates committee hearings. But a number of us were not present at the Estimates committee hearings and were not aware of it until we either read the Estimates Committee Hansard or considered the matter here.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of questions to be asked as to our legislative function. That is a truly legislative function that will be denied to individual senators. I think that suggestion in recommendation 5 is totally unfair and ought to be rejected outright. I took the opportunity which was afforded to me by the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Colston, to respond to him in writing in September last year. I indicated in that letter that during the 13 years in which I have been a senator I have been alert to the need to ensure that parliamentary procedures operate to the advantage and not to the disadvantage of individual senators, be they Independents or individual senators of the various political parties. That should be the test against which any amendments to the Standing Orders are applied. I am aware, of course, that some senators are obliged to play a designated role within the party team and often quite reluctantly see their responsibilities as being more within a party context than within the context of the Senate's legislative procedures.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a problem that you have.

—No, it is not, but it is a problem that some people in the various parties have. They are told to join a committee or specialise in certain matters. What opportunity do they have to express the views of their constituents in respect of some other matters? That is what I am getting at, particularly in respect of recommendation 5. The safeguarding and advancement of the role of individual senators, be they members of political parties or not, forms the basis of my consideration of these proposals. I feel that they are found wanting on that basis. When I considered the draft proposals late last year I thought that it was of some merit to relay experiences of the Senate Estimates committees since their establishment in 1970. I have endeavoured, as honourable senators will know, to participate in the functions of the Estimates committees to the best of my ability. It appears to me that the theory of a filtering system, which is implicit in the proposals that are currently before the Senate, bears some resemblance to the unstated premise on which the Estimates committee system has been based.

SPEECH.PARA: As an individual senator I have found it impossible to keep tabs on what is happening within each of the Estimates committees' policy areas in which I am interested and in which my electors are interested. I endeavoured to do this in my earlier years here, but it is the practice for several committees to meet simultaneously-in fact, three committees meet simultaneously nowadays-and I find it logistically impossible to sit with one committee and follow its progress, then leave that committee and sit with another, and perhaps have someone else keep an eye on the progress of the remaining committee. Nor am I sure that the permanent members of those committees always welcome my coming and going. Honourable senators may well laugh, but it is disconcerting when chairmen give one a look as though one is an interloper. Certainly that is not the case with Senator Colston. I am not looking at him at all. He has protected my rights, and the rights of every other individual senator, to ask questions of the various departments.

Looked at from the point of view of an individual senator with diverse interests, the operation of the Senate's Estimates committee system has carried with it the associated disadvantage of forcing me to specialise and to choose between those areas of top priority. This is what I have had to do in recent years. I am not a one-issue person. I was not elected on a one-issue basis. I am a multi-issue person. I attempt to cover many issues. With diverse interests I have great difficulty. The one saving factor about the Estimates committee system is that the Committee of the Whole remains an opportunity for referring to areas of departmental estimates in detail, regardless of whether the same area has been examined by the relevant Estimates committee.

In recent years I have discerned an underlying feeling of impatience with anyone who branches out into great detail in the chamber debate. I have not been one to do that. I have done it on occasion, but I have not made a welter of it. However, in essence this means that the focus of the proceedings of the Senate has been transferred from the chamber to the six Estimates committee meetings, meeting in committee rooms, and in the process the focus has been diffused. I ask the Senate to consider these questions. The focus has become diffused, and I think that is what is going to happen if we have this system that is proposed for Bills to go off to committees on Wednesdays. Individual senators will not have the opportunity that they now have to contribute to the debate when it counts. One might say that there is a committee stage when the report comes back, but is the Senate going to tell me that, once decisions on that Bill have been made in that committee, people will change their minds? Of course they will not. The committee stage will be a rubber stamp of what the committee has done. Honourable senators will get quite impatient when somebody who has not been on the committee comes into this chamber to put forward a bright idea about the Bill and has an amendment to put forward. What chance will that amendment have of getting the support of the Senate? Honourable senators will not be here to listen to the debate. They will think, `We've gone through all the pros and cons of that Bill in the committee hearing'. That is a travesty. I feel very offended, as an individual senator, by the recommendations that have come forward on this matter. I do not believe that the basis for these recommendations holds any water at all; that is to say, the volume of legislation. That argument, advanced in support of the recommendations confronting the Senate does not hold up if one really examines it.

The first point to make on that issue is that governments of all complexions have been guilty of forcing the Senate to consider a rush of legislation towards the end of sessions. This has contributed to the perception of an avalanche of legislation that is beyond the resources of the Senate as presently constituted to deal with. It is only a perception. I have been amongst those who have repeatedly suggested in the Senate that these problems are generally of the Government's own creation and that they could have been ameliorated by better programming. My impression is that this situation has improved in recent years and that the message has been conveyed back to the departments via the programming officers. That message is simply that timely notice should be given of all legislative proposals. I understand that under the present system Ministers must make advance bids to a committee of Cabinet for a place for legislation which they hope to introduce in the next session and that, if they cannot establish some kind of priority, the legislation is not endorsed.

I am concerned that, if the Senate signals to the bureaucracy and to Cabinet that new machinery has been established to facilitate the examination of greater volumes of legislation, elements of the bureaucracy will move to increase the flow of legislation. One virtue of the limited quota of time available under the present system is that departmental officials must constantly ask themselves whether what they propose is of major importance or could be left for the next amending Bill. I see that as an intangible self-regulating mechanism that is worth reserving.

To test the excuse, if I might use that word, behind these proposals-increased volume and complexity of legislation-one analysis which I requested examined all the legislation considered by the Senate in 1987 and categorised only 22 per cent of that year's Bills as being of major importance. I think the Senate ought to consider that. I am of course aware that the criteria for such categorisation contains a strong element of subjectivity. It should be pointed out that in purely numerical terms the Senate considered fewer Bills-that is to say, 222-in 1987 than it did in 1985, when it considered 273. But I am aware that such a comparison can be deceptive. Nevertheless, on the basis of the 1987 figures only 22 per cent of the Bills were in the category of being of major importance.

I come next to a very important matter which no doubt the Committee has considered, namely, the implications of this system for extrinsic aids to the interpretation of the law. I do not know whether it is proposed to have a Hansard report of these committee meetings or whether it is proposed that individual Ministers be present at the meetings.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be put at the discretion of the committee. There certainly would be Hansard. Whether the Minister would be present would be at the discretion of the committee.

—From memory-and Senator Durack will correct me if I am wrong-I understand that, under the Acts Interpretation Act, statements by Ministers to the chamber at the committee stage may be taken as extrinsic aids to the interpretation of the law. It seems to me that since the passage of the Acts Interpretation Act in 1984 the proceedings in the Senate chamber itself have assumed a particular position for the purposes of judicial interpretation. If the focus of legislative examination is shifted from the chamber to a collection of committees, will the proceedings of those committees, as distinct from the proceedings in this chamber, be taken into consideration for the purposes of interpretation of the law?
—They have not thought that through.

—I am sure that the Committee has given consideration to that. I would be interested to hear the response. If, for example, there is no Minister present at those committee meetings, it would be somewhat difficult for a judge to determine whether or not the intention of the drafters or the proponents of the legislation-namely, the Government-was clear. If the proceedings of the committees are to be taken into consideration by the courts, what action can be taken by an individual senator who might wish to challenge an interpretation which has been read onto the record in his absence within a particular committee?

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to say much more. However, I point out that there are two sides to a compromise. The allure of legislation committees is exemplified by the following quotation from the 1976 report of the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Committee System entitled A New Parliamentary Committee System. I quote from page 128:

46. It is highly likely that more amendments would be acceptable to governments if committee deliberation was less formal and more flexible. In legislation committees the government would not appear to lose face in accepting amendments to its legislation. The closer quarters and less theatrical circumstances should facilitate discussion and compromise.

That is what that Committee said in 1976. I can understand and appreciate the theory which runs through that statement. Disregarding the comment about `theatrical circumstances', which surely must not apply to the Senate, I am not convinced that the act of compromise should be hidden away in the less than public proceedings of a committee. That is a very important point. What will inevitably occur in these committees as people get to know one another is trade-offs. Deals will be done between committee members. A member will say, `I will trade this off in considering this Bill and you trade that one off in relation to the next Bill'. All of this will be done away from the gaze of the public. Members of the public may be present at these committee meetings.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no reason why they should not be.

—That is right. However, members of the public also do not have the gift of bilocation. They cannot cut themselves up into six parts and attend six committee meetings simultaneously. There is nothing intrinsically wrong with political compromise, but surely it is desirable that as much of the legislative process as possible should take place in the open forum of the Senate chamber where its elements can be considered and evaluated. I have some sympathy for the view expressed by Mr E. J. Lindsay, MHR, in his dissent from a recommendation favouring legislation committees for the House of Representatives. At page 59 of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure, second report, May 1986, PP. No. 108/1986, Mr Lindsay states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the constitutional duty of the House by itself, or as a committee of the whole, to undertake the deliberative legislative processes for the passage of a bill. The recommendation of the Procedure Committee would remove part of the integrity of that process from the House.

I believe that the recommendation of the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures that we now have before us will remove part of the integrity of the processes of this chamber and thus should be seriously questioned and, I believe, not accepted. When the report to which I have just referred was debated in the House of Representatives, Mr Lindsay made the further point that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure had failed to adduce any evidence in support of its recommendation for the reintroduction of legislation committees. This absence of any strong evidence in the report in support of legislation committees perhaps explains why the Government finally rejected that recommendation.

I believe that there is a fundamental concern about the whole proposal being considered. It revolves around the threat that it poses to the ability of individual senators, whether they be party senators or not, to understand what they are voting for or against and to exercise their vote in a responsible manner. I fear that, in transferring the focus from the chamber to a number of committees, senators will be asked to accept a great deal more on trust and that a substantial part of the legislative process will take place away from adequate public scrutiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that, unbeknown to me, an arrangement has been made that we are to complete this debate by a quarter to six. By necessity, of course, my contribution will have to be short. I know that Senator Hamer wishes to make some comments, particularly in light of the contribution that he has made to the proposals that are presently before us.
—Why a quarter to six?

—Because an arrangement has been made to which Senator Walters and I were not privy. Let me quickly go through the matters that are of fundamental concern to me. Without question, the present intrinsic role of the chamber will significantly change. The proposals, quite deliberately, will change the committee system. The committees will develop significantly more responsibility. They will take on responsibilities in areas that they have thus far not taken. It ought not be forgotten-I think it was Senator Robert Ray who touched upon the point-that it will very much change the role of the present standing committee system. My judgment is that the standing committees no longer will be able to pursue their areas of current interest and central responsibility when looking at social issues such as drugs in sport or matters relating to pornography, the environment or whatever. Terms of reference which do not automatically flow from legislation no longer will be able to be dealt with because the committees simply will not have time. I have grave concern that the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and other joint committees that have recently been formed under new procedures no longer will be able to address issues other than those flowing from legislation. In my view that is detrimental to the system of the Parliament and to the functioning of the committee system. It will deny the community access to invaluable information and work and substantial recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of long and late sittings was raised by Senator Ray. By and large, the problems that confront the chamber in respect to late sittings invariably and inevitably flow from the Government's incompetence or bad management of its legislative program.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. Nonsense.
—I see Senator Tate nodding over there in approval.
—I am not nodding in approval.

—I am sorry. I imagined for a moment that Senator Tate was acknowledging the inevitable. We only have to look at the war crimes legislation that Senator Walters touched upon. A long, detailed debate took place in the committee stage.
—An excellent debate.
—Yes, it was an excellent, high quality debate.
—Particularly Senator Hamer's contribution.

—Senator Hamer's contribution was notable, as were many on this side. The reason the legislation came before us late was that the Government could not arrange, amongst its own warring factions, its business. It could not extricate itself from the problem it had got itself into with various groups in the community. It was bowing, scraping and bending and, in the end, wimpering, trying to find a way to get the legislation approved and carried unanimously so that everybody, not just the Government, would carry responsibility for it. That is a typical example of why we find ourselves sitting late in December each year. It has nothing to do with the normal efficiency and functioning of the chamber and its intrinsic responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also concerned about the type of Bills that are likely to be examined. It is suggested that we might have to deal with Bills of no account. I wonder whether there are those who will be pushing for legislation of a detailed, complex and controversial nature to be examined by these committees. Such activities inevitably will detract from the contribution of all senators in the chamber. What Senator Harradine said is ever so true. Once a committee brings in its report, if it is carried unanimously, one will be like an interloper if one wants to stand up and take a different view, to seek to argue it again, to seek to saw sawdust, to repeat that which has already been done in the confines of a committee. To that extent the chamber will be denied the healthy debate which ought to take place at a second reading stage.

I will touch quickly on the other matters. First, there is the question of quorums. It was inevitable that this Government would seek to reduce the number required for a quorum from one-third to one-quarter. Part of the Government's argument relates to the size of the building. The truth is that the time to get to the chamber has been extended. I do not see the logic of simply seeking to reduce the aggregate numbers because the building is larger. It sounds like Mr Keating's arithmetic to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't come in for quorums, do you?

—I do not have to come in for quorums. One of the few responsibilities of government, on Senator McKiernan's side, is to maintain the chamber. If those opposite cannot maintain the chamber it ought to close down. They ought to be seen as incompetent and failing in their conduct and responsibility. Madam Acting Deputy President, you are not unaware that one of the clubs that the Opposition has over the Government is the use of quorums. It is one source of discipline to ensure that those opposite conduct themselves with propriety and show respect for the chamber and the functioning of the Parliament. If that is removed, they will further abrogate their responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: They have gone another step down the road in their dress sense. We only have to look at how those opposite drag themselves in here-their motley, half-undressed attire, their conduct and the language that has become the norm and the standard. It is now almost fixed into the Standing Orders. This is just another step in reducing the standing of the chamber. I am not saying that of all senators but there are some notable characters on the Government's side. Finally, because I promised to be short, I just say--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you seen anybody in here with his shoes off?
—I certainly have.
—Was that an Opposition or a Government senator?
—Senator Walsh was in here with his shoes off, his feet up on the desk and singing Irish songs.
—What time of the day was it?

—I do not know what time it was. Does it make any difference to Senator Walsh what time of the day it was? Senator Reid raised with me privately the proposition that at the end of the day there is some virtue in having a sunset clause in the amendments to the Standing Orders. We have had this proposal put to us as a package. I love the way the Government seeks consensus and presents a package. One is never allowed to disagree. One has to agree-and agree in total. So if this system fails or collapses, as it inevitably will, at least we can return to the system we have at present which does not function as it should because of the Government's failings in arranging its legislative program and its failure to arrange its affairs in an orderly fashion so that we can all be much more effective than we are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) moved earlier a three part motion that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, probably have before you and honourable senators opposite have before them.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators-No, we have not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the motion reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) That the Senate take note of the report of the Select Committee on Legislative Procedures;
(b) That the Senate supports in principle the recommendations contained in the report; and
(c) That, unless otherwise ordered, consideration of recommendations be a Business of the Senate Order of the Day for 25 May 1989.

I have been asked by the Manager of Government Business to indicate a withdrawal of the second part of that motion; that is, that the Senate supports, in principle, the recommendations contained in the report. Honourable senators are simply being asked to take note of the report and, unless otherwise ordered, consideration of its recommendations will be a business of the Senate Order of the Day for 25 May 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we have a copy so that we can see what is proposed?

—It is quite easy to understand. What we now have before us is that the Senate take note of the report of the Senate Select Committee and that consideration of the recommendations be a Business of the Senate Order of the Day for 25 May 1989.
—Is leave granted for that amendment?

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. We do not have any paper in front of us. I understand Senator Tate. Why is this request that the Senate not accept the recommendations in principle now being made? Why is it now not part of the motion that the Senate accept the recommendations in principle? Why has the Government withdrawn that part of the motion? I would be most interested to know.

—As I understand it, the Manager of Government Business in the Senate simply wants the Senate not to get into such controversy that this matter generates ill will, which might jeopardise further consideration of the report of the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures on 25 May 1989. It is therefore suggested that we leave out the paragraph relating to supporting the recommendations in principle and that we simply note the report today and look forward to a full debate on 25 May 1989.
—While you are on your feet, can you tell me whether we are to have a full debate for an hour or hours or whatever?

—This matter ought to be given full consideration in the chamber. Obviously, senators will want to insist on the fullest consideration and deliberation. We are simply saying that that ought to take place on 25 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say on behalf of the coalition that a number of honourable senators here in the chamber at the present moment have indicated a desire to speak. Senator Crichton-Browne is clearly only part way through his words in relation to this matter. Senator Durack intends to speak, and clearly we would be interested to hear Senator Hamer, one of the authors of the paper, express his views on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not oppose the Government's proposal to defer debate on this matter to 25 May, but we will want to have a full debate on the subject because we believe that the procedures in this Parliament are a matter of great importance. So, as I understand from what Senator Tate has said and from the head nodding of both of the Government's Whips that there will be a full debate on 25 May, the Opposition will not oppose this proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it acceptable that I speak to the chamber for just a couple of minutes on this matter? I know I have the call, but I am trying to be amiable about what I am doing.
—There is a motion to defer debate, to which motion you may speak.

—No, he is not deferring the debate; he is merely amending the original motion, which was that the debate ultimately be adjourned, and in due course we will vote on that. Presumably we will support it, but in the meantime the debate continues, as I understand the situation. Am I not correct in that, Madam Acting Deputy President?
—Yes.

—Then I would like to speak on this matter very briefly. I think there were a couple of misunderstandings, partly caused by the way in which the matter was introduced by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray). I do not believe that these recommendations are a single package. They should be viewed in their own right and in their own light. It the Senate passes the package, well and good. But there are problems, and Senator Harradine has pointed out one of them; that is, the fact that the position of Independent senators in this chamber is very difficult to protect. I tell Senator Harradine that we on the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures did try to protect the position of Independents, but it is difficult in the light of the type of recommendations being made. It is up to the Senate to consider that and whether the difficulties of Independent senators should take precedence, in which case the proposals should be rejected. I am sure that when the particular motions come before the Senate Senator Harradine will speak eloquently on that subject.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three separate issues in this report. The first is one I feel very strongly about, and that is that this Senate should devote more of its time to detailed consideration of legislation, with expert witnesses being able to give critiques and suggestions on legislation. The House of Representatives, as presently constituted, cannot perform that legislative role. It is very important that it be performed, and the Senate is the only body that can. I think we should make full use of our committee system to ensure much more detailed consideration of legislation. By the way, sometimes it is not the controversial legislation that has the hidden catch in it; it is the legislation that everyone agrees with that we look at too little. We should have a procedure whereby we give detailed consideration, in committee and in the Senate's legislative and general purpose committees, to these matters. That should not preclude subsequent proper debate in the Committee of the Whole. In my experience, Bills that have been referred to committees for report have frequently occasioned very spirited debate in the Committee of the Whole when the committee report has come back to the chamber. That is the first issue.

But if we wish to do that, we have to devote time to it. The Committee's recommendation is that Wednesdays should be set aside for that purpose. If we are to set aside Wednesdays, there are only two options: either the Senate will have to sit longer to deal with the rest of its business or we will have to make savings in our proceedings elsewhere so that the Senate does not have to sit longer. That is not a popular answer, I have found by discussing this matter with various honourable senators. We have commitments back in our electorates. We are expected by our electors, and in our system they are very strong.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have preselection battles too.

—I am not referring to preselection battles. They are very easy ones. I am talking about the more general ones of collecting and representing views from the electorate. I read an autobiography of an English member of parliament. When he was a young man he was elected as a candidate for the Conservative Party for a place he had never ever set foot in before. It was up in the north of England, and he came from London. He asked his electorate chairman, `Would I be required to live in the electorate?'. The electorate chairman said, `Good God, no. You are a young man; you want to sow some wild oats. You must do that sort of thing in London. It would never do in Preston'. He said, `Well, in that case, how often should I visit Preston?'. His electorate chairman said, `Once a month. If you visit more often you will cease to be news; if you visit less often they will think you are neglecting them. Once a month will do'.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we all know that that would not work in this country. The people for whom it would not work, though, are primarily our own party members-but it just would not work. We just have to, we are expected to and we are committed to spend more time in our electorates than members of other legislatures such as the United States Congress and the British House of Commons. If we can spend more time sitting, well and good. I think we should spend a little more time, but not a great deal more. And the purpose of the recommendations in the second group was to make suggestions on how we might save time. We are aware that these proposals would take away from senators things they have been able to do in the past. We are aware that they could create problems for such people as Independent senators who did not have the multiple numbers in order to keep an eye on a number of things simultaneously. The recommendations are put forward in good faith. If they are not acceptable to the Senate, they can be beaten. That is up to the Senate as a whole.

The third group, recommendations 7 and 8, is really much involved with time saving. Those recommendations were put forward because they were previous recommendations from the Standing Orders Committee-now the Procedure Committee-and it was thought appropriate that they be dealt with in this group. They are the one to limit the time spent on motions to suspend Standing Orders and the one to reduce the quorum. The quorum change would have very little effect on the time of the Senate. It would allow, as the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) said, more administrative time for Ministers. The one on the suspension of Standing Orders is one which I know worries many honourable senators on this side of the chamber. Of course, if the suspension of Standing Orders is agreed to, there is no debate at all. We often suspend Standing Orders on the voices. The only occasion on which there is this debate is when the Opposition, normally, or perhaps another party, wishes to make a fuss, a noise, about some issue which the Government is chopping off. That is the reason for that particular proposal that that sort of activity should be limited to half an hour. Again, that is an infringement, a reduction, of the present rights of senators. The Senate would have to give consideration to the balance between the time spent on these activities and the time available for others. It is all about how much time we are prepared to spend in this place and how we should allocate that time.

I emphasise that the recommendations are in three quite separate groups: one to improve our scrutiny of legislation; the second to save some time by changing procedures to allow for that without increasing the length of time the Senate sits; and the final one, the two procedural recommendations, which did not really originate from the Committee but were on the books of the Senate for some time and which the Committee thought should be debated and decided upon by the Senate in conjunction with the others. I emphasise that it is not a package; it is three quite separate groups of proposals. I commend the first proposal very strongly to the Senate. In relation to the other ones the Senate has to make up its own mind as to how it wishes to conduct its procedures.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats indicated during the second reading stage of the debate on this legislation that we certainly support Government amendments that will prevent foreign investors from buying Australian residential real estate without Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) authority and approval, and will be doing this because we believe it is a long overdue move and a very necessary measure for a variety of reasons, not the least of which is to reserve the capacity of Australian residents to buy their own real estate. Having said that with regard to residential real estate, we will not be supporting the Government's moves with regard to thresholds on foreign investment in business or in the area of rural real estate. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Pages 8 to 11, clause 14, proposed sections 13a and 13b, line 33 (page 8) to line 4 (page 11), leave out the proposed sections.

The Australian Democrats will be opposing the thresholds on the grounds that the measure does not go far enough. The measure has established thresholds of $5m for purchases by foreign investors of urban businesses and $3m for purchases of rural land. We believe that those thresholds are far too high and, indeed, that there should be no threshold of this kind set. Anybody who wishes to buy Australian rural property should be required to get the approval of the FIRB. We believe that that body, inasmuch as it still exists and inasmuch as it has the resources to cope-and that is a matter the Government needs to reconsider as well-ought to be in a position to scrutinise all foreign investment proposals.

In a moment we will be moving a connected amendment for the establishment of a register of foreign ownership in this country not just for rural land or for residential real estate which has already been purchased by overseas investors but for general investment across the board in business. When we have thresholds of this kind we are leaving a massive loophole for people to get through. Adjoining properties can be bought by associated companies, nominees or companies which intend to cooperate in some way or another to avoid meeting the limits.

The Australian public, concerned as it is about the level of foreign investment, has a right to believe that somebody is investigating, scrutinising, all purchases of business interests and of real estate, whether it is rural or urban, in this country. The value of foreign investment in Australia has increased dramatically in the last few years, almost doubling in the years from 1985-86 to 1987-88, going from a little under $10 billion three years ago to over $18 billion in 1986-87 and then to $25 billion in 1987-88. If we exclude purchases of up to $5m and $3m with regard to business and rural real estate respectively then we are going to have no comparable figures by which to judge the increasing purchases of businesses and real estate in this country.

Unfortunately this has been another example of the Government acting by way of legislation by press release because purchases of rural property worth less than $3m and businesses worth less than $5m have been exempt from the requirement for Foreign Investment Review Board approval since April 1987. When the Mr Keating announced these changes he forecast that they would reduce FIRB applications from 1,300 to 400. It is rather extraordinary that we have a government which reduces the resources, staffing and capacity of the Foreign Investment Review Board and then turns around and says, `Because the Board is not able to cope with the workload, we are going to impose some sort of ceiling so that its workload is reduced to meet the capacity of the reduced resources'. That sort of thing is Alice in Wonderland stuff and I do not think it is justifiable in any circumstances at all.

What is worse is that, in that reduction from 1,300 to 400, if the 900 transactions excluded by those categories were worth an average $2m each, something like $1.8 billion worth of foreign real estate purchases would not even have been recorded, much less scrutinised by the Foreign Investment Review Board. I do not believe-and neither do my colleagues-that any threshold should apply with regard to foreign investment, given the ease with which these can be circumvented the total amounts of money property and involved. I am not aware of too many other countries in the world which make it as easy as Australia for foreigners and non-residents to buy up businesses and real estate, whether urban or rural real estate. I think it is quite shameful that we as a country are not only busily selling off as much of the farm as we possibly can-and various other bits of Australia as well-but also leaving so much of this unscrutinised by government instrumentalities whose major purpose, I would have thought, would be to keep a weather eye on who owns what, and to what extent, in this country.

I think it is very sad indeed that if, after the next election, the Opposition parties were to get into power the Foreign Investment Review Board would be abolished altogether. According to some statements by Mr Peacock and Mr Howard, the Board is not considered a necessary authority to have because they say they would maintain a capacity in Treasury to monitor foreign investment. I want to know how we could monitor what we do not even know about. It is a little tough to expect Treasury, with everything else it is doing, to take on board an activity that ought to be the province of a specific authority such as the Foreign Investment Review Board.

This means that it is even more important that we have something like a national register of foreign ownership in this country so that not only can Treasury monitor these sorts of situations-or the Foreign Investment Review Board for as long as it is allowed to continue to exist-but so can members of parliament and, just as importantly, so can members of the public. Whilst we are denied information of this sort we really are, in this chamber and out in the community, paddling around in the dark a bit. We get some information with regard to who owns what, but it is often left to other organisations to track these figures down.

Records kept by the Cattle Council of Australia, for example-presumably accurate records-tell us that Japanese companies with majority and minority interests in abattoirs and feedlots in Australia are quite extensive. Nippon-Ham has 100 per cent ownership of the Oakey abattoir in Queensland. The company also owns its own feedlot at Whyalla and has said that it plans to increase slaughter capacity to 120,000 a year. Mitsubishi and Hannan Chikusan own 95 per cent of the Forbes abattoir in New South Wales and aim to process 75,000 head of cattle per year. Mitsubishi and Hannan in partnership also have a majority interest in the Macksville abattoir on the New South Wales central coast. It is aiming to process 125,000 head per year. In addition, Mitsubishi has bought the Killars and Quirindi feedlot operations to supply the Macksville plant. Itoman has a 50 per cent interest in Hawkridge Meat Co. Pty Ltd abattoirs near Burnie and Devonport in Tasmania. The company also has a 40 per cent stake in Gilbertson's chain of abattoirs around Australia. It is pretty grim that we have to rely on records kept, however well kept those records may be, by organisations such as the Cattle Council of Australia, the National Farmers Federation and other groups in the community which are concerned about the extent of ownership in the rural community of things which ought to be proudly and 100 per cent owned by Australian interests. It is of concern to those people that we are selling off the farm in a very literal way. If this legislation goes through with the thresholds that apply, there will be very limited capacity for the FIRB to scrutinise, monitor, ask questions and stop, if necessary the extent of foreign ownership.

I am not concerned just about the question of Japanese ownership. The problem, of course, since we do not have readily available accurate public figures about who does own that part of Australia which is no longer in Australian hands, is that there is a tendency for people to perceive Asian ownership as being majority ownership. This produces all sorts of xenophobic results, not to say outright racism. I can remember an Australian National University seminar eight or nine years ago entitled, from memory, `Who owns Australia?'. When it was pointed out that millions of hectares of Australian pastoral land in the north were in fact owned by Saudi Arabian and West German interests. As a member of Parliament, I am not particularly concerned whether Australian property, real estate, rural land and so on is owned by Saudi Arabians, West Germans, Kiwis, British or Asians. What I am concerned about is the amount that is not owned by Australia and the rationale behind it. This will be totally deregulated if the Opposition ever becomes government. If we do not have some sort of register of foreign ownership, then the Australian public-and that includes members of parliament, who do not have access to these sorts of details-will not be in a position either to justify the amount of ownership or to oppose it.

If one does not have information, one has no real right to be making declaration on one side or the other. That is really putting the general public at a distinct disadvantage. If there is not proper scrutiny of overseas investment in this country, we have no idea what proportion of this country is owned by whom, what their money making capacity is and where that money is finishing up. There is certainly anecdotal evidence-and groups like the Cattlemen's Union, the National Farmers Federation and people who just watch what is being bought down the coast of Queensland are aware of some of what is going on-but the real picture is not going to be made available either until we have a national register, about which I intend to have considerably more to say in a minute, or while we have thresholds applying to certain purchases.

Given the comments made by people such as Senator Watson during the second reading debate, and given the concerns expressed by the National Party and rural lobbyists over the extent of foreign ownership in the rural sector, I would have hoped to get at least the support of my colleagues in the National Party for this amendment, if not the support of Liberal Party senators. I am disturbed that at this stage there are in the chamber no members of the National Party preparing to take part in this debate. They have expressed their concern publicly. Now is the time for them essentially to put their money where their mouth is and support the Democrats' amendment for removing these thresholds and requiring the Foreign Investment Review Board to have scrutiny of all purchases of Australian business and real estate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment is the first of what are really two interlocked amendments that have been put forward by Senator Haines. The Liberal and National parties will be opposing both amendments, for very clear and cogent reasons which I will now outline. The purpose of the first amendment in respect of the new sections 13a and 13b in the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill is to exclude takeovers of Australian companies and businesses with total assets below $3m where more than half of the assets of the businesses are attributable to rural land and, in the case of other businesses, $5m. The force of Senator Haines's amendment is to exclude altogether from the effect of the proposed law those businesses below that level. The effect of her second amendment, which has not yet been moved, is to require that all foreign takeovers be subject to the scrutiny of the machinery which she has outlined in the second amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: One is staggered by the size of the Australian Democrats' proposal. What she is doing is bringing to account, to scrutiny, every single transaction, irrespective of its size, its value and the concern it may have for Australian citizens. Some areas of concern are obviously of greater concern than others to Australians, but requiring potential overseas investors to notify the Treasurer of every single transaction, no matter what the size, is certainly not something that the Opposition would seek to support. It has not even been contemplated by the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) on previous occasions. It seems to be an onerous and expensive procedure that has very little value and would not add to the sum of human knowledge to a very great degree at all. That is the first reason for rejecting the Democrats' first amendment.

The consequence of enacting such a requirement would be to ensure that foreign investment in this country stopped dead in its tracks. The loss of confidence as a result of such an enactment would have enormous consequences for this country, especially at a time when this country is absolutely desperate, because of the financial policies of the present Government, for foreign investment. We have to find upwards of $1 1/2 billion every month just to stay alive. That would be cut off immediately as a result of the Democrats' proposals. Quite apart from that, the bureaucratic machinery that would be required to be established, and no doubt Senator Haines will have more to say about that--

TALK.START.PARA: —The ACOA would love it.

—I am sure that somebody would love it because I am told that if this were brought into force it would amount to something like 1,000 extra employees in the Treasury. It would certainly create an enormous bureaucracy for somebody. That kind of bureaucratic nightmare is something that Australia has already become famous for on the world scene. We have the complex situation where foreign investors of various kinds are forced to deal with both State and Federal bureaucracies, which inhibits enormously their capacity to make decisions in a rational way. Now we are seeking, by the Democrats' amendment, if it is accepted, to impose even more stringent and difficult requirements which are complex and costly, overriding the need for this country to look at the question of foreign investment.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that foreign investment brings enormous economic benefits to this country if it is handled in the right way. I agree with Senator Haines to the extent that there is a need to know exactly where this is occurring, but I do not agree that her means of surveilling foreign investment is the way to go. It is clear-and that will become part of the argument in the second amendment that she intends to move-that there are means available already, certainly at the State level, for the scrutiny of foreign investment. We have within the State jurisdictions the land titles offices, where all land transactions are recorded. We have the corporate affairs commissions where all transfers of shares in companies are recorded and which are publicly accessible. Yet we have the Democrats wanting to superimpose upon this a whole new bureaucracy duplicating all of that. It just seems to be an absolute nonsense.

In contrast, we on this side would like to see the Federal Government coordinating the efforts of the various States to ensure that that information is properly collated and recorded to better serve the public benefit. If the Democrats were at all serious in their motives here-one suspects that they are not and that this is just another political stunt-they would have thought through the consequences of the amendment they are proposing. Clearly, they have not. That is the reason why we in the Liberal and National parties will not be supporting either of the amendments that are put forward. But I restrict my argument now to the first amendment which Senator Haines has moved. I say for the record that we will not be supporting that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it rather amazing that Senator Messner believes that just because something is a bit difficult to do and might involve employing a few more people we should not do it. He may not have noticed this, but when Australians earn money they are required to provide the details to the Treasurer. A foreign resident who buys a piece of urban real estate is required to provide details from dollar one. If it is all right to have no threshold for urban real estate why is it not equally applicable to have no threshold for rural real estate? I would have thought that we were far more vulnerable in the area of problems relating to rural property purchases. After all, we have seen questions asked in this chamber about access for isolated children to something such as Austudy, which is not only income tested but assets tested as well. In many cases the nominal value of the property on which those people live is highly inflated due to purchases by foreign interests of rural property.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh gets up in the chamber saying that if a piece of property is worth $600,000 and people cannot make their living from it then they ought not to be on that property; they should get off it and leave it to somebody who can make a profit on it and take their kids to the city where they do not need Austudy payments because they have access to the school system. That is fine and dandy as long as the property is genuinely worth $600,000 and not simply because the property next door or in the next region was purchased by foreign interests for whom Australian real estate, whether it is urban or rural, is bargain basement as far as pricing is concerned. Those who live in Europe or Asia are aware of the fact that our property prices from their perspective are a give-away. They are quite prepared to pay much higher prices than Australians can afford.

I do not subscribe to the arguments put forward by Sydney real estate agents that foreign investors in the real estate market are not having an impact on the price of property in this country. Of course they must. It is not simply $4m harbourside properties in Sydney that these people are purchasing. Even if it were, the trickle down effect would have some impact on markets, at least in the upper brackets. The fact of the matter is that in Perth and elsewhere foreign investors have been moving into real estate at the smaller level, buying up whole blocks of units for an inflated price, pushing up the rentals in order to get their money back and therefore having an impact on the rest of the market.

If it is good enough to recognise the problem that is occurring in urban real estate markets and to remove the threshold there, then surely we should be recognising that those people who live in rural areas have the same rights to protection as their cousins living in urban areas. I would have thought that, given the parlous state of the rural economy at the moment, they would have even more reason for getting protection from highly inflated house prices than their city cousins do.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not accept these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner has said that the Australian Democrats' proposal is outrageous and that scrutiny should start from dollar one in all property. I remind honourable senators of something I referred to in my speech in the second reading debate; that is, that the Cattlemen's Union of Australia has asked for even more-not simply scrutiny or even a register but the establishment of guidelines for scrutiny which, in the area of the industry with which it is most concerned, the meat industry, would have meat authorities to determine whether an industry benefit analysis was needed. The Cattle Council of Australia went on to suggest that there should be an economic impact study. It outlined quite a detailed process that it believed should be undertaken. There are other people in the community who are very concerned about this. I reiterate the point that Senator Haines has made-that is, if it is good enough for urban real estate to come under scrutiny, it is certainly good enough for rural real estate and for industries and investment concerning rural people also to come under scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Haines's) be agreed to.

Clause agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated before dinner, the Australian Democrats intend to move an amendment that would allow for the establishment of a register of foreign corporations-that is, a register of foreign ownership in this country. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 20, after clause 32, add the following new clause:
Register of Foreign Corporations
``33. After section 38 of the Principal Act, the following new Part is inserted:
`PART IV-REGISTER OF FOREIGN CORPORATIONS OWNING OR CONTROLLING AUSTRALIAN PROPERTY
Interpretation
`38A. (1) In this Part, unless the contrary intention appears:
``Australia'' includes the External Territories;

``Australian corporation'' means a corporation incorporated or registered in a participating State or a participating Territory under the provisions of the Companies Act, other than such a corporation that is a foreign corporation as defined in this subsection;
``Commission'' means the National Companies and Securities Commission established by the National Companies and Securities Commission Act 1979;
``Companies Act'' means the Companies Act 1981 of the Commonwealth or a corresponding law of a State or Territory;

``debenture'' includes debenture stock, bonds, notes and any other document evidencing or acknowledging indebtedness of a corporation in respect of money that is or may be deposited with or lent to the corporation, whether constituting a charge on property of the corporation or not, but does not include a prescribed document or a document included in a prescribed class of documents;
``foreign corporation'' means:
(a) any body (including a society or association) incorporated outside Australia, including a recognised foreign corporation;
(b) an unincorporated society, association or other body formed outside Australia that:

(i) under the law of its place of formation, may sue or be sued, or may hold property in the name of the secretary or other officer of the society, association or body duly appointed for that purpose; and
(ii) does not have its head office or principal place of business in Australia;
(c) a corporation in which a natural person not ordinarily resident in Australia holds a controlling interest;
(d) a corporation in which 2 or more persons, each of whom is a natural person not ordinarily resident in Australia, hold an aggregate controlling interest; or
(e) a corporation in which:
(i) a body referred to in paragraph (a);
(ii) a society, association or other body referred to in paragraph (b); or
(iii) a corporation referred to in paragraph (c) or (d),
holds a controlling interest;

``investment contract'' means any contract, scheme or arrangement that, in substance and irrespective of the form of the contract, scheme or arrangement, involves the investment of money in or under such circumstances that the investor acquires or may acquire an interest in or right in respect of property in Australia that under, or in accordance with, the terms of investment will, or may at the option of the investor, be used or employed in common with any other interest in or right in respect of property, whether in Australia or elsewhere, acquired in or under like circumstances;

``last accounting date'', in relation to a corporation, means the date of the expiration of the most recent period in relation to which a balance-sheet of the corporation has been laid before it in general meeting, including a balance-sheet so laid before it before the commencement of this Part;
``mineral right'' means:
(a) an authority, licence, permit or right under a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory to prospect or explore for, or to recover, minerals;
(b) a lease under such a law by virtue of which the lessee is entitled to prospect or explore for, or to recover, minerals; or
(c) an interest in such an authority, licence, permit, right or lease;
``participating State'' means a State that is a party to the Agreement,
``participating Territory'' means;
(a) the Northern Territory; and
(b) an external Territory to which the Agreement applies in pursuance of clause 50 of the Agreement;
``prescribed interest'' means any right to participate or interest, whether enforceable or not and whether actual, prospective or contingent;
(a) in any profits, assets or realisation of any financial or business undertaking or scheme in Australia;

(b) in any common enterprise, in Australia, in which the holder of the right or interest is led to expect profits, rent or interest from the efforts of the promoter of the enterprise or a third party; or
(c) in any investment contract,
whether or not the right or interest is evidenced by a formal document and whether or not the right or interest relates to a physical asset, but does not include:
(d) any interest in, or arising out of, a policy of life insurance; or

(e) a right or interest, or a right or interest included in a class or kind of rights or interests, declared by the regulations to be an exempt right or interest, or a class or kind of exempt rights or interests, for the purposes of this definition;

``recognised foreign corporation'' means a foreign corporation formed outside Australia that is registered as a foreign company in a participating State or participating Territory under the provisions of the law of that State or Territory that correspond with Division 5 of Part XIII of the Companies Act 1981;
``securities'' means;
(a) debentures, stocks or bonds issued or proposed to be issued by a government;
(b) debentures (including debentures that do not constitute a charge on assets), stocks, shares, bonds or notes issued or proposed to be issued by a body corporate or unincorporate;
(c) any right or option in respect of any such debentures, stocks, shares, bonds or notes; or
(d) a prescribed interest,
but shall not include a prescribed document or a document included in a prescribed class of documents;
``share'' means share in the share capital of a body corporate, and includes stock except where a distinction between stock and shares is expressed or implied;
``the Agreement'' has the same meaning as it has in the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1980.

`(2) For the purposes of this Part, the question whether a corporation is a holding corporation of an Australian corporation shall be determined in the same manner as the question whether the company within the meaning of the Companies Act 1981 is the holding company of another such company is required to be determined under that Act for the purposes of that Act.
`(3) For the purposes of this Part, the question-
(a) whether a person holds a controlling interest in a corporation; or
(b) whether 2 or more persons hold an aggregate controlling interest in a corporation,
shall be determined in the same manner as that question is required to be determined under the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975 for the purposes of that Act.
Prescribed corporations
`38b. (1) A reference in this Part to a prescribed corporation is a reference to-

(a) a foreign corporation that, on its last accounting date, held assets the sum of the values of which exceeded $5,000 or, if another amount is prescribed for the purpose of this paragraph, the amount so prescribed, being assets consisting of all or any of the following:
(i) land situated in Australia (including legal and equitable interests in such land);
(ii) mineral rights;
(iii) shares in a corporation incorporated in Australia;
(iv) securities issued in Australia; or
(v) assets of a prescribed kind or included in a prescribed class of assets;

(b) a foreign corporation that was, on its last accounting date, a holding corporation of an Australian corporation or Australian corporations, where the sum of the values, on that date, of the assets of the Australian corporation or Australian corporations exceeded $5,000 or, if another amount is prescribed for the purpose of paragraph (a), the amount so prescribed;

(c) a foreign corporation that, on its last accounting date, held any single asset (including a single interest in shares or securities) within Australia the value of which exceeded $5,000 or, if another amount is prescribed for the purpose of this paragraph, the amount so prescribed;

(d) a foreign corporation that was, on its last accounting date, a holding corporation of an Australian corporation, or of Australian corporations, which held any single asset (including a single interest in shares or securities) the value of which exceeded $5,000 or, if another amount is prescribed for the purpose of paragraph (c), the amount so prescribed; or
(e) a corporation that was, on its last accounting date, a holding corporation of a foreign corporation referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (d).
`(2) For the purposes of sub-section (1), the assets or a corporation shall be deemed not to include any shares in a subsidiary of that corporation.
Balance-sheet: recognised foreign corporations

`38c. Where a prescribed corporation that is a foreign corporation registered under Division 5 of Part XIII of the Companies Act lodges a copy of its balance-sheet with the Commission under section 516 of the Companies Act, the corporation shall, within 7 days after doing so, cause a copy of that balance-sheet to be lodged with the Treasurer.
Balance-sheet: other foreign corporations

`38d. (1) A prescribed corporation, other than a foreign corporation to which section 38c applies, shall, at least once in every calendar year and at intervals of not more than 15 months, lodge with the Treasurer a copy of its balance-sheet made up to the end of its last financial year, in such form and containing such particulars and including copies of such documents as the corporation is required to prepare by the law for the time being applicable to that corporation in the place of its incorporation or formation, together with a statement in writing in the prescribed form verifying that the copies are true copies of the documents so required.

`(2) The Treasurer may, whether before or after the expiration of the period within which a prescribed corporation is required by sub-section (1) to lodge a copy of a balance-sheet and other documents, extend the period within which the balance-sheet and the other documents are required to be lodged.

`(3) The Treasurer may, if the Treasurer is of the opinion that the balance-sheet and the other documents referred to in sub-section (1) do not sufficiently disclose the corporation's financial position, by notice served on the corporation-
(a) require the corporation to lodge a balance-sheet; or
(b) require the corporation to lodge an audited balance-sheet, within such period, in such form, containing such particulars and including such documents as are specified in the notice.
within such period in such form, containing such particulars and including such documents as are specified in the notice.

`(4) Where a foreign corporation is not required by the law of the place of its incorporation or formation to prepare a balance-sheet, the corporation shall prepare and lodge with the Treasurer a balance-sheet or, if the Treasurer so requires, an audited balance-sheet, within such period, in such form and containing such particulars and including such documents as the corporation would have been required to prepare if the corporation were a company other than a proprietary company incorporated under the Companies Act.
Statement to accompany balance sheet

`38e. (1) Whenever a prescribed corporation lodges with the Treasurer a copy of its balance-sheet in pursuance of section 38c or 38d or in pursuance of a requirement of the Treasurer under subsection 38d (3), the Corporation shall, at the same time, lodge with the Treasurer a statement, in writing, setting out particulars, as at the end of the financial year to which the balance-sheet relates, of:
(a) the name of the corporation;
(b) the address of the registered office of the corporation;
(c) the name and address of the agent, or each agent, of the corporation in Australia;
(d) the name of any other corporation of which the prescribed corporation is a holding corporation;
(e) the total value of assets held within Australia, including, but without limiting the foregoing, assets of the following kinds:
(i) assets situated in Australia;
(ii) mineral rights;
(iii) shares in a corporation incorporated within Australia;
(iv) securities issued in Australia; and
(v) assets of a prescribed kind or included in a prescribed class of assets;
(f) the value of each of the following classes of assets held within Australia:
(i) land situated in Australia (including legal and equitable interests in such land);
(ii) mineral rights;
(iii) shares in a corporation incorporated within Australia;
(iv) securities issued in Australia;
(v) assets of a prescribed kind or included in a prescribed class of assets;

(g) the identity and value of each and every asset held within Australia which has a value in excess of $5,000 or, if another amount is prescribed for the purpose of this paragraph, the amount so prescribed, including, but without limiting the foregoing, each and every asset which has such a value and is any of the following kinds of assets:
(i) assets situated in Australia;
(ii) mineral rights;
(iii) shares in a corporation incorporated within Australia;
(iv) securities issued in Australia;
(v) assets of a prescribed kind or included in a prescribed class of assets; and
(h) the name of any other corporation incorporated in Australia in which the prescribed corporation has:
(i) a controlling interest; or
(ii) an interest in shares or securities, the value of which exceeds $5,000 or, if an amount is prescribed for the purposes of paragraph (g), the amount so prescribed,
and the nature and value of those interests,
and containing such other information, and accompanied by such documents, as are prescribed.

`(2) A prescribed corporation of a kind described in paragraph 38b (1) (b) or (d) shall include in a statement lodged with the Treasurer in pursuance of subsection (1) of this section, in respect of each Australian corporation of which that prescribed corporation is a holding corporation, the particulars specified in subsection (1) of this section as though the Australian corporation were a prescribed corporation.
Form of statement

`38f. A prescribed corporation shall not lodge a statement with the Treasurer in pursuance of section 38e unless the statement has been examined by the auditor of the corporation and the auditor has certified on the statement whether, in the view of the auditor, the particulars shown on the statement are true and fair.
Valuation
`38g. For the purposes of this Part, the value on a particular date of an asset of a corporation, or of an interest in shares or securities held by a corporation, shall be taken to be:
(a) the value of that asset or interest as shown in the last balance-sheet of the corporation that was prepared and audited before that date; or
(b) if no balance-sheet of the corporation was prepared and audited before that date, the value of that asset or interest as shown on that date in the accounting records of the corporation.
Register

`38h. The Treasurer shall cause a Register of Foreign Corporations to be kept for the purposes of this Part, and shall cause to be entered in the Register, in respect of each prescribed corporation that lodges a balance-sheet in pursuance of section 38c or 38d or of a requirement under subsection 38d (3):
(a) the name of the corporation;
(b) the address of the registered office of the corporation;
(c) the name and address of the agent, or of each agent, of the corporation in Australia; and
(d) the date on which each balance-sheet of the corporation was lodged with the Treasurer in accordance with this Act.
(e) the total value of assets held within Australia, including, but without limiting the foregoing, assets of any of the following kinds:
(i) assets situated in Australia;
(ii) mineral rights;
(iii) shares in a corporation incorporated within Australia;
(iv) securities issued in Australia; and
(v) assets of a kind prescribed prescribed for the purpose of subparagraph 38e (1) (e) (v) or included in a kind of assets so prescribed; and
(f) the value of each of the following classes of assets:
(i) land situated in Australia (including legal and equitable interests in such land);
(ii) mineral rights;
(iii) shares in a corporation incorporated within Australia;
(iv) securities issued in Australia;
(v) assets of a kind prescribed prescribed for the purpose of subparagraph 38e (1) (f) (v) or included in a kind of assets so prescribed; and
Inspection

`38j. A person may inspect, and make copies of, or take extracts from, the Register of Foreign Corporations and any balance-sheet or statement lodged with the Treasurer by a prescribed foreign corporation in accordance with this Part.
Offences
`38k. (1) A prescribed foreign corporation:
(a) shall comply with the requirements of section 38c or 38d, whichever is applicable to the corporation;
(b) shall comply with the requirements of a notice served on the corporation under subsection 38d (3); and
(c) shall not lodge with the Treasurer a balance-sheet or statement for the purposes of section 38c, 38d or 38e that is false or misleading in a material particular.
Penalty: $250,000

`(2) Where a prescribed corporation contravenes or fails to comply with subsection (1), any officer or agent of the corporation (including a person who subsequently ceased to be an officer or agent of the corporation) who is in any way by act or omission, directly or indirectly knowingly concerned in or party to the contravention or failure commits an offence against this subsection punishable, upon conviction, by a fine not exceeding $250,000.
` ``(3) For the purposes of subsection (2), where a prescribed foreign corporation is registered under the Companies Act 1981 in a State or Territory:
(a) if it is so registered in a single State or Territory only-the agent of the corporation, within the meaning of Division 5 of Part XIII of the Companies Act 1981, in that State or Territory; or

(b) if it is so registered in 2 or more States or Territories-the agent of the corporation, within the meaning of that Division, in the State or Territory in which it was first so registered, shall, unless the contrary is proved, be deemed to be knowingly concerned in and party to any contravention by the corporation, or failure by the corporation to comply with subsection (1) of this section.'.''.

There is a lot of concern in the community about the level, or the perceived level, of foreign ownership in this country. The fact is that most people in Australia, and that includes members of parliament and business people as well as ordinary men and women in the street, simply do not know how much of Australia is in foreign hands, how much of Australia has been sold, leased, loaned, mortgaged, or in some other way disposed of. We believe, and many people in the community believe, that they are entitled to know and that the best way for them to have access to this information is through a register of foreign ownership. Under those circumstances, of course, the government of the day, of whatever political persuasion, whether it is at the State or Federal level, may still be able to sell off the farm-or the Torrens Island power station in South Australia, the Melbourne central business district, Perth real estate, or whatever-but at least Australians would have some knowledge, if they wished to acquire that knowledge, of how much of it is sold and who is buying it.

The Democrats are not the only people expressing concern at the levels of foreign ownership in Australia. Concern has been expressed by the National Party in Queensland and by the Queensland Labor Party. The Queensland Labor Party has called for a tax on foreigners who own land in Queensland but who live overseas. The Queensland National Party Government introduced a foreign ownership of land register Bill in October last year. I am not aware of whether it is operating yet. I do not think it is; I think it has been held over. In any event, at least it has indicated some sort of bona fides as far as registering some foreign ownership is concerned. It is only some; it concerns foreign ownership of land, foreign ownership of businesses or the whole gamut of ownership. The Liberal Premier of Tasmania announced last year that he, too, would establish, or attempt to establish, a register of foreign land ownership in Tasmania. I am not aware how far that has progressed, but to the best of my knowledge it still has not been introduced. The point is that it ought not be left to the goodwill of State governments to put in place ad hoc registers of some parts of the foreign ownership situation.
