Many people believe that there is a problem with foreign ownership, but we cannot determine absolutely whether there is a problem, to what extent there is a problem or in what areas that problem occurs until we have established a register of what foreign investments there are in this country. Only when that has been done will we know which Australian assets are controlled by foreign interests, which States, which regions, which industries have a foreign ownership problem or are in some way benefiting from foreign ownership. We are not in any position to make categorical statements about foreign ownership unless we have the information on which to base those statements. While governments prefer not to give ordinary individuals access to the information, one must suppose that it is more likely to be a problem than a benefit or there would be no need to hide the information.

The history of foreign investment in Australia in recent times, of course, is, apparently at least, a history of increasing dependency. We argue that we have all sorts of economic problems in all sorts of other areas, that if we do not attract foreign money to this country we will have additional problems in meeting foreign debt and so on. That may well be a situation that needs correcting, but I am not sure that too many Australians would genuinely believe that selling off the farm and any other bits of Australia that are not tacked down is necessarily the best way of correcting some other very real, very serious and ongoing economic problems that we face.

One of the difficulties facing the community is that it is not sure whether there is an excessive amount of foreign ownership or, if there is, in what areas it lies. The concern in the community is real. Whether it is justified, we will not know until we have some form of public access to the information that will provide the basis either for concern or for pleasure at what is happening to this country. There is concern that Australia has very easy rules and regulations regarding foreign ownership-certainly a lot freer than apply in many countries. I was somewhat startled, during a recent television program in which some very angry Australians confronted a Japanese investor, that nobody asked him to justify Japan's fairly strict rules with regard to foreign ownership-far stricter than we have here.

The fact is that we simply do not know anything but dollar amounts as far as foreign ownership is concerned. We are able to get some sort of breakdowns, and I cited those figures earlier this evening. We have virtually no information about the who, the what and the why of foreign ownership. Nobody inside or outside of this Parliament has any real capacity, as I said, to criticise, support, oppose or justify foreign investment in Australia when we are so deprived of the necessary information. As I said, we can only suppose that it is a worst case scenario because we are not given access to any information to make any other sort of judgment. Without information, we are, on the one hand, powerless to asses the value of foreign ownership, if there is any, and, on the other hand, powerless to challenge the extent, amount and potential damage of foreign ownership.

What is worse, of course, is that this lack of knowledge is playing into the hands of some extremists on both sides of the argument. Those who appear blindly to support all or any foreign investment justify it on economic grounds which are not-I guess because they cannot be-based on fully detailed factual information, simply because that information is not available. Just as worrying, maybe even more worrying, is that while foreign investment is not new, the awareness of it in the hearts and minds of the electorate is new and it is occasionally being misdirected. The reason is that we have a relatively new phenomenon of significant Asian investment in this country-something which is far more obvious to ordinary Australians than, say, investment by the British, New Zealanders, West Germans or possibly even Saudi Arabians. There is a very visible amount of investment by Asians in this country. This is happening for a variety of reasons, some of which may be justified, some of which are not. This is far more stringently opposed by average Australians than is investment by other foreign nationals. This is bringing a very disturbing element of racism into the debate on foreign ownership. It is a recent element of racism; it is a reprehensible element of racism; but it is possibly an understandable element, certainly in some areas. For all we know to the contrary, the concern that is frequently expressed in Queensland in particular but also in other areas as to the extent of Japanese investment may be unjustified. I suspect that it is not, and that there is, in fact, a significantly increasing amount of foreign investment in this country which is Japanese investment. In any event we, as members of parliament, and the members of the public are entitled to know who owns what and how much of this country. We are entitled to know what is owned by whom, what the benefits and drawbacks are, and where the profits from the venture will be going.

I said a moment ago that the Torrens Island power station in South Australia has been sold to foreign interests on a lease back basis, if I recall correctly, but we do not know who has bought that utility. Frankly, I do not think that is good enough. We live, so we are repeatedly being told around here, in a democracy. Members of parliament from time to time-especially when they are in opposition-espouse the intrinsic merits of open government. How can we be a democracy, how can we have open government, if information is denied to the electorate and to members of parliament on something as vitally important as who owns how much of Australia and how much of the money they are making out of what they own is going out of the country to the country of origin?

Real estate agents dismiss the idea that foreign investment in urban or rural land has any impact on prices or stock availability across the board. That is fine for them. We know that many foreign investors are capable of paying far more for land and property than are the average Australians, so the higher the price goes the better off the real estate agent is because the bigger the cut is. I do not think that is sufficient justification for somebody arguing that there is no harm in foreign investment in urban or rural real estate.

I said before dinner that there is a real problem for some people who live in isolated areas and whose property has a nominal value that is much higher than they would ever get from an Australian buyer simply because a foreign investor has bought an adjoining or nearby property at an inflated price and has pushed up, therefore, the apparent value of their property. As a consequence, people living in country areas in northern South Australia, in Queensland, and in Western Australia are finding that the very necessary Austudy payments that they need to educate their children properly are being denied them because the income and assets test is applied strictly but unfairly in this case because the property value is not the real value of what Australians would be paying for that property. I would have thought that logic alone would force people to dispute the real estate agent's argument that there is no effect across the board on real estate prices because of foreign ownership. Logic is all we have to go on. There are no detailed facts available to us. Those facts will not be available to us until we have a register.

It is interesting that a group such as the National Farmers Federation is also concerned about this matter. It is not just the concern of some Australian families who want to buy homes but find that the price is going out of their reach and they cannot meet the mortgage repayments because interest rates are blowing out. The National Farmers Federation, in a letter to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), said:
. . . National Farmers Federation is concerned that the change will prevent any reasonable-
that is, the change to the minimum value for which Foreign Investment Review Board approval is required for rural property purchased by foreign nationals-

assessment of the level of foreign land ownership in Australia. In the interest of national security and being able to respond to public concern about foreign ownership, it is highly desirable that the Government maintain the capacity to observe and measure the level of foreign ownership, even where approval is not required.

NFF considers that the foreign takeovers legislation should require foreign investment in land (and possibly selected other assets) to be notified to the FIRB. In addition steps may need to be taken to strengthen the FIRB's powers to ensure that a requirement to notify is effective and enforceable.

There is real concern in rural communities about the effect of foreign ownership. If only to alleviate those concerns-even if the Government and the Opposition believe there is no reason for concern-we should be moving to a national register of foreign ownership of property and of business in this country. I commend the amendment to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with some care to the intervention by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Haines. With respect to the honourable senator, the problem she presents to the Committee is one which only too frequently derives from the corner of the chamber in which she and her colleagues sit; that is to say, it is a whole catalogue of complaints, fears and criticisms-but no solutions. That is only too typical of the Party of which Senator Haines has the honour-I presume that is the right word-to be leader. I am the more moved to make that sort of comment in view of the fact that on almost every occasion that we debate in this chamber questions of fiscal policy, monetary policy, or any aspect of economic policy, whether it be macro-economic policy or micro-economic policy, we find that the voices being raised from the Australian Democrats' corner are almost invariably in favour of measures which would have the effect-not the direct effect but the indirect effect-of rendering worse the very problem about which Senator Haines is now moaning. Yet the Leader of the Australian Democrats comes into this chamber and upbraids us all. I have no brief for the Government in this matter, and I will come to it in due course, but I find it offensive that Senator Haines appears to believe that the level of intelligence of the Australian electorate is so low that it does not see through this kind of populist demagoguery of which this intervention tonight is just another example.
—They do not need a majority. They only need about 8 per cent.

—Since we have been favoured with an interjection from the Minister for Finance, let me turn my attention to the role of the Government in this whole matter. The Government does not come to this question with clean hands either, although I would say in fairness to Senator Walsh that perhaps his hands are a little cleaner in this regard than those of most his Cabinet colleagues, by which I mean that Senator Walsh is I think publicly and semi-publicly on the record as standing for a good deal more rational economic policies than so far he has been able to persuade his colleagues to accept.

SPEECH.PARA: However, let us ask a few simple questions about foreign investment in Australia, around which this debate has revolved. I hope that Senator Haines would not contradict me if I were to say-and I think she said it herself-that we are today receiving a significant foreign capital inflow into this country not only in the form of what is typically called foreign investment, as it is certainly called in this debate, namely, the acquisition of physical or paper assets by foreigners, but also in the form of the issue of debt instruments to foreigners by Australian residents, whether they be governments, corporations or sometimes individuals. In terms of the Statistician's definition, that is just as much foreign investment as is the thing we are talking about tonight.

Let us assume that by some wave of a magic wand or, if one likes to conjure up an even much more horrifying prospect, some wave of the control power of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), as exercised by the Australian Democrats-and that would be really horrifying-we abolished entirely the capacity of foreign investors to acquire Australian assets, whether it be in the form of land, which has been much discussed, or some other form of asset. If nothing else changed-in other words, if Australia continued to pursue the rake's progress of economic policies which under this Government it has now been pursuing over the last six years-all that would mean is that we would have to borrow more.

At present we are running a balance of payments deficit on current account of over $15 billion per annum. Nobody can be quite sure where it will finish up for 1988-89, but it will certainly finish up over $15 billion. I do not know what the amount will be, because I do not have sufficiently up to date figures, but let us say that about $5 billion of that is being financed by foreigners purchasing Australian assets-whether they be rural property, real estate, shares in Australian companies, Australian companies themselves or some part of them-and the other $10 billion is being financed by Australian residents', whether they be government, corporations or individuals, borrowings.

The first thing to have very clearly in mind when we address the question before the chamber tonight is that, in the absence of any policies to address the underlying cause of this phenomenon, the only effect of producing a diminution in the level of foreign ownership of Australia would be to produce an increase in the level of foreign indebtedness of Australians. Once again we have the rather characteristic phenomenon in Australian economic debate of addressing symptoms, not causes.

I have already hinted at the cause by my reference to the fact that these things are occurring because we are running a balance of payments deficit on current account of over $15 billion a year. I might add that we are doing that at a time when, as the Statistician observed in the national accounts document published yesterday, our international terms of trade are at their most favourable level since the March quarter of 1977. This is the best period for 12 years. So, on what the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and the International Monetary Fund might call a cyclically adjusted view of the matter-that is to say, if one adjusted the statistics of our balance of payments deficit to account for the fact that we are at present enjoying very favourable trading conditions-we are actually running a balance of payments deficit in the order of $20 billion a year. On that basis it would be something like 6 per cent or 6 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product.

I do not want to spend too long on those kinds of speculations. I simply want to make the fundamental point that if people in Australia are concerned about the growing acquisition by foreigners of assets previously owned by Australians-I confess to concern on that point and, in that sense at least, I share some of the views that Senator Haines expressed and many other people are beginning to express-let us start talking about the policies that are required to get rid of the need on our part to finance a balance of payments deficit either by borrowing or by selling off bits of Australia. I have to say to Senator Haines, and to anybody else who wants to embark on the same kind of emotional trip that she was on, that, unless one is prepared to accept and acknowledge that that is the heart of the matter, one simply cannot be taken seriously, and must not expect to be taken seriously in any proper discourse on the subject.

As Senator Haines also pointed out, some specific aspects of the present foreign investment debate in Australia do give rise to concern. I referred to at least one of those in my remarks during the second reading debate on this Bill, and that is the growing body of voices being raised in protest against the prevalence of foreign investment from Japan. As Senator Haines quite rightly observed-again I agree with her on this point-there is a racist undertone in those comments and it is not a pretty one. Nevertheless, again I say that if we are concerned to mute or dampen down that kind of comment in the interests of the quality of life and the quality of social discourse in this country, we should start addressing the causes, not run around addressing the symptoms by talking about land registers, this, that and the other.

Having said that, I have to say that our Japanese colleagues are not altogether blameless in this matter. In recent times concern has been expressed in the area of so-called vertically integrated investment in the beef industry. I refer here to the process whereby a Japanese trading company comes in and purchases an abattoir in which it can slaughter the beef. No doubt such a company can make arrangements to purchase its own trucking business in order to transport the beef to a port. Certainly, the beef can be shipped in a Japanese ship and so on. On the face of it, there is nothing in any of that to which one could reasonably object. Other countries are quite free to do the same thing. The objection relates not to any of those actions but to the other end of the chain of production, the distribution end, when that meat arrives in Japan. As anybody who has had a look at the Japanese meat importing system knows, the system is totally rigged, like a good many other things in Japan, against the foreigner.

It follows from that that Japanese firms entering that trade do so not on equal competitive terms-which we tend to assume is the case when we talk about this in good economic textbook fashion-with, say, an Australian producer or, for that matter, an American producer, who had made a similar purchase of assets in Australia. A Japanese firm does not do so on equal competitive terms at all, because a Japanese producer in Australia can pick up all of his margins in Japan, which the Australian producer cannot do. By definition, one simple consequence which flows from that is that the Japanese purchaser can afford to pay a lot more for those assets than can an Australian competitor or, for that matter, an American or British foreign investor, who does not have the same privileged access to the highly regulated and highly controlled marketing distribution systems for beef as is the case in Japan.

If we want to start talking about Japanese investment in our beef industry, that is the problem we ought to be addressing. Our Ministers ought to be talking to Japanese authorities. They should say to them in no uncertain terms that this kind of approach to international trade is not acceptable. If there are to be sanctions of any kind against foreign investment in Australia, which I personally think should be abhorred for the most part, they would need to be very carefully and specifically directed to instances of the kinds I have given by way of example where one could quite conclusively demonstrate that the foreign investor is in fact not operating on equal terms with its Australian or, for that matter, its other foreign competitors possessing equivalent assets in Australia. The debate on this Bill would be a great deal more rational and therefore a great deal more productive if we began to focus on some of these causes and stopped talking about symptoms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate, first of all, that I am in total agreement with the remarks of Senator Stone in this regard and to draw attention to the fact that we are dealing with what amounts to an amendment that I believe the Australian Democrats have given very little thought to. They have obviously not in any way thought through the consequences of what they are proposing. Let me just take some of the detailed parts of the first amendment moved by the Democrats, which we discussed before dinner.

SPEECH.PARA: Before going to that, let me put on the record that the Liberal and National parties have, as Senator Stone has outlined, an underlying concern about the degree of foreign investment in this country. We share with many Australians the need to know more about the nature and the form of that investment. Given that there are registries of real estate ownership and corporate ownership in the hands of the State governments, we, in government, would seek, through the Treasury, to establish a unit to bring together and coordinate the activities of the State governments in keeping those records so as to disclose the degree of foreign investment. That is the sensible down to earth approach that can be adopted by any Federal government. It is the proper role of the Federal Parliament. To do otherwise and to accept what the Democrats are proposing, by establishing a national registry of all these assets, would be merely to duplicate much of that which is already available within the public record and that which can be publicly accessed within the various States.

Let me just give an example of the difficulty of what the Democrats are proposing by the establishment of this new national registry within the Department of the Treasury. The simple point to be made is that this amounts to a duplication of the land titles offices and the corporate affairs commissions of each of the States to be located within the Federal Treasury-a total duplication of those things which are already being carried out by the States. That seems to me to be totally unnecessary, for a start. It would simply amount to enormous extra costs to the taxpayers of Australia and would be a major inhibiting factor to the future of foreign investment which, as Senator Stone pointed out, is so necessary to keep this country going. This Government's policies have forced this country to become more or less a mendicant on the world stage, to the tune of $1,500m a month in order to survive. For Australia to pay its bills every month we need $1,500m to flow in. That is a direct result of this Government's policies. It flows directly from this Government's lack of performance in the areas of reforming the waterfront, industrial relations, the telecommunications industry and so on. We made those points in the earlier part of the debate, at the second reading stage.

I will just pick up one or two points in Senator Haines's remarks when speaking to her amendment. I do not know whether she has read through the amendment that she has moved. I am sure that I heard her correctly. I heard her say that the proposed registry applied to nothing else but real estate.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not say that at all. I said the Queensland registry applies to nothing other than real estate.
—I beg your pardon. But I just draw out the point--
—The answer to your first question was yes, I have read the amendment.

—Good. I am glad to hear that. The first point I want to draw out is that it is a requirement, if this amendment were to be accepted, that persons investing more than $5,000 in any instrument, which includes a savings account, a cheque account or a purchase of Australian Government bonds in London, register that in this almighty register than Senator Haines wants to create in the Treasury in Canberra. The mind boggles at the cost of establishing such a register and the money that would have to be spent in order to maintain such a register. If an aunt in London chooses to send out to her niece an Australian Government bond purchased in London, that would presumably have to go on this register. That is the sort of nonsense being proposed by the Democrats. It clearly extends right across the whole range of what might be regarded as ordinary transactions. That is why we object to this proposal and why we do not support it.

SPEECH.PARA: The commonsense approach is to coordinate that information, which is already available on the public record and which is fully accessible to the Australian people. As I mentioned earlier, that is not to say that we are not concerned about this matter. We are saying that this is the way to do it; this is the way the Democrats should be pursuing the matter. This is the way that we, in the Liberal and National parties, in government will be pursuing this in order to ensure that the information which Senator Haines seeks is made available. It will then be conducive to the making of appropriate decisions within government about the nature and extent of foreign investment in this country.

I want to conclude by reiterating the point that that duplication, which could well be eliminated by a proper coordination by a Federal government, is in fact being set up because of the positive moves that some State governments are already making. The Queensland Government is the case in point. Senator Haines referred to that. I noticed in recent days that the South Australian Government similarly is moving in that direction. I understand the Tasmanian Government is doing so as well. In other words, the facilities readily to hand, under the control of the State governments, are being mobilised to establish the kinds of registries that are the purpose of Senator Haines's amendment. That being so, this enormous bureaucracy which, I am told, could employ as many as 1,000 extra public servants would be absolutely superfluous and useless in the kinds of situations that Senator Haines envisages. Consequently it does not have the support of the Liberal and National parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a touch amazed at some of the matters that Senator Messner has talked about. For a member of a party who gets up here and spouts States rights all the time to be talking about virtually compulsorily coordinating information that is collected and collated by the States into a national registry seems to be running counter to all the other protestations we have heard from members of the Liberal Party of Australia when there has been any suggestion that perhaps there should be a cooperative effort among the States to provide the Federal Government with information on practically anything. Duplication, of course, is something we live with in a federation and, unless the Opposition parties are planning on doing something like abolishing the States or giving additional constitutional powers to the Federal Government, there is no way that the Federal Government can compulsorily acquire the sort of information from land titles registries and one thing and another that are currently the province of State governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner talked about the enormous cost and the large number of people who would have to be employed to run this operation. I have only his word for the fact that it will take squillions of people to handle this, but I would have thought that, in any event, the cost-whatever it may be-may well be worth it. We in this country regularly expend money in order to protect our country and our citizenry. We did not hear members of the Liberal Party, for example, saying that they would oppose the tax file number proposals because of the cumbersome bureaucracy, the difficulties associated with the cost of mail-outs and the confusion and so on that they would cause. They quite cheerfully supported the tax file number legislation, apparently despite the cost of the bureaucracy and what appear now to be some significant infringements of privacy.

I find it rather odd, too, for anybody to suggest that simply requiring a foreigner who owns property or business in this country to register it on a national register would inhibit foreign investment. Does somebody have something to hide? Unless people do, why would they object to their name being listed on a register of this sort? Surely if there is no problem with the investment it ought to be open to scrutiny, particularly if, as Senator Messner asserts, it is already open to scrutiny for those who know where to look in some State government departments.

I would also like to question just what real value there is in some of the investment that is being made, particularly by the Japanese, who are giving themselves the benefit of moving into Australian ownership not only in the beef industry but also in other areas. For example, we are seeing increasingly that the Japanese are buying golf courses, tourist developments, hotels and what have you for the exclusive use of Japanese nationals who are visiting Australia as tourists or on business. What benefit is that to anyone other than to the owners of the golf course who cheerfully sold out their property to the Japanese for whatever benefit they could get? The money that therefore goes out of the country is not benefiting Australia at all. Should anyone think that Japanese tourists will not come here if they cannot play on Japanese owned golf courses and stay in Japanese owned hotels, that certainly has not been the situation to date, and one wonders why it should be the situation in the future.

Senator Stone said that he had listened carefully to what I said, and I wonder which part he was listening to, because at no stage in the 15 minutes prior to this did I suggest that we should stop foreign investment. I may have talked in the past, publicly and in this Parliament, about putting some limits on foreign investment, as many other countries do, but I did not do so in the previous 15 minutes; I concentrated entirely on providing the necessary information that we in this chamber and the general public need if there is to be an informed debate rather than an inflamed debate-which is very largely what we have seen to date.

I also find it a little odd for Senator Stone to indicate that he is not in favour of many restrictions on foreign ownership when, as I understand it, if one believes what one reads in newspapers-and who does not when it is one's opponent being written about?-the National Party has a policy for firmer control on foreign investment, particularly in the agricultural and fishing industries. Certainly supporters of the National Party such as the National Farmers Federation and the cattlemen-the National Party's main constituency-would like to see an investment freeze and a lot more stringent restrictions placed on foreign nationals investing in this country. For example, they would like to see the Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines made much tougher rather than less strict, which is what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has acted to do.

The cattlemen would like to see economic impact statements required of foreign investors proposing investment worth a million dollars or more, with such investment proposals to be subject to government and industry scrutiny. The cattlemen want to see Japan agree to allow equal access for Australian investors. I think this is one source of increasing resentment-that foreign investors expect to be able to invest here, for whatever economic reason we care to allow it, under a certain set of rules that they do not apply in return. The cattlemen's industry estimates suggest that Japanese trading houses now control a third of Australia's beef feedlot capacity and almost 15 per cent of meatworks capacity-almost quadrupling what it was a year ago. As Senator Stone has pointed out, that benefits not Australia but entirely the Japanese as far as their trade is concerned.

If Senator Stone wants to broaden the debate-which we are not supposed to do at the committee stage of a Bill anyway-maybe we ought to have a look at non-tariff barriers that are applied by a range of countries with whom we trade on a regular basis. Maybe we should say, `Okay, all people who are producing primary produce for sale in Australia should have applied to them the same manufacturing, contents and packaging requirements that apply to our own local producers-no artificial colouring and flavouring in cheeses, no unwashed Pakistani dates'. Maybe we should start looking at a few non-tariff barriers in this country. I would be the first to agree with Senator Stone that we need to start looking at the source of the problem and taking some retaliatory action. But that is not what this Bill is about; nor is it what my amendment is about. I point out that my amendment is not about stopping foreign investment-although if some people prefer not to invest because they might have to disclose their investment, that is a decision they will make. This amendment aims at providing accessible information without somebody-whether it is a member of parliament, a bureaucrat or an ordinary member of the public-having to go State by State through lands titles registries, which is a fairly bizarre operation, not to say expensive.

Our tourist industry is increasingly, if not largely, in the hands of foreign ownership, and that is not necessarily a good thing. There have been studies to show that both here and overseas the benefits to a country of tourist developments would be a lot better if they were in the hands of nationals of that country rather than those of foreign investors. Dr Adrian Bull, a Queensland academic, has done some studies on other countries pointing out that foreign investment in tourism should be stringently controlled so that the financial benefit does not simply flow back to the visitor's own country. I mentioned a moment ago the amount of Japanese investment which is being made available specifically and sometimes only to visiting Japanese nationals.

Dr Bull points out that in some western European countries-he cites Spain as a specific example-as little as 31 per cent of all money spent by tourists remains in the country where that money was originally spent. He points out that if all the services and facilities in, for example, the Spanish situation had been Spanish owned and operated that country would have retained nearer to 85 per cent of the revenue expended by tourists. There is an enormous difference between 31 and 85 per cent when you are talking in terms of millions, if not billions, of dollars. Australians need to start asking themselves just exactly where the value is. But we will never be able to get an answer for ourselves or from somebody else until the information is collated and collected centrally.

I for one believe that the cost of any increased employment in this area is worth it even if all we do is double the percentage of tourist dollars that remain in this country instead of most of that money flowing out, even if all it does is give our primary producers an even playing field when it comes to beef exports, even if it means only that the price of Australian real estate is still within the reach of the average Australian family. Senator Walsh is working himself into a frenzy over there. I will give him the opportunity to join Senator Stone and Senator Messner in criticising what is after all only a register of what is owned by foreign nationals of Australian property, Australian business, Australian real estate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up briefly a couple of things that Senator Messner said because he seems to be misinformed about the registers of real estate which are kept by the States. There is no register of nationality kept in the States. As Senator Haines indicated earlier, Queensland has recently passed such legislation. I believe it sat on the statute book for some time, but it has recently been gazetted. In no other State at the moment do we have a register of real estate which includes nationality; so the information is simply not available from the States.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator pointed out also that there would be an enormous cost. If, indeed, this information is already being kept by the States it is difficult to see how he can argue that there would be an enormous cost in keeping that information. As I have already indicated, that information has not been kept, so there is a double lack of logic in what he had to say. Moreover, I wonder whether Senator Messner has learned about the way in which computers can transfer quite large amounts of information. If the States did keep information on real estate ownership, including nationality, it would be a relatively simple matter to transfer that to a central register.

Senator Stone started off by criticising Senator Haines by describing her speech as a catalogue of fear. I sat throughout Senator Haines's speech and did not hear anything in any way even heated. Certainly in no sense was anything she had to say a catalogue of fear; it was very calmly and logically argued. What she was pointing out was that there is either a justified or unjustified concern among the Australian population regarding the level of foreign ownership. That is not expressing a fear; it is expressing a matter of fact.

Senator Stone then went on to say that Senator Haines offered no solution. When I initially heard his remark I thought what Senator Haines was offering, of course, was a solution, namely, the establishment of a foreign register, but it became clear then that Senator Stone was talking about the problem of why we have so much foreign ownership. Senator Stone may have information not available to the rest of us-the sort of information that the rest of us would like, namely, some information as to how much foreign ownership there really is. The honourable senator then criticised us in relation to our economic policy, pointing out that the fact of any foreign ownership was itself indicative of a fault in the Australian economy as it is at the moment and that simply establishing a register would not reverse that trend. Of course, that is absolutely true, but he implied there that the Democrats had no other solutions and would simply establish a register and leave it at that.

I would like to point out-and I think Senator Stone would agree with me here-that the majority of foreign indebtedness is not a consequence of Federal Government borrowings. A substantial proportion-I believe somewhere between 60 and 70 per cent-of that foreign indebtedness is private foreign indebtedness, and only some 30 per cent or so is shared between Federal and State governments and government instrumentalities. I am certainly not aware that the average Australian is substantially responsible for that private foreign indebtedness. That has substantially been incurred by, I believe, well-off Australians going overseas, borrowing money to buy what are often Australian assets, and having to pay capital plus interest to those foreign lending institutions. That is where a substantial proportion of our foreign indebtedness arises.

TALK.START.PARA: —It arises from the rotten policies of a government which, basically speaking, you support.
—You vote with them more often than we do.

—The honourable senator votes with them more often than we do, as Senator Haines has just pointed out. On this very issue I suspect he is going to vote with them yet again, and we will be voting on the other side. The Australian Democrats would do a great deal to change that pattern of speculative use of Australian capital, and would change very considerably government policies with regard to growth economics and the wise use of our resources, which would allow us to use our resources far more conservatively.
—Put up windmills and generate wind power.

—I am glad Senator Stone mentioned that. Some 25 per cent of the costs of power stations is borrowed overseas because we do not make heavy generating equipment in this country. A sane policy would allow us to use our electricity a lot more efficiently and avoid that large amount of capital borrowing. Approximately 20 per cent of our foreign indebtedness is related to government instrumentalities such as the State electricity commissions-for example, the Electricity Trust of South Australia. The Democrats would have far more sensible and sane energy policies, not simply devoted to growth for growth's sake, which would avoid a great deal of that foreign indebtedness. That is just one example. I thank Senator Stone for bringing it up.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone then went on to develop a most contorted argument. He used a non sequitur to argue that if we do not know how bad the problem is then we do not need to support the establishment of a register. That seemed to me to be a most peculiar argument. If Australians, by and large, are not concerned about our present level of foreign indebtedness and therefore are not prepared to do anything about it, such as changing the present government, then it would seem to me that they may become concerned about a consequence of that foreign indebtedness, namely, the sale of our real estate to cover that foreign indebtedness. It is therefore useful to establish such a register so that that information will become available to them in a form which will cause them to act. Senator Stone's argument in fact turns around and becomes an argument in favour of the establishment of a foreign register.

I can only conclude by reiterating what Senator Haines said so eloquently, and that is that this is merely a request that we get the information. What we do with that information is further down the track. Information is a sine qua non of the democratic process. We cannot make intelligent, informed, democratic decisions in this very important area unless we have that information. Therefore, it is highly desirable that a register be established and that that information be available to all Australians, not least those who sit in this chamber and pontificate about these questions in total ignorance of the facts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to dispute the remarks that Senator Messner made about the information with regard to foreign ownership of property being readily available in the States. As far as the Western Australian situation is concerned, in September 1987 the then Premier of Western Australia, Mr Brian Burke, made a public announcement that Western Australia did not need a register of foreign ownership. When he was asked how much foreign ownership there was in Western Australia he had to admit that he did not know. In fact, at the present time in Western Australia the National Party in the State Parliament has announced that it is about to introduce legislation requiring a register within the State with regard to foreign ownership. So I do not believe that everybody in the Liberal and National parties in Australia feels the same way on this issue as our Federal colleagues here seem to.

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly support this amendment of the Democrats. We are laying ourselves wide open in a most unfortunate way. I would remind the Senate of an advertisement that appeared in June of last year in the English language newspaper the South China Morning Post, which is published in Hong Kong. It was a very offensive advertisement which stated:
Australia is up for grabs. Invest in your future now.

This was part and parcel of an advertisement advertising land for sale south of Perth in the suburb of Rockingham to people living in South East Asia. I also commend this amendment very heartily to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not able to accept this amendment. If it was to be carried, it would require all foreigners, both corporate and individual, to report each year all the property or shares that they own in Australia. I think it is fairly obvious that that would require an enormous administrative effort, the cost of which would ultimately be lumbered on the Commonwealth taxpayer, public sector costs, and probably something like comparable private sector costs to the companies or individuals which would be required to supply.

SPEECH.PARA: It is aimed principally at rural land. The registers or records of rural land are held, of course, by State governments. It has been mentioned that Queensland has already announced that it intends to establish a foreign owned land register. If all States had such a register in existence, it may well be that it would not require a great deal of cost or effort by the Commonwealth Government, provided the States were willing to cooperate, to establish a central register. However, that is not the position. The Federal Government has no records of the sales of assets from foreign ownership to Australian ownership, be it land or portfolio investment. As I and Senator Messner have said, it would be an extremely costly exercise to establish one.

However, there is some information. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has published surveys on foreign ownership and control of different industry sectors in Australia. I do not think it is a regular survey or publication; it is something that happens from time to time. Some of those have dated, but they are a far more useful guide to the extent of foreign participation than could be obtained from the register proposed by the Democrats.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Haines's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: LANDS ACQUISITION BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:LANDS ACQUISITION (REPEAL AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 November 1988, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I suggest that there be a cognate debate on the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 and the Lands Acquisition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988.
—There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it two pieces of legislation-the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 and the Lands Acquisition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988. These Bills deal with one of the fundamental issues to be faced by any government, namely, the acquisition of private property for public purposes. That is a very important and significant role which any government has to play. The record of Labor governments in terms of dealing with the question of the acquisition of private property is not a particularly spectacular one. Indeed, coming as I do from the State of New South Wales, I am reminded of the activities of the late and unlamented Wran Labor Government in that State, which in 1981 passed the Coal Acquisition Act which allowed the State Government to seize from private individuals without the payment of compensation all of the coal rights which they held and in some cases had held for many years and for several generations.

SPEECH.PARA: The two pieces of legislation now before the chamber are designed to redress both deficiencies and matters of urgency as they relate to the question of land acquisition. I turn first to the question of deficiencies. In 1986 the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence produced a report on the question of land acquisition in New South Wales by the Australian Army. This concerned an attempt by the Australian defence forces to acquire certain land in the western areas of New South Wales. In the course of the Senate Committee inquiry a number of deficiencies in land acquisition procedures were brought to public attention. The Committee says on page xiv of its report that the Western Lands Commissioner, Mr Pearson:

also stated that because the Commonwealth Lands Acquisition Act is not considered a suitable mechanism to provide for the acquisition of leasehold property or the variation of the terms of a leaseholder, the Western Lands Commission would hope that the establishment of the manoeuvre area would be the subject of special legislation.

In other words, at that stage a particular deficiency in regard to the acquisition of particular land in particular circumstances under the Lands Acquisition Act was revealed. The Committee, in its comments on page xvii of the report, says:
Thus the Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government clarify its policy on the compulsory acquisition of land in peacetime for Defence purposes before proceeding further . . .

The Committee was at pains to draw attention to the deficiencies which existed in the then Lands Acquisition Act. The matter is not only one of addressing deficiencies. It is also a matter of addressing a number of urgent or potentially urgent problems, the most important of which is the acquisition of land in order to facilitate the development of some sort of aviation facility at Badgerys Creek in the west of Sydney. You and I, Mr Acting Deputy President, are both very interested in the decision as to exactly what sort of facility will be developed at Badgerys Creek, but neither of us is any the wiser as a result of Government decisions about the development of aviation facilities. I was intrigued to see in the Sunday Telegraph of last Sunday a call by Mr Roger Price, one of the Government's backbenchers in the House of Representatives, to speed up airport development by privatising Badgerys Creek. How all of that is to be achieved at the same time as there is to be acquisition of land by the Commonwealth for its particular purposes I am not altogether sure. The representatives of the Land Acquisition Reform Committee, to which I shall refer later, have made representations to the Government, so far unanswered, asking it exactly what is the status of land to be acquired in the Badgerys Creek area as a result of the decisions made about airport development in that part of NSW.

To give one other example of where the question of Commonwealth lands acquisition legislation is going to be important, I draw attention to the December 1988 report on the very fast train project, and in particular, the document entitled Concept Report Summary in which the proponents of the very fast train project say:

Without government backing for land acquisition, it is likely that the VFT would face costly and protracted negotiations and legal proceedings about acquisition of the route. For this reason it is considered necessary for governments to legislate in support of the land acquisition process.

That is simply another example of why it is necessary to have a modern and coherent Lands Acquisition Act in place for the Commonwealth when it is going to require the compulsory acquisition of currently privately owned land. The Commonwealth has had lands acquisition legislation in place for a considerable period. In fact, the original Lands Acquisition Act was passed in 1905. That Act in turn was based on a United Kingdom statute which dated back to 1845. The current Act, which is essentially the subject of repeal and the enactment of this new piece of legislation, was enacted in 1955. It is clear that problems existed in land acquisition for many years. In 1977 the Government gave a reference to the Law Reform Commission to produce a report entitled Lands Acquisition and Compensation. That report was provided to the Government in 1980 and the work of the commissioner, His Honour Mr Justice Wilcox, as he now is, is something which is to be greatly commended. Mr Justice Wilcox has not only undertaken this inquiry but has been a major adviser to both government and interested parties in the question of land acquisition for more than 10 years. I have already mentioned the Senate inquiry which dealt in part with the problems of land acquisition by the defence forces. That also had the sole of exposing some of the deficiencies in the 1955 legislation.

I also mention the role of that body to which I referred a few moments ago, the Land Acquisition Reform Committee, commonly known as LARC, which over the last few years has done the most extraordinary amount of work in the public domain in dealing with problems of land acquisition. Its Chairman, Mr John Duff, and its Deputy Chairman, Mary Turner, have been quite prodigious in the amount of work they have done, the public meetings they have organised, the seminars and the representations and submissions they have made to successive Commonwealth Ministers in order to try to bring about the most satisfactory piece of legislation possible.

As I said, the Law Reform Commission reported in 1980 and that report was critical of a number of aspects of lands acquisition legislation. During recent years the Commonwealth Parliament has enacted legislation to enable the independent review of administrative decisions which adversely affect individuals. The decision to acquire property, particularly by the use of compulsory process, is a decision which affects, sometimes profoundly, the owner of the property. There is in the current Act no mechanism whereby an owner may require the acquiring authority to justify publicly the need for and choice of his property. When persons' homes are acquired, it can cause significant disruption to the individuals involved. There is currently no legislative provision to ensure that displaced owners can provide for themselves out of their compensation money a suitable alternative home. The Government concedes that it is reasonable that people in those circumstances should be provided practical assistance and recompense for this intangible effect of removal from their home. This is not provided for in the current legislative arrangements which we have.

Another area which is not provided for in current legislation is that of blight. It is not uncommon for government acquisition decisions to be generally known for some years before acquisition takes place. The case of Badgerys Creek is one of the most long running sagas in this regard. People whose property is involved can find themselves in the situation where there is no market for his property because of the Government's intentions, and the Government might not be ready to acquire the land for some years. Under the current Act there is no facility for the owner to compel the Government proposing the acquisition to purchase from him. Inflation can also cause difficulties for owners, particularly if there is a significant lapse of time between acquisition of the property and payment of compensation following final agreement on the amount to be paid. As a result of all of these criticisms, three main recommendations emerged from the Law Reform Commission study: first, that there should be more open procedures in the acquisition process; secondly, that there should be greater public accountability for decisions to acquire property; and thirdly, that there should be more generous statutory provisions for the compensation of persons deprived of their land by the Commonwealth.

This Bill was introduced originally on 25 May 1988, almost a year ago. It was then laid on the table for an extensive period of public discussion. The Land Acquisition Reform Committee commenced a series of public forums in July 1988 to discuss this, in which the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), my New South Wales colleague Senator David Brownhill, a number of other distinguished speakers and I participated and turned our minds to this matter. In October 1988 the Government introduced 34 amendments to the legislation and finally, in order to pick up the time lag which had been exposed over the Badgerys Creek decision, in November 1988 the Government introduced the second piece of legislation with which we are dealing this evening, the Lands Acquisition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill.

The main Bill, the primary piece of legislation that we have before us, arises from the Law Reform Commission report. It specifies an entirely new and comprehensive process that must be followed when the Commonwealth wishes to acquire property. At the start of the process the Bill requires that the Government make a pre-acquisition declaration. This declaration is a statement of intention which is provided to the owner, giving the Government's reason for the acquisition and identifying the owner's rights. At the same time the Bill says that the Government's intention to acquire is to be made public by publication in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and in a local newspaper. Furthermore, the Bill requires that the marketplace be alerted to the Commonwealth's intention by providing that the declaration will be registered on the title of the property and, indeed, that the owner will be required to tell intending purchasers of the Commonwealth's intention.

The Bill requires the Government to complete acquisitions expeditiously. Of course that is something of a joke for the people of Badgerys Creek. Throughout the Bill time limits are identified in which the Commonwealth must act or make decisions. One of the important features of the Bill is that the owner can seek a review of the Government's decision to acquire his property, although-as I shall show later-that is circumscribed in certain areas. For example, the policy decision of the Government which has led to the decision that an acquisition should take place is itself not subject to review.

As I say, the Bill has been through a number of changes as a result of the public discussion to which I referred earlier. For example, under clause 46 of the original Bill, where there was to be a disallowance of an acquisition of an interest in land in a public park, the legislation provided that either House of the Parliament might, within 28 days after a copy of the declaration had been laid before it, pass a resolution disallowing the acquisition. When the Bill was rewritten, because of the considerable time delays which had been identified in the procedures laid down by the Government, we found that that 28 days had been cut back to seven sitting days. That is a welcome change in the legislation and one which has resulted from the extensive public discussions to which I previously referred.

The Bill was subject to a large number of amendments introduced by the Government. Those amendments covered quite a number of issues, including the right of landowners to seek review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of compensation offers; a new statutory list of compensation entitlements; the payment of a householder's solatium, that is to say a payment in cases where the principal place of residence is acquired by the Commonwealth; optional compensation on the basis of the cost of equivalent reinstatement where there is no market for the property and a bona fide intention to re-establish. There were a number of other amendments: for example, a statutory requirement to make 90 per cent advances of compensation offered, some changes to time limits and some changes in the power to approve compulsory acquisition to devolve from the Governor-General to the Minister for Administrative Services.

We also have before us the Lands Acquisition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill, which is designed to extend to acquisitions which were already in train for land at Badgerys Creek before the introduction of this new package of legislation the more generous provisions of this package of legislation, as if the acquisition of land at Badgerys Creek had commenced under the regime which is in fact now the subject of the legislation before us. In other words, where acquisition was already in train but had not been completed, those acquisitions will be completed on the basis of the 1988 legislation rather than on the basis of the 1955 legislation, and that is a more generous regime than was otherwise provided for.

I turn finally to the question of deficiencies which the Opposition sees as still remaining in this piece of legislation. I should indicate that although we will move one amendment in relation to certain mining matters, it is our intention to support this legislation when it comes to a vote. The first of the deficiencies which we identify is in relation to certain ambiguities in terms of mining matters; in other words, whether existing State mining regimes are in any way affected or displaced by the operation of the new Commonwealth legislation. The 1955 Act guaranteed compatibility with State practices and procedures in relation to mining activity. We are concerned that the 1988 legislation does not adequately repeat that guarantee. We will therefore move an amendment to ensure that it does.

The second deficiency is that the legislation appears to discriminate specifically against the position of the Northern Territory. My colleague Senator Tambling, always assiduous in his representation of the rights of the Northern Territory, has drawn attention to the fact that the provisions of this Bill seem to imply that the Northern Territory is not treated in the same way as the States. For example, the public purpose for which land may be acquired in a territory means any purpose in relation to the territory, but in relation to States is limited to Federal purposes. In other words, we have a situation in which the acquisition of land in the Northern Territory does not take place on entirely the same footing as the acquisition of land in the States. This is a situation which we believe the Government has wrongly addressed. We believe that the Government should undertake some review of this matter to ensure that the Commonwealth's power to acquire land in the Northern Territory should be limited to public purposes other than those which might relate to a transferred matter under the Northern Territory self-government regulations.

The third point to which I draw attention is the complaint which has been made by the Land Acquisition Reform Committee that there remain a number of areas in which the question of suitability of the Government's proposals have yet to be addressed in relation to the question of Badgerys Creek. Rather than go into that in great detail at the moment, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter which was shown to the Minister in the chamber when this matter was about to come on for debate. The letter is from the Deputy Chairman of the Land Acquisition Reform Committee and details those objections and problems.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
THE LAND ACQUISITION REFORM COMMITTEE
CHAIRMAN: John Duff-(02) 651 2151.
P.O. Box 4, DURAL. 2158.
DEPUTY CHAIRMAN: Mary Turner-
9th November 1988
The Hon. Stewart West, M.P.,
Minister for Administrative Services,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA. A.C.T. 2600.
My Dear Minister,
LANDS ACQUISITION BILL 1988

Our Committee was pleased to see the amended Bill returned to Parliament so promptly and to note that the amendments addressed many of the points raised in our LANDWATCH Forum last July. We greatly appreciate your personal commitment to seeking and taking account of public comment on the draft Bill, and agree with you that the new Act, assured of support by the Opposition in the Senate, will be a great advance on the old legislation in its progress towards the constitutional requirement for `just terms' of land acquisition by the Commonwealth, despite its accepted avoidance of the contentious issue of injurious affection.

However, although we concur with the Opposition's view that the amended Bill should proceed to enactment and proclamation as soon as possible so that its many improved provisions may be speedily enshrined in law, we are deeply disappointed that the most serious flaw in the old Act remains in the new, i.e. the ability of any Government to withhold the process which sets the Act in motion during its pleasure, however long that may be.

The injustice of this is vividly illustrated by the situation which has obtained at Badgery's Creek since the then Minister for Aviation made his public announcement on 17th February 1986, followed by letters from him to the (clearly identified) affected landholders dated 24th February 1986 and supported by letters to the same persons from the then Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services dated 25th February 1986.

To contend that these acts-each of them separately, let alone all of them together-do not constitute ``a government or ministerial announcement [of intention to acquire]'' and hence, by the plainest English definition, a ``pre-acquisition declaration'', is in our view self-evidently insupportable.

With respect, we believe that the views of the Law Reform Commission on this point have been misinterpreted. Its Report alludes to the ``need for a system of review of a tentative decision to acquire land'' (see para. 111), and states (in para. 140) that ``any effective review of the decision to acquire depends upon information as to the purpose for which the land is intended to be used.'' The same paragraph goes on to suggest that ``an appropriate procedure would be to require the Minister to make a declaration that a specified area of land appears to him to be suitable for use . . . by the Commonwealth and that he is considering acquisition for a specified public purpose.''

The emphasis on the above words is ours, and we submit that the tentative nature of their meaning indicates that the Law Reform Commission envisaged the Minister's declaration (with its consequent machinery for ``effective review'') taking place early in the progress towards acquisition, not-as seems to be its position in the minds of your Department's bureaucrats-as the penultimate step to completion after Government policy has hardened into a final decision and even the finance has been allocated.

Although the new Bill, as amended, in Clause 22-Declaration that land is suitable for acquisition, uses the phrases ``is considering the acquisition'' and ``appears to be suitable'', your supporting speech (Hansard 20/10/88 p. 2054) clearly indicates that the declaration is not to be made early, to enable the Minister's proposal to be tested and ``effectively reviewed'' as the Law Reform Commission recommends, but indeed as the penultimate step to acquisition. In effect the new process, ``pre-acquisition declaration'', becomes just another name for the old ``notice to treat'', and while ever this flaw is perpetuated the many excellent provisions in the new Bill which come into play after the ``pre-acquisition declaration'' has been made remain out of the reach of affected landholders, who will be as unjustly victimised as ever up to this point in the process; witness the landholders at Badgery's Creek.

Other sections of the Law Reform Commission's Report reinforce the concern underlying its thinking, particularly its acknowledgment that undue delay on the part of the Government causes blight, which causes loss, and that such loss should be compensable. We refer you particularly to paras. 157 to 160.

We also refer you to para. 182, in which the Commission discusses the limitations of Section 9 (6) of the old Act, and submit that as currently conceived your ``pre-acquisition declaration'' provisions contain the same limitation:-

``. . . The second major limitation of S.9 (6) is that it requires a formal notice to treat. In practice a proposal for a public work will be common knowledge long before any formal notice to treat. A `blight' may then descend on the land which will only be removed by an announcement of abandonment of the work or actual acquisition. Where the proposal is abandoned between its original mooting and a formal notice to treat no claim can arise under S.9 (6). Yet in such a case damage may be suffered.''

Discussing the period within which such damage should be indemnified by the Commonwealth para. 188 says:-``. . . If . . . there has been a formal government proposal for the use of the land involving acquisition [such as that published on 17th February 1986 in the case of Badgery's Creek] it is unreasonable that losses caused by such a proposal should be uncompensated simply because no formal acquisition step has been taken . . . The rule should be that the compensable period commences with the date of the Minister's declaration of a proposal to acquire for a project and that it should terminate at the date of actual or deemed abandonment. The period, for compensation purposes, will coincide with the period within which there is a restriction on sale or development of the land [a period which has existed, in the case of Badgery's Creek, since 17th February 1986].

Discussing an appropriate formula for such compensation the Report (in para. 243) says:- ``. . . Specific provision needs to be made for this and it is appropriate to include it as part of the disturbance factor. This may be done by extending the present concept of disturbance, consequent upon acquisition, to include disturbance consequent upon the making of the declaration. The event should be the `making' of the instrument rather than service upon the owner to cover the possibility of the declaration not being served but, nonetheless, coming to the knowledge of the owner [as it did to owners at Badgery's Creek in February 1986] and thus inhibiting development by him of the land.'' (The emphasis is ours.)

In pressing the importance of triggering the Act earlier in the process of proposal and review, we would point out that the Law Reform Commission's recommendations were made nine years ago, and the intervening period has produced not only examples and experience of acquisition proposals which have enabled more precise definition of deficiencies and injustices, but a much wider public awareness of acquisition issues and a more sensitive public perception of Government's responsibility to deal justly with individuals who may be called upon to make sacrifices for the public good.

We would also emphasise another point which was made by our Chairman, John Duff, at the forum; that although the perceived cost of prompt acquisition seems to be the most potent factor inhibiting Government action on this score, the cost of the actual land on which a project is to be sited may well be a very small fraction of the total cost of the project, a fraction which to our Committee it seems worth spending in the interests of justice to innocent parties who are otherwise sorely victimised.

We are encouraged by your declared commitment to keep the workings of the new Act under review; but we must reiterate our belief that the flaw we have discussed above is a crippling one that demands prompt attention if the new Act is to fulfil the hopes we all had of it.

In conclusion we should like to add our weight to the Opposition's call for the Government to establish forthwith a task force to examine the remaining complex issue which was deliberately excluded from consideration in framing the new legislation as it is now presented-the matter of injurious affection. We fully support the need-which you have yourself acknowledged-to examine this very complex and contentious question as early and as thoroughly as possible, with the object of framing additional legislation to relieve some at least of its severest effects on people who fall victim to it.

We have noted, in this connection, the reference in your speech to the House on 20th October last (Hansard p. 2055):- ``. . . I will be proposing an amendment to the Bill after full consultation with the Opposition spokesman and with organisations such as the Land Acquisition Reform Committee''. We would greatly appreciate some clarification and amplification of the direction of your thinking that lies behind this statement.
Yours sincerely,
Deputy Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —The fourth matter about which I have some concern relates to the acquisition of land in park areas. The Bill provides for the Minister to have power to acquire land in public parks. The compulsory process must be used but can only be used where a specified set of conditions has been met. These are that the State or territory concerned must agree to the acquisition and an inquiry is to be held under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. Both Houses of Parliament may veto the requirement for an inquiry. If that occurs, any other level of environmental investigation required under the Act must still be undertaken. Furthermore, if the land falls within a National Estate area or World Heritage area an environmental impact statement is mandatory. The Minister must table a notice of the acquisition in both Houses of Parliament and either House may declare the acquisition null and void. I have some concerns about the complexity of that matter which I will refer to when we address this matter in the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The fifth matter which is of concern is the question of the solatium which I mentioned previously, which was introduced in the subsequent amendments. The solatium is set in the legislation at a figure of $10,000, to be adjusted according to the consumer price index, whereas there is some case for claiming that it should be set at a percentage of the value of the property. Indeed, under the legislation which is operative in Victoria a fixed 10 per cent of the acquisition price is made as a solace payment. This provides the solatium rather than the fixed figure provided for in the Commonwealth legislation.

The sixth matter of concern is the question of capital gains taxes. Undoubtedly, Senator Walsh would be able to explain this anomaly. The taxation Act, and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) passed by the Senate on 2 March, impact on the taxation liability for those whose land or other property is compulsorily acquired by State or Commonwealth governments. The taxation Act allows for capital gains tax roll-over relief if the moneys gained as compensation for acquisition of land are used to purchase a replacement asset of a nature similar to the asset acquired by the Government. It does not permit roll-over relief if moneys are spent on a dissimilar asset; for example, compulsory sale of a farm or part thereof and purchase of a shop, factory or investment property.

Clause 44 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill permits capital gains tax roll-over relief for sales of property concluded by negotiation between the owner and the Government where they are part of the lands acquisition process. For capital gains roll-over relief to be granted for a negotiated sale, the Government must advise the vendor that, failing a satisfactory negotiated sale, the land or property will be acquired compulsorily. Given the difficulties in finding a similar replacement asset such as a farm of similar type or value, it is highly likely that the land and property owners will face, as a result of compulsory sale of property and difficulty in purchasing a replacement asset, a capital gains tax. Therefore, the taxation effect of compulsory acquisition of land or property provided for in the Lands Acquisition Bill creates a conflict with the provisions in clause 55 of the taxation legislation that any cost or expenses incurred by the landowner as a result of acquisition of land would be compensated by government.

Importantly, the cost of a capital gains tax needs to be explicitly included in the compensation package. At present the Bill, unlike the taxation Act, does not link compensation of costs plus expenses to the condition of purchasing a replacement property. Indeed, the National Farmers Federation has recommended that the Lands Acquisition Bill contain reference to the need for capital gains tax roll-over relief where a land-holder does not purchase a similar replacement property following negotiated or compulsory acquisition of property by government, either by direct reference within the Bill or, I think more appropriately, by an amendment to the definition of `replaced asset' currently in taxation legislation.

The final point which I make by way of criticism of the Bill in its current form is that it does not really address the question of blight. I do not know that there is any really adequate legislative provision which can address that problem. I believe the legislation has simply shied away from dealing with questions of blight. This is a matter which is now one of very considerable moment to people in Badgerys Creek. They have, after all, expected the acquisition of land. After all, they had Senator Evans's assurance that there was not going to be a third runway at Kingsford-Smith. Therefore, they expected the development of a particular type of international airport out at Badgerys Creek. They had Senator Evans's worthy assurance that there was never going to be a third runway at Kingsford-Smith. It turned out to be like so many other worthy assurances that were given by senior figures in the Government that this was never going to take place. Of course, now that it has taken place and Senator Evans has decided that his assurances do not require him to throw himself upon the same sword that Mr Punch has thrown himself upon over this particular matter, the people at Badgerys Creek find that they are no longer as confident about the nature of the acquisition which will take place or the time framework in which the acquisition will take place. They are the primary sufferers at the moment from the effects of the blight which has been caused over the sale of their property by the Government's backing and filling on the question of Sydney's airport needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your policy?

—Our policy has always been perfectly clear on this matter. We support the development of the third runway at Kingsford-Smith. There has never been any doubt about that matter. The legislation substantially improves the regime for public acquisition of private property. It makes a considerable advance on the legislation which started off in the United Kingdom in 1845, was translated into Commonwealth legislation in 1905, was codified in a major Bill in 1955, and was then the subject of a Law Reform Commission inquiry which commenced in 1977, concluded in 1980 and produced a Bill which originally saw the light of day in May last year, which was amended in October last year by the Government with the introduction of 34 amendments and which was added to in November last year by the bringing forward of another piece of legislation, the second Bill before the chamber at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: We support the legislation. We believe that those seven deficiencies which I have outlined in relation to the Bill need to be addressed. We will be expecting the Government to respond at the conclusion of this debate to each of those particular matters, namely the ambiguity of the mining regime, the discrimination against the Northern Territory, the particular concerns of the Land Acquisition Reform Committee in the letter which I have tabled, the complexity of the parks regime, the payment of the solatium, the effect of the capital gains tax, and the provisions dealing with blight. We will have something to say about some of those matters at the committee stage of the Bill. Other than that, I have pleasure in indicating the Opposition's support for the Bill in principle. We wish it a speedy passage after the very long and very tortuous time that it has spent in both chambers. It is an important piece of legislation which deserves to be passed and put into effect as quickly as possible.
