SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Lands Acquisition Bill, which relates to Commonwealth acquisition of land, as Senator Puplick has pointed out several times in his dissertation, has had a long gestation period under both the present and previous governments. The Australian Democrats do not intend to add too much to that gestation period, which might come as some relief to the chamber tonight. The need for reform in this area has been long recognised. The inadequacies of the existing legislation prompted the Fraser Government to request the Law Reform Commission to examine the legislation and to concentrate on the rights of people whose land was compulsorily acquired by the Commonwealth and to report on the question of compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Law Reform Commission report was tabled in April 1980 and recommendations to improve the legislation were made. Since then, there has been extensive community consultation about the report and this Bill, as pointed out by Senator Puplick, has emerged from that. It is worth observing that the process has been rather slow and, while the reforms are welcome, the Government has been very tardy in recognising that and in introducing them. Some concerns expressed since the original Bill was introduced last year have been picked up in extensive amendments brought in by the Government. I refer particularly to representations made at that time by the Land Acquisition Reform Committee in New South Wales.

The original Australian Law Reform Commission recommendations urged more open procedures in the acquisition process, greater public accountability for decisions to acquire property, and more generous provisions for compensation for persons deprived of their land by the Commonwealth. The Bill before us has largely picked up those objectives and certainly provides more adequately for the rights of property owners whose land might be acquired. One important aspect of this is that persons threatened with compulsory acquisition of their land should have the opportunity to challenge the fairness of that decision before an independent tribunal. The Bill provides for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) based upon such matters as public purpose, suitability, effect on land owners, environmental effect and alternative means of achieving the public purpose. There is no provision for appeal where the land is `essential for the implementation of policy', but in such circumstances an owner can always appeal to the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The Bill picks up all the Law Reform Commission recommendations on changed acquisition procedures, including the gazettal of acquisitions, and provides for former owners to remain in possession for six months after acquisition. More generous compensation will be available, and detailed guidelines are included to ensure its adequacy.

One important issue which has not been addressed adequately in the Bill relates to injurious affection, that is, compensation for those whose land is adversely affected by the acquisition by the Commonwealth of adjacent land. This is a very complex area, legally and administratively, but it is a serious problem which needs to be addressed. Certainly the Government proposes to retain that part of the existing Act which takes some account of injurious affection but, in the view of the Democrats, it does not go far enough.

The Australian Law Reform Commission has pointed out that an adjacent owner may suffer an injury equal to that of the neighbour whose land is acquired, but he is not entitled to any statutory compensation. Obviously, this is both anomalous and unjust, and the Democrats would welcome some comment from the responsible Minister concerning the Government's intentions on this matter. We are also aware that the Government moved some way on this issue in the amendments it made to this Bill after it was first introduced.

Senator Puplick has outlined in considerable detail some other concerns which remain about the legislation, in particular concerns expressed by the National Farmers Federation, which I will not reiterate except to say that the Democrats acknowledge those concerns and take this opportunity to draw them to the Government's attention. In essence, the first concern is the likelihood that all property owners will face capital gains tax as a result of compulsory acquisition of land or property due to that conflict between the spirit of the Bill and of the tax Act. The second concern is that a solace payment, a solatium, is applicable only to the loss of a home and not to the loss of land. As the National Farmers Federation points out, farming families, particularly those which have worked on properties for generations, have an emotional attachment to the land which is indistinguishable from an attachment to a home. This is a concern. As the National Farmers Federation points out, it will be a complex process and one which needs to be reconciled, particularly as major projects such as the very fast train will affect many landowners in the course of their development. That is something which the Government and, indeed, all of us need to bear in mind in developing further this area of legislation.

The Land Acquisition Reform Commission in New South Wales has outstanding concerns, most of which Senator Puplick has already referred to. In addition to those matters, I refer to a question from that Committee which was addressed to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in March of this year. The Committee is concerned that some defence area control legislation has been foreshadowed. It is anxious that further developments should take place on that issue, which is of particular concern to it. However, the Committee has yet to hear again from the Minister following the consultations that were made in July of last year.

Overall, this Bill provides a much better framework within which the acquisition of land by the Commonwealth will operate. The rights of landowners are much better protected. The Australian Democrats can only regret that the process has taken so long. As I said, we do not intend to lengthen that process. We will be supporting the legislation. We ask that the Government bear in mind the anomalies which have been pointed out and the concerns that we have brought before the Senate in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 and the Lands Acquisition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988 have been hanging around for quite some time. It is rather sad that legislation of such significance should have been pushed off the agenda of this place time after time. Little thought has been given to the handful of people who have worked for years to draft the legislation for the Parliament or to the dozens of people who have established committees, held conferences, written letters to members of parliament and lobbied continuously for improvements to existing and outdated legislation. Hundreds of people have already seen their own land taken or placed under threat. Last, but not least, little thought has been given to the thousands of people who have signed petitions on this subject, many of which I have tabled in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I deal with the substance of the legislation before us, I would like to record and applaud the work that the Land Acquisition Reform Committee (LARC) has undertaken over a number of years to bring about changes to the legal process. The Committee members have been tireless workers for their cause. They have written many letters to me and to other members of parliament. Their correspondence has always been full of fact, with well argued opinions. Very obviously, they have looked more closely at the finer points in the legislation than many members of parliament do. I believe that two people who ought to be commended for their work are Mrs Mary Turner, from Orange, New South Wales, who is the Deputy Chairman of LARC, and Mr John Duff, the Chairman of LARC. They must be commended for their dedication and absolute belief in what they have been doing. This legislation is for the most part the result of their lobbying efforts and I commend them for that.

This legislation has a long history. In fact, it was the previous coalition Government that first sent a reference to the Law Reform Commission requesting a review of the Lands Acquisition Act 1955. The Commission was asked particularly to make comments on the rights of private citizens whose land was compulsorily acquired by the Commonwealth. The Law Reform Commission made a report in 1980, and it has taken this long for appropriate legislation to come before the Parliament, although I know that successive governments have had extensive consultation with various groups and individuals during that time. However, despite the obvious need for this legislation, the Government has been disturbingly slothful in addressing itself to the problem. Even when it finally got the Lands Acquisition Bill into a draft and then a final form, it found it necessary to introduce a secondary Bill, the Lands Acquisition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill, to correct the anomalies. In my view, the Government still has not got it right, but we should all be grateful for small mercies and glad that at least some form of legislation is to be put in place. Mr Uren in the House of Representatives has played a big part in the formulation of the Bill.

It is very likely that prior to the 1984 Army land grab fiasco there were other cases where compensation for compulsorily acquired land was unjust or inappropriate. Given that the Commonwealth Government acquires an average of 2,000 properties annually, it is obvious that not all are required without acrimony. Regrettably, little notice is taken of odd instances. It required a seige in the Orange-Bathurst area and the Cobar area to bring the need for legislation into the spotlight. It was only then that the people fully realised the inadequacies and the injustices that the Act contained. I do not need to delay the Senate with a long and protracted history of the aborted attempt by the Department of Defence to evict landholders in the Bathurst-Orange and Cobar areas of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the role of their local Labor member in that.
—The honourable member for Calare?
—Yes.

—What a great part he played! He did not look after the people whose privately owned freehold land was under threat of being taken away from them. However, LARC evolved from resident action which took place over more than four years. It was realised that the injustice that was occurring at that time could recur anywhere because the legislation was inadequate, just as the Law Reform Commission had found in 1980 and just as the 1977 reference to it suggested. The Law Reform Commission, in its 1980 report, recommended new legislation covering both land acquisition and injurious affection which incorporated revised acquisition powers and new pre-acquisition procedures. As I said, the Commission reported in 1980. Only now, nearly nine years later, the Government has finally brought the legislation to the Parliament. The Senate now has an opportunity to debate the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The central feature of this legislation is that a person threatened with compulsory acquisition of his land should be provided with an opportunity to challenge this decision before an independent tribunal-taking it before an umpire, as it were. The legislation provides several grounds on which an affected land-holder can appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the independent arbiter. These grounds include the purpose for which the Government wishes to acquire the land; the extent to which that use is in the public interest; the suitability of the land; the effect of acquisition on land owners; the environmental effect; and alternatives for the proposed public purpose. However, the Bill makes some exceptions, with land required for essential purposes being exempt from that procedure.

The Commission's recommendations concerning pre-acquisition, which are already incorporated in the Bill, include improved information to the owners whose land is to be acquired-I might add that the position could not be any worse than previously when people read about proposals in the newspaper or heard about them on radio-an ability for people who have a vested interest in the land in question other than the owner to appeal against the Government's decision; and a statutory deadline for acquisition of land. These are all improvements.

The Bill also takes into account the Commission's advice on changed acquisition procedures, including the gazettal of acquisitions, and provides for former owners to remain in possession for six months after acquisition. This will alleviate disruption and help assist in relocation once compensation has been paid. The Bill accepts the Law Reform Commission's recommendation that a home owner should not receive less than the cost of a reasonably equivalent dwelling. Too often in the past, legal loopholes have allowed governments to pay amounts which were insufficient to enable a person to be relocated satisfactorily.

The legislation has already received the support of the Opposition in the House of Representatives. It will also receive the support of the Liberal and National parties here in this place. However, I cannot help wondering just how committed the Government will be when the time comes for it to put into practice the sentiments this Bill embodies; that is, that landholders' rights are protected and that the Government is committed to ensuring a fair go.

I was very involved with the people who, for so long, were caught up in the Army land grab. I saw what it did to families, to marriages and to people's health. I saw farms go downhill either because the farmers were out learning how to become lobbyists in order to save their farms or because they had given up. We all know how wool prices have shot away in the past year or so. I wonder how much income the people in the Bathurst-Orange area lost because over the four-year period, while they were away fighting the Government, they did not build up or maintain their flocks. There was no apology from the Government then and there has been neither compensation nor an apology since. Nor has there been an apology from the newest addition to the Hawke Labor Ministry, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), Minister for Defence Science and Personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —And, ironically, in a defence role.
—That is right.
—I wonder what the people of Orange can look forward to now.

—We will have to wait and see. I believe I can be pardoned for being cynical about the sincerity of this Government in its enactment of this legislation. Of course, those opposite can demonstrate their sincerity very quickly but I doubt that they will. In fact, to date they have shown they have learnt nothing from the Orange-Bathurst fiasco. I refer to the Badgerys Creek acquisitions. Having completely bungled the Bathurst-Orange deal, we now see a similar mess arising in connection with the Badgerys Creek saga. The Federal Government's handling of the Badgerys Creek saga is a massive con of this Parliament and of the Australian people. For months the Opposition has been pushing the Government to come clean on Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. We have said there are problems. These arguments have been supported by airline pilots, who use the airport every day, and by air traffic controllers, who are resigning in record numbers because of work pressure caused by inadequate facilities and overcrowded runways. I could go on but I would run out of time, and it has all be said before.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has sat on the other side of the chamber oblivious to all this criticism, stalling on making a public announcement about anything to do with airports. A succession of Ministers has told us that Badgerys Creek could be up and running in four to six years. Even Senator Richardson told us this in this chamber recently. Now, of course, the Government has decided to go ahead with the third runway at Mascot. I commend it for that but it will take a long while for the environmental study, which should be hurried up. I ask this Government: How, in four years, will it build an airport at Badgerys Creek that will take 747 planes when it has literally to move a mountain to get the distance? What about the water and power for the area? Is it not a fact that Prospect County Council has not so much as a formal plan for providing any services as yet? What of the landholders? That is what this Bill is all about. The Government has already told some of these landholders that it cannot afford to pay out this year. If the Government cannot afford to pay out the small landholders, how can it afford the dairy, the winery and the entertainment centre businesses? Given that its valuers have admitted that they have no idea what valuations to put on these two large businesses, how can the Government say the airport could be finished by 1993? It will take the Government that long just to sort out in court the arguments that are amassing in that area. What about the people living in the Liverpool and Wollondilly shires who have been prevented for some time from making any extensions to their houses or developing their businesses? How long are they to be kept on a string? Senator Michael Baume knows a lot about this. He has been fighting to help those people in that area.

I suggest to the Ministers concerned that, before they come into this chamber and try to do a snow job on us, the media and the people in Australia, they take a visit to the Badgerys Creek area. There have been no plans to reroute the main road-the main northern road. That road provides the major link between western Sydney and the Hume Highway. Up to 1,000 semitrailers a day use that road. Where will the Government move them? And when the airport is constructed, how will all that increased traffic be directed? When will it tell the people living along that road that they will have to move? To date the Government has not done this. Badgerys Creek is another saga in dishonesty, administrative bungling and political incompetence, and it must be exposed as such.

The Orange-Bathurst disaster was an outrage-a vicious soul destroying outrage-and yet, less than three years later, the Government is again doing the same thing to average Australian families. How does it think it can get away with it? Honourable senators opposite cannot come into this chamber and lie their way through Question Time, claiming that all the environmental impact studies have been done when they have not, and pretend that ordinary Australians do not matter when political expediency is at stake.

There are 243 affected landholders in the Badgerys Creek area. Some of them are residents, some have small rural holdings, while others conduct a variety of businesses, from service industries to wineries and wool sheds. Each of these landholders was assured the Federal Government would purchase their properties when they decided to sell and that either Government or private valuers could be used. But, after that commitment was given, the Government found itself short of cash, so it froze the deal. As at the end of October last year, only 108 properties had been acquired.

The LARC group is also concerned about what is happening to the people of Badgerys Creek. It considers the most anomalous flaw in the old Act is continued through to the new; that is, the ability of any government to withhold the process which sets the Act in motion for any period it so chooses. That is what is happening at Badgerys Creek now. That is what happened to the people in the Bathurst-Orange district. So, only two years after the public relations disaster in Bathurst, the Government repeats its mistakes. Once again it puts people on the backburner. Once again we have families waiting to move and businessmen not knowing when they have to relocate their operations. Is it any wonder that I do not trust the Government? Is it any wonder that people, particularly those who have been involved in land acquisitions with the Federal Government, are cynical, distrusting and fed up?

Of course, New South Wales people have further reasons to distrust the Labor Party. They remember only too well the legacy of the Wran years when, as my colleague Wal Fife so appropriately put it, the `Wran piracy' stripped thousands of New South Wales companies and individuals of their private coal rights under compulsory acquisition and offered compensation which was less than one third of the coal royalty rate collected by the State. It is only now that the Greiner-Murray Government is in power that this appalling travesty has been righted.

Another area in which I consider the existing legislation to be deficient, and which this new Bill fails to address, is injurious affection. This applies to land that is not the subject of the acquisition but perhaps located adjacent or near to the area acquired. The Government has said it will retain section 23 (1) (c) of the old Act, which takes some account of injurious affection. But it is not sufficiently extensive. In respect of solatium, a flat rate has been determined so that no discretion is given for exceptional circumstances. There is no consideration for interest on unpaid compensation. This is a legislative and administrative minefield. I believe it is important that work be done in an attempt to produce some sort of working formula or guideline that can be used to bring about justice to people that, up until now, have been denied it.

In conclusion, let me say that I am pleased that after so long we are finally getting some sort of words put into place; that after so much work and lobbying by groups such as LARC, their efforts finally are being rewarded. The Bill is not perfect. A number of areas need improvement. I have mentioned some and other areas were covered by my colleagues. But it is important that there are no further delays to this legislation. We must be grateful that this Government has actually done something after so many promises and after so much procrastination. In a good, hopeful spirit, I think we are thankful for mercies, however small they are. I look forward to the time when those who for so long have been adversely affected and who are suffering at present because of compulsory acquisition of their land by the Federal Government will be compensated fairly and swiftly. It is, after all, the very least that a responsible government ought to do, although I could not say that this is a responsible government in respect of anything to do with land acquisition. I commend the Bill to the Senate and I support the words of Senator Puplick in leading this debate for the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Lands Acquisition Act is not controversial. I think that is evident from the contributions of those who have already addressed the issue in this debate. It is also good legislation. I understand that the Opposition intends to seek some amendment, but the general thrust of its argument is that the legislation is not controversial and is good. In the circumstances of this very important piece of legislation coming before and being passed by Parliament, it would be ungracious not to acknowledge the part played by the Australian Law Reform Commission. The Commission has served this Parliament and the people of Australia well, and it seems only appropriate that in this debate we acknowledge its part in bringing this legislation forth-giving birth to it, as it were-and now, hopefully, listening or watching as the process is completed and it becomes law. The other person who should be acknowledged is the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Stewart West.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation has taken almost a decade to come before Parliament from the time the Law Reform Commission first wrote its report. That is partly due to the careful way the Minister has gone about giving everybody who was affected an opportunity to say something about it. That was made clear in the second reading speech, from which I quote:

Submissions were made by a number of groups including the Australian Institute of Valuers and Land Administrators, the National Farmers Federation, the Northern Territory and Western Australian Chambers of Mining, the Australian Mining Industry Council and the Land Acquisition Reform Committee. The latter convened a two-day symposium in Sydney to discuss the Bill which was attended by the Opposition, the judiciary and the Government.

The Minister has made amendments that were proper and has made them readily. He has brought this Bill forth on the basis of what the Law Reform Commission recommended and he has done so in a very considered and conciliatory fashion. Through the operation of the Commission and the Minister, this legislation has come before this chamber and has been, I think it is fair to say, enthusiastically received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note from the Lands Acquisition and Compensation report of the Law Reform Commission that the instruction to the Commission to undertake its inquiry was actually issued by the then Attorney-General on 7 July 1977. It has taken that long for this legislation to come before the Parliament. The Law Reform Commission's report No. 14 opens with the sentence:

SPEECH.PARA: Each year the Commonwealth acquires an average of 2000 properties.

That is 2,000 people, companies, families or whatever involuntarily pass up their property at the request of the Commonwealth for various Commonwealth works. In many cases settlement is reached between the Government and the owners and, of course, there are many cases that require further negotiations and, regrettably, they often get to the courts.

I wish to speak in this debate for two reasons: firstly, there is one point that I wish to make and, secondly, I believe at this juncture I am still the only member of the Australian Institute of Valuers in this Parliament. I have been a member of that august body since 1955, and I am even wearing my valuer's tie tonight, which is most appropriate for this occasion. I acknowledge that the Government must have powers to make property acquisitions. There are, of course, public purposes that have to be fulfilled, and so acquisition is necessary. However, the clear problem that I have always found is that so often legislation seems to prevent the valuers of both sides of the argument getting together for an agreed settlement. Without the constraints of artificial barriers it would have been much easier. Of course, valuers who are worth their ticket need not be told how to assess a loss. That is all part of the profession, and legislation is not required to lay down to valuers how they should do it.

The other qualification is that it is still not accepted that, where it is necessary to acquire property for a community purpose, it is the community that must be prepared to pay, and pay appropriately. This is where the differences usually arise. Legislation that limits compensation or removes items where there is a loss of value, or property, to the disadvantage of the owners is simply not adequate under these circumstances. This, of course, is the point I wish to make particularly. This was all part of this Government's humbug in the referendum question of 1988. It required the States to pay fair and just compensation when, of course, it does not pay it itself and has no intention of doing so.

The whole purpose of this legislation is to reduce or remove the rights of owners-nothing more, nothing less. I repeat: any legislation dealing with land acquisition is specifically designed to avoid paying normal common law entitlement to owners dispossessed or injuriously affected by government-nothing more, nothing less; that is the only reason. How can legislation be fair and just when there are restrictions on appeals, when exceptions are made to allow the Government to circumvent the rules, when there are non-reviewable decisions, when properties under threat of acquisition can be blighted for years, when interest on settlements is fixed without reference to the current rates, when solatium payment is a fixed sum irrespective of whether it is too much or too little, when injurious affection-that is the term given to damage to property caused by the actions of, in this case, this Government-is specifically excluded even if it bankrupts property owners, and when it is specifically recommended as being essential by the Law Reform Commission, to which Senator Cooney referred? I believe that in this regard the Victorian legislation is important. As far as solatium is concerned, section 44 of the Land Acquisition and Compensation Act 1986 says:

The amount of compensation may be increased by such amount, not exceeding 10% of the market value of the land, by way of solatium as is reasonable to compensate the claimant for tangible and non-pecuniary disadvantages resulting from the acquisition.

That allows any reasonable valuer quite an amount of latitude, and I certainly suggest that such a provision should have been included in this legislation also. In some of these issues there were precedents that could have been followed, but they were not.

As far as interest payments are concerned, why could we not have had a clause that for instance, set the long term bond rate applicable at the date for the notification of acquisition as being a reasonable amount? There would be no argument. There would have been reasonable justice. In the Victorian Land Acquisition and Compensation Act 1986-sections 52 and 55-there is again such provision. Section 52 of that legislation says:
(1) The Governor in Council may from time to time, by Order published in the Government Gazette, determine the rate of interest to be paid in respect of unpaid compensation under this Act.
(2) The rate of interest determined by the Governor in Council must not exceed the rate for the time being fixed under section 2 of the Penalty Interest Rates Act 1983.
That is a very fair authority. Section 55 of that same Act says:

. . . if the Authority fails to pay any amount of compensation which it has agreed to pay or which has been awarded under this Act within 30 days of the date of that agreement or award, the interest payable on that amount is five per centum per annum higher than the rate of interest for the time being determined under section 52.

That is, I believe, absolutely essential. Too often have I seen dispossessed owners strung out by governments that have not paid. There have been many criticisms raised. I have had a lot of letters from all sorts of areas as to sections in the Bill. I am pleased that the Government has taken some action to make some of them right but I am sorry that it did not go a bit further to really provide justice for the people who are the subject of this legislation.

However, I fully support the Opposition amendment foreshadowed by Senator Puplick. I have seen far too much of governments riding roughshod over private owners. They suffer because they are left up in the air or because they are caught in a bind, without money to buy, with a price fixed on their acquired property. I said earlier, and I repeat, that if acquisitions are made for the public good then the public should pay, and pay in the manner that at least ensures owners receive an amount of money that compensate them for the loss incurred.

While not opposing the Bill-I repeat it is disappointing-it still prevents fair and just compensation being available and makes an even greater humbug of the Government's referendum question as it was framed, requiring the States to pay compensation fairly and justly. This legislation provides that the Commonwealth is not required to do so and is not intending to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate and for their in-general support for the Lands Acquisition Bill. There has been the odd churlish comment about how long it has taken to get the Bill before the Senate. I understand that the report on which it was based came down in 1980, so we all must bear some of that blame-not only on this side but also on the other side.

SPEECH.PARA: The Act and the reforms are fairly complex. They do signal a great deal of progress in this area and the Commonwealth will now be well in advance of all State legislation in this regard. Some of the specific points raised as to Badgerys Creek and other matters seemed to me to be more making political points. All I would say is that I would love to live in the simplistic world of Senator Brownhill where everything is in absolute black and white and so simple. If only decisions one makes could be that simple. Some honourable senators, including Senator Puplick and Senator Powell, certainly raised some concern as to aspects of the Bill similar to ones which were raised in the House of Representatives. I will pass those on to Mr West for his consideration.

I only want to conclude with the point that was raised that we have acted too late in this particular area. I listed this Bill, I think, in August last year as No. 2 to be considered. If we had not wasted four weeks on what proved to be a waste of time, filling in with industrial legislation in the meantime, this Bill would have been well and truly up and operating. It is the duty of the Opposition to be churlish. It is the duty of the Opposition always to say that we have taken too long with something. I just wonder why the Opposition never amended the Commonwealth Electoral Act, the Migration Act, the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or the taxation Act. There is a whole series of things the Opposition never did when it was in power. It used to be said that the only difference between a Trotskyite and a Stalinist was that a Trotskyite was out of power.

However, I do appreciate the comments made by Opposition members here tonight. It is very hard to get the balance between the rights of individuals and the priorities of government. I think we all concede that. This does represent a major advance even if the Opposition is to argue it is still weak in one or two areas; it is a major advance, and I commend the progress of it to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the Bill in Committee of the Whole be made an Order of the Day for the next day of sitting.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 March I spoke during the adjournment debate on the tragic circumstances of two deaths in custody, one in my home State of Western Australia and the other in New South Wales. I drew the attention of the Senate to the fact that prisoners are routinely denied medical attention even when they are in agony and virtually unconscious. I also revealed the fact that in some cases autopsies have been delayed so long that critical information on the cause of death ceases to be ascertainable.

SPEECH.PARA: I have recently read some correspondence of the Campaign for Prevention of Custodial Death relating to the tragic death of Daniel Taylor, who died on 11 September 1987. This is another occasion when an autopsy was delayed. In this case it was delayed for five days. Infections, as I said before, cannot be reliably identified after 36 hours at the outside, and specimens should preferably be examined within 24 hours. Who was responsible for the delay and what action was taken against him? It is obvious that a lengthy delay in the carrying out of post mortem examination could well have the effect of hiding forever the true cause of death. Only when the true cause of death is established is it possible to prevent further tragedies. Failure to identify properly the cause of death can effectively camouflage gross neglect by prison staff.

It would seem that the coronial inquiries in New South Wales are designed more to justify the behaviour of correctional staff rather than to expose the truth. Because in this case the parents were unable to afford independent medical opinion it was impossible for them to expose any incompetence in the medical treatment received by their son. At the inquest, I am told, it was stated that headaches were not an indication of encephalitis, that changes in methadone doses would not mask the symptoms of encephalitis, that his death was certain and that prompt medical intervention would not have made any difference to the tragic outcome.

Firstly, I am told on good medical advice that headaches are one of the symptoms of encephalitis. Indeed, I can confirm this myself because my own daughter had encephalitis 12 years ago. Daniel Taylor's acute, persistent headaches began in late July, approximately seven weeks prior to his death. His continued pleas for medical attention were ignored and no treatment was instituted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying seven weeks of headaches?
—Yes.
—That is not acute encephalitis.

—Secondly, any significant change in methadone dosage, either up or down, would cause temporary personality changes with physical and mental distress. Such dosage variations might also cause headaches. I have had legal advice on these matters. Any of these symptoms, I am told, would certainly have the effect of disguising and masking a developing virulent illness.

SPEECH.PARA: It would seem highly probable that the prison staff, knowing that Daniel's methadone dosage had been modified as a form of punishment, assumed that his headaches were due to the fluctuating methadone dosages and were an intended effect of the punishment. They therefore did nothing to investigate the headaches. Thus an indefensible practice, the variation of methadone dosages as a form of punishment, may have lulled prison staff into neglecting to investigate the possibility of a more sinister cause of the headaches.

Thirdly, death as a result of encephalitis should never be thought of as inevitable. Some victims do survive. My own daughter is now a very healthy and active 21-year-old. The earlier it is diagnosed the better the chances of survival. In any case, a dying person, even one who is imprisoned, is entitled to all the comfort, care and the best medical attention that our society can provide and, in particular, to comfort and love in such circumstances. This was all denied Daniel Taylor.

He had a series of grand mal fits. Grand mal epileptic seizures must be considered serious and sometimes life-threatening events for anybody. In the first instance, even if they occur in a person known to have seizures, they pose a threat. For another reason, the unexpected occurrence of seizures, either in someone well controlled by anti-convulsant medication or occurring for the first time, must never be ignored. They demand urgent assessment as to why they occur.

I mentioned a moment ago the varying of medication dosages as a form of punishment. Daniel Taylor was a former drug addict who had made the commitment to free himself from his addiction. He had been on a methadone program for seven months prior to the time of his death. He had never breached any of the conditions of the program and had maintained it during a period of four weeks when he was not in custody. It was confirmed at the inquest that Daniel's dosage was altered because he had an altercation with the nursing staff. It is acknowledged by the prison authorities that it was used as a method of control within the prison. It was admitted at the inquest that Daniel's daily dosage was reduced from 60 milligrams to 30 milligrams for three days, then increased to 75 milligrams for two days, then increased to 80 milligrams for a period of five days, before being restored to the normal dosage of 60 milligrams.

I am told that when an individual's methadone dosage is being varied as part of a methadone program-for example, to wean that person off the drug-the normal variation is of the order of 2.5 milligrams per week. Honourable senators will appreciate that, if a variation of 2.5 milligrams per week is as much as is regarded as safe, then a variation of 30 to 45 milligrams per day could have traumatic effects on the person subjected to it. The fact that Daniel's methadone dosage was varied has not been challenged, but the fact that it was varied as a form of punishment has been disputed by the Minister for Corrective Services for New South Wales in a letter to the Campaign for Prevention of Custodial Death dated 17 March 1987. I put it to the Senate that when it has been admitted that methadone dosages were varied as a method of control within the prison system, and when it has been admitted that Daniel Taylor's dosages were varied by massive amounts, the only plausible explanation for those variations is that they were punitive in intent.

Variations in the administration of any form of medication or medical treatment as a form of control or punishment are an obscenity. They are reminiscent of the behaviour of doctors in Nazi concentration camps and of penal systems in countries justly criticised by Australia for gross abuse of human rights. It is my view that the Senate cannot possibly condone such a practice in any prison system in this country and that prison staff responsible for such abuses should be subject to disciplinary charges. Further, it would appear to me that doctors who participate in such abuse of patients' rights should be formally charged.

Daniel's mother was not told of his hospitalisation but discovered this by accident on inquiry. She was given no warning of his impending death and reached the hospital only a few hours before he became brain dead. He was only able to express to his mother his fear and puzzlement regarding his condition and to plead with her for help.

In my previous speech I detailed how Nicholas Searcy in Western Australia was kept chained to his bed and guarded in hospital, despite the fact that he was delirious, partially paralysed and in no condition to escape. Even though Daniel Taylor was within hours of his, by now, inevitable death, he continued to be guarded by two armed prison officers whose presence was maintained even after he was declared brain dead.

I am greatly concerned at this further evidence that I have received that in our country, which has abolished the death sentence for serious crimes, a prison sentence for a relatively minor offence all too readily develops into an effective death sentence. This can happen also to prisoners on remand, who are technically innocent of any offence. Daniel Taylor was simply on remand at the time of his death; he had not been convicted of any offence. He had applied for bail but died before his application for bail was considered.

I am further concerned that the investigation of deaths in custody is often woefully inadequate, especially when the circumstances possibly involve abuse or neglect by prison or police officers. It is simply not possible to get at the whole truth when the only people who present evidence are those who, were they to tell the whole truth, might well incriminate themselves. Running through this sad story is the persistent theme of the denial of medical treatment to those in custody. Quite simply, our prisons and police lock-ups are a health hazard, and a life threatening one at that. In the general community most people are under the impression that deaths in custody are, in the vast majority of cases, Aboriginal deaths involving hangings or strangulation. In fact, the truth is that there are many more white deaths in custody than black deaths. But colour is immaterial. Every death is a disaster for Australia; every death is a loss of human potential; every death brings grief and torment to parents and loved ones; every unnecessary death is a denial of our standing as an enlightened nation.

Australians are often aghast at prison conditions and judicial abuses in countries which do not enjoy the freedoms that we take for granted. It is time that we faced up to the fact that in our own prisons human beings are being abused, treated without pity, stripped of basic rights to personal dignity and necessary medical treatment, and dying of blatant neglect. This situation will not improve until coroners are given a great deal more power and independence to investigate deaths in custody. This has been highlighted by Mr Justice Muirhead, who has called for the setting up of an independent team to investigate deaths in custody and has made it clear that custodians must be able to be compelled to give evidence under oath, as is the case in respect of a royal commission. Further, the practice of delaying post mortem examinations until it is too late to accurately determine the cause of death must cease.

Mr President, I call on the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to approach the State Attorneys-General with a view to strengthening the powers of coroners, taking coronial inquests out of the hands of the police and removing the provision for police officers to assist the coroner in the court, thus enabling them to guide the proceedings to a conclusion pre-ordained by them in some cases and protective of the interests of their colleagues in the police and prison services.

I further call for the setting up of the type of team proposed by Mr Justice Muirhead to investigate deaths in custody, for ending the practice of using medication as a form of control and of punishing those in custody by denying them medication or medical help and for ensuring that prisoners receive a level of medical care not less than that available to people in the general community, thus generally bringing the administration of our custodial systems into the twentieth century.

In closing my remarks, I note that an inquest will be held in Sydney commencing on 19 April into the death in custody of Malcolm Hatch, about whom I spoke last time. His autopsy was also delayed until the fifth day following his death. I will be monitoring this inquest closely. I trust that deficiencies evident in the conduct of earlier inquests will not be repeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not normally comment on the speeches of other senators, but I want to say that all the evidence that I have received anecdotally would support everything that Senator Jenkins has said, that there is something wrong with the way our prisons work in terms of medical care offered to prisoners, especially to those prisoners who are on methadone programs for treatment of intravenous drug abuse. Everything she has said is consistent with what I have heard. I am grateful to her for having brought it to our attention.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of us serve on the parliamentary liaison group on acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). A number of us were enlisted by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) to serve on working panels in order to look at the Green Paper that was produced recently. I chaired the panel on intravenous drug use and HIV infection. We came up against the problem of what does constitute intravenous drug use in Australia. We actually reported 10 statements: There may be up to half a million Australians who at some stage have used drugs intravenously; that most of them are recreational users; that they have an increased risk of infection; that users come from all sections of the community and from all social economic groups; that drug use occurs within all ethnic groups in Australia; and that a large percentage of prisoners are in prison for drug-related offences. I interpolate here that drug use is rampant in prisons, even though the drugs are supposed to be contraband. We received evidence of 70 women prisoners sharing one needle and syringe and 40 male prisoners in another prison sharing one needle and syringe. If we want to spread the virus that is the way to go about it. We also heard that there was so much heroin in Pentridge at one stage that it was being exported back to St Kilda for sale.

We were told a number of other things about drug use but what emerged was how little is actually known and how little hard evidence there is which we can use and be certain about. I want therefore to bring to the attention of the Senate some work done by Stephen Mugford, a senior lecturer in sociology at the Australian National University and a member of the drug indicators project in the Australian Capital Territory. In a paper entitled `Indicators of Drug Use in Australia: An Overview of the National Data', Dr Mugford has done us a great service. He has analysed some of the data sources available to the different States, indicating that most States use only some of the possible sources of data, those being mortality statistics, police statistics, morbidity statistics, methadone data, telephone service data, schools surveys, price and purity data, AIDS data, court statistics and population surveys. The evidence that is available was given at a conference at which Dr Mugford was a participant and he has brought it together in a paper. Because the subject is important and because it is of importance to know how many drug users there are in Australia I have taken the liberty of showing this paper to the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus. I seek leave to table the paper.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about a visit I recently made to the Philippines as part of the Australian Peace Brigade, which was attended by many other international visitors, in the month of January. Unfortunately I was not able to be there for the whole month but I was there for 10 days, which were very busy and extremely enlightening. Most of the Australians, 88 people in all, were there for the full month. They went on exposure tours in the countryside during which they learnt a great deal about how ordinary people in the Philippines are living and the problems that they are facing at the moment. There was a conference called the Asia Pacific People's Conference on Peace and Development. A very interesting declaration came out of that which was put very briefly along the lines of calling for a cessation of outside international involvement in the internal affairs of the countries in the region, particularly military interference. It was a call for the closure of all foreign military bases in the region.

SPEECH.PARA: There were people at the conference from Japan, Korea, the Pacific island nations, Aotearoa, Nepal, India and Thailand. Many countries were represented. The people who were at the conference were invited to go to the Philippines by a coalition of 15 cause oriented groups. They worked cooperatively together to provide a very interesting set of exposure tours for the international groups-they were not just Australians travelling together-and put together a very good conference program. The third part of the Peace Brigade's activity consisted of a peace caravan when 2,000 vehicles and 7,000 people weaved their way out of Manila toward Clark Air Force Base-a huge United States air force installation-then towards Subic Bay, which is an enormous United States naval installation.

The point I want to make is that there is no way that Australia should be supporting the fallacy that the Philippines is a democracy. I heard it repeated by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), who visited Manila just after the Peace Brigade was there along with various other parliamentarians and members of the public from Australia. People seem to think that following the Edsa revolution three years ago, in January 1986, democracy had been restored to the Philippines. There were great hopes that democracy would be restored with the overthrow of the Marcos regime. For the first year President Aquino experienced a great deal of goodwill from people supporting her and trying to put some democratic processes into place. Unfortunately, a year later she declared a policy of total war against the insurgents. The label `insurgents' can be applied to any people who are working actively for social change in the Philippines. It is not just directed against members of the New People's Army or others who are connected in any way with any communist organisation. This policy of total war which has been enunciated very clearly by President Aquino is directed against anybody who is working for social change.

I met many people involved in these cause oriented groups in Manila and outside it. I would like to mention a couple of stories that I was told, particularly by women's groups. The overall umbrella women's group in the Philippines is called Gabriela. It does an amazing job in trying to educate women about their rights. I do not think anybody should argue with that kind of education. From their experience they have found that Mrs Aquino is now totally unwilling to speak to these women, many of whom worked very hard to help her in the election following the overthrow of the Marcos regime. She has removed herself from any kind of consultation with the people who worked very hard to support her. She seems to be totally under the thumb of the military.

Many people volunteered to me the comment that things are worse as far as human rights violations are concerned under the Aquino regime than they were under Marcos. People said over and over again, `Under the Marcos regime we were afraid of being detained. Under Cory Aquino we are afraid of being shot'. That is exactly what is happening. People are disappearing in great numbers. Human rights violations are very well documented in an Amnesty International report, yet the international community seems to continue to perpetuate the myth that the Philippines is a democracy. There is no democracy at the point of a gun. I am not exaggerating the position at all. I will give a few examples of the violations of human rights in a moment. I experienced democracy Filipino style at the point of a gun and it was not a pleasant experience.

The Gabriela group that I had the privilege to meet with is a very fine organisation of women. The document I would like to quote from is called Let's work together for the protection of human rights of Filipino women: a documentation report on the human rights situation of Filipino women. It was put out last year by this group. Just to give an idea of the kind of problems that women in the Philippines are suffering I will read the headings without going into details of the atrocities. This will give people an idea of the sort of problems that are faced by women, very often by the children who are in their company and also by men. But this document focuses particularly on women.

This report documents human rights violations from February 1986 to February 1988. The first heading is `Arbitrary arrest and detention'. There are pages of such cases. The next heading is `Evacuation and hiding'. The next one is `Killings and frustrated massacres'. We have to remember that these cases involve real human beings. I met many of them whose families had suffered and whose spouses had disappeared, or been tortured, and some had themselves been tortured and survived. I will give just a couple of examples. Under the heading `Killings and frustrated massacres', there is the example of Cecita Udtuhan, a 36-year-old peasant women of Matinao, Burawen, Leyte, who was forcibly taken by 20 men who were believed to be members of the Tadtad group, a vigilante group, and the military, on 29 May 1987. She was seven months pregnant. Four days later she was found dead with stabs on her side, her belly lacerated and her foetus pulled out. It is not very pretty stuff but I think people in Australia need to understand what is actually happening in the Philippines now. Another case is that of Marlyn Negro, a 38-year-old peasant women from Barangay Matinao, Burawen, Leyte, who was abducted together with Cecita Udtuhan by a composite group of military men and Tadtad members. Her body was found four days later. Her head had been cut off. The cases under the heading `Killings and frustrated massacres' goes on for pages.

There are such headings as `Illegal searches and raids', `Looting and destruction of properties', `Abduction and disappearances', `Rape', `Sex trafficking' and `Sex tourism' which gives one particularly ghastly case. I am afraid to say that there are Australian business people involved in sex tourism and sex trafficking. I actually went to some of the bars owned and operated by Australians and felt quite sickened and ashamed. This particular case involved an Austrian, not an Australian. It was the case of Rosario Baluyut, a victim of sex tourism, who died in 1987 at the age of 12 of cervical infection caused by a broken piece of vibrator left in her cervix by a pedophile. That is the sort of situation that Philippine people are facing constantly. There are pages in the list of women political prisoners in the Philippines as at 12 October 1988. I think the women number 68 in all. That is the sort of situation that the people there are facing.

On International Women's Day, which was 8 March, I did not manage to get on the speakers list, but I want to quote from a statement for International Women's Day from the women of Gabriela. They said that two International Women's Days had elapsed, and now three with the latest one, since `the Filipino women, rejoiced over the coming to power of a woman president at the government's helm'. They said:
We were so full of hope then. So full of hope on the promise of freedom and democracy brought by the people's uprising in Edsa. But after two years,-
and this would now be three-
sorrow and anger had taken over the ecstasy.

In spite of the hardship and pain that we have suffered in the ousting of the Marcos regime, the government of Cory Aquino betrayed the democracy that the people have fought for in Edsa. Up to the present there has been no change in the lot of the deprived and impoverished masses, especially the women. There has been no solution to our age-old problems-most of us are still without jobs, relegated to the role of housekeepers . . . Our wages are mere pittances and we are still discriminated against in occupational opportunity and promotion. We are forced into prostitution and degrading commodification of our bodies. Sexual abuse, institutionalized discrimination, domestic violence . . . and political repression-these are the evils we have to contend with in our daily lives.
Last year, Cory Aquino, together with her soldiers, police and para-military that was formed with the support and blessing of United States, has declared the policy of `total war'.
The total war is waged against not only the NPA and the MNLF, its political arm, but:

it is an indiscriminate, genocidal war against the people of this country who want to change the old system of the ruling elite, to end the economic plunder and control of United States and other imperialist powers, and to regain our national sovereignty. It is a war against the Filipino women, who seek genuine progress and freedom.

There are many other atrocities that I could quote, but I think it is more important to move on the experience of just one other group that I want to mention, and that is the discrimination against and repression of trade unionists in the Philippines. Here again human rights violations are rampant. There is a basic wage in the Philippines but it is not enforced. It is not enforced because there is a great deal of corruption and because it suits the ruling elite to have workers at their beck and call working for an absolute pittance. I visited some picket lines on the outskirts of Manila and I met women who were on strike because they were paid only 23 pesos a day, that is, about $1.50. The basic wage, incidentally, is just over $4 but they are not being paid it. These women had been on strike for only a couple of weeks. All of them in this textile factory had gone out on strike together. I said, `What are your hopes of winning this dispute?'. In fact, they were very bleak indeed, because the bosses merely shut up shop and move out somewhere else where the workers are not yet unionised. That is the kind of violation that is going on. The people who are working with the unions, who are trying to educate the people about basic democratic rights as workers and trying to enforce the Government's own stated basic wage, which is still by our terms a miserable pittance, are also subject to torture, disappearances and salvaging. It is just so distressing to see the scale on which this is happening not only in Manila but in the countryside as well-this war being waged against the people who are working for social change.

Part of the exposure that I undertook was to go to the United States bases. I did not actually go into the bases but I was interested in looking at the townships which had sprung up outside them: Angeles, which is outside the Clark Air Force Base, and Olongapo, which is outside Subic Bay. I visited two women's centres there, Kapitbahay and Buklod, which try to help the women who are forced into prostitution by their economic deprivation in those townships. I talked with them and learned a great deal about the lifestyle that they lead. As I said, unfortunately, I even had the opportunity of visiting Australian owned and operated bars which are involved in this exploitation, which is the most gross and ghastly because it involves not only women who are there because of the cycle of poverty but very often children as well. The children are often the results of liaisons with United States servicemen. That is what the townships are there for. It is euphemistically referred to as the hospitality industry but it is at a great price to the people.

These women are often despised by their families back in the provinces, if their families know what they are up to. They are despised by the Catholic Church. Eighty-five per cent of the people in the Philippines are Catholic but the Catholic Church will not allow any form of birth control to be used or any education about birth control. So the chief form of birth control is abortion and, of course, it is illegal abortion so it is backyard stuff, causing many more problems for the women's health.

The acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) is also a very important issue which is not being dealt with adequately or responsibly by the United States servicemen who use those women, and I say `use' in the most obvious sense of the word. There are 28 cases of AIDS amongst the prostitutes in Olongapo. They are not full blown cases as yet, but they have been identified as AIDS carriers and they are still working. As they do not feel sick, they do not see why they should not keep working. Of course we all know how easy it is for that virus to spread, and I think that is a consequence which should not be overlooked.

The problems that these women face are more psychological because, as I said, they are abhorred by their own families if they know what they are up to, they are looked down upon by the Catholic Church and they are treated very judgmentally by the hierarchy of the church, but not always, thank goodness, by the priests and nuns who are often there to help them-that is the ones who are really living according to the spirit of the gospel and who are concerned about liberation theology and trying to change the social situation of the Philippine people. The women are also despised by their clients. That must be very difficult for these women to deal with. The depression that they often face is so extreme that there are many suicides. They get drugs from the US servicemen on an irregular basis, and when they cannot get drugs to alleviate their psychological depression, they resort to cough medicine so they can get some cheaper kicks that take them away from their particular problems at the time.

One of these centres that I visited, Buklod, is a night care centre for children. These women often have children and they have got to have somewhere safe where they can leave them while they go off to ply their trade at night. Very often the women are in debt to the bar owners and many of them cannot get out even if they want to and, of course, there are not a lot of other jobs for them. So the economic situation and the deprivation forcing women into this cycle of poverty and then prostitution constitute a very important and distressing problem for the Philippines.

If the Philippine people decide that the United States bases should go, of course there would be a lot of women out of work and a lot of workers on the bases also out of jobs. But it is up to the Philippine Government to look for creative and socially useful and more morally acceptable work for those people who might be thus displaced. There is a big debate going on in the Philippines at the moment about the presence of the US bases because for 450 years the Philippine people have suffered colonialism of one kind or another, and this is certainly colonialism at the hands of the Americans. It suits the Americans very well to have the international community regard the Philippines as a democracy. It is no democracy.

The Australian Embassy staff, particularly the former Ambassador, Mr John Holloway, who has now returned to Canberra, was very helpful in listening to people in the peace brigades and in trying to set up some meetings for us. We felt that it was very important to have that link with our embassy. After all, it helps all kinds of business people who are setting up deals in the Philippines, and they are not always of the very best kind, so it was good that we had that support from the embassy and that helpful information flow.

I am very concerned about Australia's role in the Philippines. The investments that we have there are often at the expense of the people and the environment. The foreign aid that we give, which is quite substantial-$29m per annum-was increased quite dramatically with the arrival of Cory Aquino on the scene. Everybody was very hopeful for the first year or so that democracy would be restored. But that is not the case now. I think that our foreign aid, government to government aid which actually gives Cory Aquino the support of the Australian Government and of course the support of the Australian people, is misplaced. We should not be supporting a military regime. Cory Aquino has now survived five attempted military coups and each one has pushed her further to the right. She is under the thumb of the military. She is not, as I said earlier, taking any notice of her former advisers. The people who she first put in place to be her advisers have all been moved over. Each time there is a military coup, she has had to move further to the right. She is there with the permission of the military and with the permission of the United States Government as well. It suits them very well to have Saint Cory, as she is often referred to, ostensibly leading the Philippines.

With her blessing-and I must say with the blessing of the hierarchy of the Catholic Church too-the vigilante groups, which are like a paramilitary force assisting the military forces in the Philippines, carry out these barbarous acts on the people who are working for social change. I do not think that we should support that sort of a regime. My recommendation is that Australia's foreign aid to the Philippines should not be cut or ceased, but that it should be redirected to non-government organisations, of which there are many which are quite capable of distributing that foreign aid in a more equitable way and to the people who could benefit from it most.

I believe that most Australians would want our aid to go to alleviate the problems of the Filipino people at the grass roots level so that they can put in place self-help projects, so that we are not just giving bandaid treatment and so that we are not supporting that Government by giving government to government aid. I think it is a great mistake to continue to do that. Australia is also involved in military aid to the Philippines in the form, mostly, of officers from the Philippine military forces coming to Australia for periods of three to six months each year. I think that that should stop as well, because it is very obvious that whatever kind of training these military people are getting in Australia can be used very readily-and most readily is used-against their own people.

Time and time again, when I was in the peace caravan travelling to Clark Air Force Base, I heard the Philippine people say to the soldiers who were holding us up and causing us delays on the way-at gunpoint, I might add-that instead of defending the United States bases against some peaceful people who were engaged in a non-violent protest, they should be defending the Filipino people; that the job of a defence force is to support and defend its own nation's people. That is not what it is engaged in. It is engaged in defending the might of the United States military against the Philippine people who are, understandably, very concerned about the continued presence.

I also mention the case of Captain Edgardo Sebastian of the Philippines Constabulary Military Intelligence Group who, when he was involved in torturing a woman by the name of Adora Faye Devera-she is now a prize-winning poet; she lived to tell the tale-for a period of three years under the Marcos regime bragged about having been taught his torture techniques in Australia. I have asked the Foreign Minister to check this out. Whether or not it is true, it certainly deserves to be thoroughly investigated. I hope that it is not true, but this man who inflicted all kinds of dreadful torture on Adora Faye Devera thought that it was in his interests and made him look like a greater hero if he could brag about having been taught his torture techniques in Australia. For that reason I think that Australian military aid should stop altogether.

As far as Australian investment in the Philippines is concerned, I think it is necessary to set up a set of ethical guidelines to guide investors so that they do not get involved in the sleazy sex trade which is the most ghastly kind of exploitation of women and children imaginable. If certain ethical guidelines were set up for Australian investors in foreign countries-they should apply to all countries, I guess-the Government could do something to actively discourage people from getting involved in exploitative industries overseas.

The spirit of the Filipino people is inspiring, despite their problems, despite the militarisation of their country, despite the fact that there is no democracy and that economic deprivation is extreme. One has only to go to Smoky Mountain, the rubbish tip in Manila, where thousands of people live on the rubbish dump, and smell the stench of that place to have the lesson very clearly driven home that enormous changes are necessary in the Philippines for the basic human rights and the basic social needs of the Filipino people to be met. Despite their problems, the spirit of the people that I met who are involved in the cause or who enter groups working for social change was absolutely inspiring. Their courage in the face of adversity is tremendous. Their struggle for democracy is extremely brave and they are prepared to continue it until they finally get democracy. Their struggle should be shared by people in Australia. I look forward to the time when-if the recommendations that I have put for foreign aid from Australia to be re-directed towards non-government organisations, for Australia's military aid to cease, and for a set of ethical guidelines to be developed for Australian investment are adopted-Australia is actually part of the solution to the problem in the Philippines instead of contributing to the furthering of the problems for the Filipino people.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.06 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 25 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the proposed development of a so-called Asian College together with a satellite town, by a mining company, Mallina Holdings, at Point Gray on Peel Inlet near Mandurah W.A.
(2) Has the Minister been made aware of the considerable body of local opinion which is opposed to this project.

(3) Is the Minister aware that the Peel Inlet-Harvey Estuary has been described by the (then) W.A. Department of Conservation and the Environment (March 1985) as being `one of the most important waterbird habitats in South Western Australia'.

(4) Will the Minister take steps to ensure the protection of the following bird species identified by the Department as being recorded at the Peel Inlet-Harvey Estuary, which have been further specifically identified in the Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of Japan for the protection of Migratory Birds in danger of extinction and their environment, and the draft Agreement between the Government of the People's Republic of China and the Government of Australia for the Protection of Migratory Birds and their Environment': (a) Pluvialis dominica (J.C.) Golden Plover: (b) P. squatarola (J.C.) Gray Plover: (c) Arenaria interpres (J.C.) Ruddy Turnstone: (d) Calidris ruficollis (J.C.) Red-necked Stint: (e) C. subminuta (J.C.) Long-toed Stint: (f) C. melanotis (J) Pectoral Sandpiper: (g) C. accuminata (J.C.) Sharp-tailed Sandpiper (h) C. ferruginea (J.C.) Curlew Sandpiper: (i) C. tenuirostris (J.C.) Great Knot: (j) Charadrius mongolus (J.C.) Mongolian Sand-dotterel: (k) C. leschenaultii (J.C.) Sand-dotterel: (l) Limicola falcinellus (J.C.) Broad-billed Sandpiper: (m) Sterna bergii (J) Crested Tern: (n) S. hitundo (J.C.) Asiatic Common Tern: (o) Chlidonias leucoptera (C) White-winged Tern: (p) Xenus cinereus (J.C.) Terek Sandpiper: (q) Numeris borealis (C) Little Curlew: (r) N. Madagascariensis (c) Eastern Curlew, (s) Tringa nebularia (C) Greenshank (t) T. glateola (C) Wood Sandpiper: (u) T. hypoleucos (C) Common Sandpiper, (iv). T. brevipes (C) Grey-tailed Tattler: and (W) Philomachus pugnax (C) Ruff.
(5) What steps will the Minister take to carry out Australia's international obligations with regard to migratory birds and threats to their Australian environments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) The protection of the natural habitats of Peel Inlet in Western Australia is primarily the responsibility of the Western Australian authorities, and, in particular, of the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management.

Australian obligations under its Treaties with Japan and China for the protection of migratory birds and their environments are implemented through legislation and administrative arrangements in force in the States and the Northern Territory, with co-ordination being effected through the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM). The CONCOM Working Group on International Agreements Relating to Migratory and Wetlands Birds advises the CONCOM Standing Committee on implementation of the Treaties. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service provides the convener of the CONCOM Working Group and has an overall coordinating role in the implementation of the Treaties. Western Australia is represented on the Working Group by the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management.

Under its nature conservation legislation, Western Australia has the responsibility to assess the significance of natural areas as habitat for migratory and endangered birds, identify areas of particular importance and carry out protective measures to conserve habitats in such areas.

While my Department, when asked, provides advice on the interpretation of these and other treaties, it is inappropriate for my Department to be involved in issues relating to particular wetland areas before such assessments have been made and before the matter has been considered through agreed procedures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 24 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What standards of safety apply to nursing homes, hospitals catering for veterans and day care centres for families and children that are in whole or part financed by the Federal Government.
(2) What is the level of funding in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory for such safety precautions in the institutions outlined in (1).
(3) What is the financial level of assistance to the 6 States for safety precautions in the institutions outlined in (1).
(4) What monitoring programs has the Federal Government in place to police the strict maintenance of safety standards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth Government expects nursing homes to provide a safe environment for residents, staff and visitors. This requirement is one of thirty-one standards stated in ``Living in a Nursing Home: Outcome Standards for Australian Nursing Homes''. This publication specifies quality of life and care outcomes for nursing home residents. Nursing home standards monitoring teams focus on the achievement of the outcome, that is, that residents are safe, rather than the mere presence of inputs or processes relating to safety.
The legal basis for the safety requirement is stated in Special Gazette No. S303 ``National Health Act 1953-Section 45d: Standards for Nursing Home Care'', Standard No. 6, which states:
``The nursing home design, equipment and practices will adequately protect the physical safety and security of residents and their belongings.''
In practice, standards monitoring teams expect homes to comply with relevant safety legislation, regulations and/or requirements and to demonstrate a good safety record.

Safety standards for day care centres are the responsibility of State Governments and are determined and monitored by State licensing bodies in conjunction with other bodies such as the Board of Fire Commissioners. State bodies responsible for licensing of child care centres are as follows:
