The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following information in respect of hospitals catering for veterans, and day care centres.

The Repatriation Commission ensures that Repatriation General Hospitals (RGHs), Repatriation Auxiliary Hospitals, the Anzac Hostel and the Repatriation Artificial Limb and Appliance Centres maintain all Commonwealth, State and local standards that promote a safe environment for patients and visitors. These standards are also followed in the day care centres operating in RGHs. For staff working in these institutions, the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) has occupational health and safety programs. Procedures are also aligned with those set by the Australian Council of Hospital Standards.

Although the Commission does not operate any nursing homes, social workers at the RGHs ensure that privately-operated nursing homes that receive Repatriation patients meet Department of Community Services and Health requirements.
In regard to day care centres part financed by the DVA, occupational therapists from RGHs ensure that operating organisations adhere to the required safety standards.

(2) Nursing homes are not specifically funded to meet safety standards. They are provided a standard grant per resident to provide for basic infrastructure services within the nursing home (for example, food, rent, maintenance). The service provider must decide how to spend this income to meet, among other things, the safety requirements for residents, staff, equipment and building.
Funding for child care services under the Commonwealth's Children's Services Program is conditional on the service being licensed by the relevant authority.

(3) State Governments receive nursing home benefits for each resident accommodated in a State Government nursing home. It is the responsibility of the State Government and the nursing home administrators to allocate their budget to meet safety requirements.

Capital grants under the Children's Services Program are based on the actual cost of the project and as such will cover the variety of physical safety requirements directly associated with the building housing the service.

(4) The nursing home safety standards are monitored by standards monitoring teams, which visit homes at least annually. Where these teams find non-compliance with any standards, including safety standards, they negotiate with service providers to ensure that these standards are met. Where serious and/or persistent non-compliance occurs, the Commonwealth Government, as well as the State Government, as appropriate, can invoke powers against the nursing home proprietors. In general, negotiation with service providers is conducted on a cooperative basis to ensure a positive address of non-compliance.

Commonwealth recurrent funding is not directed specifically toward meeting safety requirements. The Commonwealth provides a contribution to operational costs which assists services to meet licensing requirements. Other Commonwealth funds are attracted through fee relief subsidies for low to moderate income families.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 31 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Given the report of the Committee to Review Australian Studies in Tertiary Education titled `Windows on to Worlds' was completed some 12 months ago, has the Minister decided which of the recommendations will be implemented; if so, will he indicate which of them will be implemented; if not, why not.
(2) Does the Minister agree that an Australian awareness should permeate the curriculum; if so, why has there been this long delay in implementing the Committee's recommendations; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The report's recommendations do not relate solely to Commonwealth responsibilities. They were also directed by the Committee to State education authorities and Vice-Chancellors and Principals of higher education institutions for attention. My reply deals only with the recommendations which fall within my portfolio responsibilities.

The report was distributed to State Ministers for Education, Directors of TAFE, the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals in Advanced Education as well as higher education institutions and appropriate Government Departments. The report's recommendations have been considered at forums such as the Australian Education Council and the Cultural Ministers Conference.

Recommendations relating to school level initiatives were referred to State Directors General for attention as primary responsibility for school curriculum rests with State authorities. So far as Commonwealth activity is concerned it is relevant to point out that my Department has recently produced and made available free of charge to all Australian schools a substantial package of materials designed to strengthen the Australian perspective across the school curriculum. These materials were produced by the Bicentennial Australian Studies Schools Project, a project of the Curriculum Development Centre.

Recommendation 1 of the Committee was that the terms of reference of any review of science and mathematics teaching in tertiary education institutions take account of the matters raised in the report.
The Discipline Review of Teacher Education in Mathematics and Science which I announced in July 1988 will take account, where appropriate, of the report's recommendations.
Recommendation 5a was that in view of the need for high quality editing skills in Australia a course in this field should be supported by the Commonwealth in a tertiary institution.

A number of higher institutions offer professional writing and journalism courses which contain editing segments. As self-governing bodies, higher education institutions are themselves responsible for decisions about courses. They are considered to be generally responsible to community needs. Certainly such an initiative would receive favourable consideration by the Commonwealth in funding for growth.
Recommendation 5b was that greater support to textual editing be given by such research grants bodies as the Australian Research Grants Scheme (ARGS).

The ARGS has been subsumed in the research grants programs of the Australian Research Council which was established in July 1988, among other things, to coordinate the national research effort. In assessing research proposals for support, the Council's primary concern is to promote excellence in research. Proposals involving research into the methodologies of textual editing, for example, would be considered on their merits, in competition with other proposals.

Recommendation 8 was that matters raised in this report be taken into account by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, and other Commonwealth and State authorities responsible for providing advice on trade training.

The concerns and recommendations outlined in the report lend support to the current policy and program directions of the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) and State/Territory Training Authorities in relation to skill formation. Many of the issues identified in the Report as crucial to vocational training have been addressed in Skills for Australia, A Changing Workforce and other recent policy statements and are receiving attention at present in the development of policy regarding competency-based training and the impact of award restructuring on entry-level training.

Recommendation 9 was for funds to be made available by CTEC through its Evaluations and Investigations Program and by State TAFE authorities to conduct surveys of vocational training areas with a view to the development of strategies for the integration of Australian based teaching material and Australian studies into technical education curricula.

The Evaluations and Investigations Program is now administered by the Higher Education Division of DEET. It is used to fund studies in the higher education area only, and is therefore no longer an appropriate source of funding for the project recommended in Recommendation 9.

The objectives of the Australian Committee on TAFE Curriculum (ACTC) include making the best use of the national resources by working nationally and to increase the use of national core curricula. Recommendation 9 has been referred to the ACTC for their consideration.
Recommendation 11 was that the curriculum for pre-service and in-service teacher education should contain a substantial component of Australian-based teaching materials and Australian studies.
My understanding is that this is increasingly the case. Higher education institutions are responsible for the curriculum of pre-service and advanced teacher education courses.

Recommendation 12 was that a Chair of Australian Screen Studies be established at an Australian university and that this appointment should be allied with a Directorship of an Australian Screen Studies program in another higher education institution.
This is a matter for institutions to take the initiative in seeking sponsorship from private enterprise and State or Commonwealth Government sources as appropriate.
Recommendation 16 is that priority in the provision of new places and funding of new key centres should be given to teaching in the heritage area.

Australian studies has been identified as a priority area for enrolment growth along with Asian Studies and areas considered important for Australia's economic development such as science, engineering, technology and business studies.
A new key centre in Australian Studies has been established at Monash University. Further details are provided in my comments on Recommendation 32.

Recommendation 18 was that a joint working party be established by the Department of Education and Foreign Affairs, with representatives from a wide range of educational organisations to develop a body to co-ordinate Australia's cultural and educational activities overseas.

Following consultations between the Departments and the educational organisations, the Government has sought expressions of interest in setting up Australian Education Centres (AECs) in countries overseas where there is a large volume of applications for study in Australia. AECs would be located outside Australian diplomatic missions (ADMs) and would offer an advisory, counselling and information service about all aspects of study in Australia for overseas students on behalf of participating institutions. This would not, however, include policy or visa issues which would remain the responsibility of the ADM. The responsibilities of the AECs would not extend to cultural activities.
Recommendation 20 was for an investigation of the teaching of English as a foreign and second language in Australian and overseas tertiary institutions.

A National Centre for English Language Teaching and Research has been established at Macquarie University. The National Centre, in the School of English and Linguistics, was approved on the base level funding of $216,000 a year for the next three years, extendable, on review, for a further three years. This is being supplemented by funding from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs which was transferred from the Adult Migrant Education Program National Curriculum Resource Centre(NCRC). The NCRC is currently being amalgamated with the National Centre. It is to be a catalyst for research into the English language, the problems it poses for non-native and native speakers in Australia and associated educational issues of curriculum design, materials development and program evaluation.

Approval in principle has also been granted for a Key Centre in Applied Language Studies to be located within a higher education institution. My Department is currently seeking proposals for its establishment. It is expected that the Centre will undertake the following functions: co-ordinate language activities in tertiary institutions through a clearing-house and language advisory service; provide professional development for language lecturers and teacher trainers; engage in research in applied language issues, including language teaching methodology; develop national language proficiency instruments in English as a second/foreign language and other languages; and offer a language testing service on a cost-recovery basis.

Recommendation 23 was that the Commonwealth ask higher education institutions to take account of the need to develop Australian-based learning and to take account of the need to consider the criterion of Australian relevance in planning and allocating resources and in determining staffing needs and staff development programs.
As I have mentioned in relation to Recommendation 16, Australian studies has been identified as a priority area for enrolment growth.

Recommendations 25 and 26, relating to the employment of staff in higher education, have been referred to the National Board of Employment Education and Training for consideration. Generally this matter is one for the higher education institutions to determine.
Recommendation 28 called for the establishment of chairs in Australian art history and Australian music at appropriate institutions.
This is a matter for institutions to take the initiative in seeking sponsorship from private enterprise, and State or Commonwealth Government sources as appropriate.

Recommendation 31 of the Committee was that the ARGC and other funding bodies which allocate research funds, recognise the importance of `tools of research', and include suitable provision for the allocation of funds to develop guides, bibliographies, registers, indexes and databases within their guidelines.

The Australian Research Council and, in particular, its relevant advisory committee in the humanities and social sciences acknowledges the need to develop `tools of research' such as appropriate databases. However, the matter must be considered in the context of determining overall research granting priorities and strategies.
Recommendation 32 proposes the establishment of a National Centre for Research and Development in Australian studies.

I announced in May 1988 funding for such a centre at Monash University. It was one of fifteen new Key Centres of Teaching and Research. The Monash centre for Australian Studies has been allocated $176,000 a year for three years, extendable on review for a further three or, possibly six, years.
The centre consists of a new multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary teaching and research unit which began operation within the Faculty of Arts at the beginning of 1988.

At the masters degree level, a core course ``Society, Culture and the Study of Australia'' will involve a dissertation chosen from the faculties of Arts and Economics and Politics. This development will produce a new range of Australian Studies programs at the undergraduate level.

Research reflects the multi-faceted nature of the course and includes: studies in the salinity and desertification of Australia, acquisition of English skills by migrant communities, history of Australian culture, publishing, theatre, religion in Australian society, work in Australian industry and much more.
Recommendation 33 of the Committee was that in the establishment of key centres in universities and colleges:
(a) attention should be paid to applications seeking to assist in Australianising the tertiary curriculum.
(b) recognition be given to the special research needs of vocational studies, and
(c) centres to be limited to one triennium.

The Australian Research Council, which now has responsibility for the Key Centres of Teaching and Research program, proposes to review the future directions of the program early this year. The recommendation will be drawn to the attention of the Council during the course of the review.
(2) Yes.
There has been no appreciable delay in implementation of the Committee's recommendations. The first opportunity to secure funding for the Committee's recommendations was for the 1988-89 Budget year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Treaties: Protection of Migratory Birds and Their Environments

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 28 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: I refer to two Treaties between Australia and Japan and between Australia and China, for the protection of migratory birds and their environments:

(1) Is the Minister aware of events in the Wyong Shire of New South Wales, in the area of North Entrance Peninsula, along the shore of Tuggerah Lake and Terilbah Island where development is threatening fast-dwindling coastal wildlife habitats.

(2) Would the Minister please detail the steps being taken by his Department to ensure the obligations imposed by these Treaties are brought to the attention of the Wyong Shire Council and the appropriate departments of the State Government of New South Wales, which are recently and currently involved in a range of activities that continue to destroy and compromise the environment on which no less than 35 different species of birds listed so far in these Treaties have been shown to depend for their survival.

(3) What action does the Minister propose to take to require that these Treaties are recognised and respected in the area of North Entrance Peninsula, Terilbah Island and the adjoining ocean and lake.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The protection of the natural habitats of the North Entrance Peninsula in the Wyong Shire of New South Wales is primarily the responsibility of the New South Wales authorities and, in particular, of the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service.

Australian obligations under the Treaties with Japan and China for the protection of migratory birds and their environments are implemented through legislation and administrative arrangements already in force in the States and the Northern Territory, with coordination being effected through the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM). The CONCOM Working Group on International Agreements Relating to Migratory and Wetlands Birds advises the CONCOM Standing Committee on implementation of the Treaties. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service provides the convener of the CONCOM Working Group and has an overall coordinating role in the implementation of the Treaties. New South Wales is represented on the Working Group by the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service.

Under its nature conservation legislation, New South Wales has the responsibility to assess the significance of natural areas as habitats for migratory and endangered birds, to identify areas of particular importance and to carry out protective measures to conserve habitats in such areas.

While my Department, when asked, provides advice on the interpretation of these and other treaties, it is inappropriate for my Department to be involved in issues relating to particular wetland areas before such assessments have been made and before the matter has been considered through agreed procedures.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Office of National Assessments: Appointment of Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 1 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it correct that the Office of National Assessments in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet refuses to appoint or to transfer successful applicants for positions in the Office, even after they have been security cleared, until the successful applicant has taken out Australian citizenship; if so, is this consistent with usual Public Service recruitment practices and by what authority is appointment delayed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Office of National Assessments (ONA) is a statutory body within the Prime Minister's portfolio but independent of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It contains staff employed under the Public Service Act and is bound by the provisions of that Act when making appointments and transfers affecting them. I assume the honourable senator's question refers to the appointment and transfer of staff of the Office employed under the Public Service Act.

Appointments to the Australian Public Service are usually appointments on probation. The Public Service Act enables a person who does not have Australian citizenship to be appointed on probation, but the Act provides that, in general, such an appointment cannot be confirmed until the officer has been granted citizenship.

The ONA, and other agencies in the Australian Intelligence Community staffed under the Public Service Act, do not appoint on probation persons who are not Australian citizens, unless special circumstances apply. This practice, which differs somewhat from the practice in the Service generally, is nevertheless regarded as consistent with the Public Service Act, and has Government approval.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: Travel and Accommodation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 6 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: What increased Departmental activities during the financial years 1986/87 and 1987/88 required the increases in travel and accommodation of 39 per cent and 35 per cent in the quarters ended 30 June 1987 and 1988, respectively, over the average expenditures for the previous three quarters in the respective financial years, as indicated in the answer to Senate Question No. 545 (Senate Hansard, 1 December 1988, page 3423).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The pattern of expenditure displayed by the response to Senate Question No. 545 is consistent with the Department's historical trends.
Based on data to the end of 1985-86, expenditure for the first three quarters of a financial year is traditionally 66.7% of the full year's outlay.

For the same periods in the years under review, i.e. 1986-87 and 1987-88, expenditure was 68.8% and 67.6% respectively. The increasing value of the Australian dollar in the former year weighted the first three quarter's expenditure above the norm; a steadier A$ during 1987-88 brought the expenditure rate back to within 1% of the historical trend.
The primary reasons for the heavier expenditure in the last quarter of each financial year are-

an accounting procedure whereby the final reimbursements of expenditure at overseas posts are brought to account earlier than usual in order to meet the June end-of-year accounting timetable. A corresponding delay then occurs in the first weeks of July.
A resurgence in travel by officers at overseas posts following the Northern hemisphere winter.
A preponderance of leave fares taken by officers and their families at overseas posts coinciding with the commencement in June of their children's long school vacation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Why has 11 per cent been chosen as the figure by which last year's income will be increased for provisional tax purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The provisional tax uplift factor for 1988-89 is 12 per cent, not 11 per cent as stated in the question. The provisional tax uplift factor was, however, 11 per cent for 1986-87 and 1987-88.

Individual taxpayers who derive taxable income of over $1000, other than from wages and salaries, may be required to pay provisional tax. Income from interest bearing assets, dwelling rent, non farm unincorporated income and farm income are important sources of taxable income which may be subject to provisional tax.

The provisional tax uplift factor which is applied to the previous year's income is based on an estimate of the average increase in the incomes of provisional taxpayers as a whole during the current year.
The uplift factor has been set at 12 per cent for 1988-89 since incomes of provisional taxpayers in 1988-89 are expected to increase, on average, at that rate.

Since the uplift factor is an average, the increase in income of some provisional taxpayers may be below this rate. The Government has made allowance for this by permitting these taxpayers, should they so wish, to assess what they think their increase in income will be, and to pay their provisional tax on that basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 13 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: What steps have been taken by the Australian Government to research overseas aid needs to provide optimum benefits in the following areas: (a) training, rural development and increased female involvement in development in the Pacific region; (b) training, hydrology and agriculture infrastructure support, food security, planning support and environmental rehabilitation in Indo-China; and (c) poverty alleviation, agriculture and forestry development in Africa.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Australian aid program supports Pacific Island countries on the basis of development strategies formulated by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB). These strategies are developed and discussed with Pacific Island governments. They are based on research and discussion of the recipients' needs and priorities, Australia's own capacity to assist and areas of expertise. Consultation with other donors is another part of the process.
In order to research aid needs for the South Pacific region, AIDAB draws on a range of in-house and external expertise.

Inhouse, the Bureau has an appraisal, evaluation and sectoral study unit and the AIDAB Centre for Pacific Development and Training (ACPAC) located in Sydney. ACPAC has on its staff experts in human resource development, economic, engineering and natural resources development. A separate Development Training Group also advises on and manages training aid activities.

In addition, AIDAB commissions research with outside organisations such as the National Centre for Development Studies, the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) and the International Development Program of Australian Universities and Colleges of Advanced Education. These research results then feed into the process of developing country and regional aid strategies.

Education and training are key elements in all country and regional strategies. A large proportion of country program funds are spent directly in this sector, through the provision of education in Australia, in-country training and third country training.

In 1989-90, AIDAB will also introduce an Equity and Merit Scholarship scheme to complement the existing training program and broaden the scope of our bilateral aid relationships. Training is also an integral component of most other aid activities such as projects managed within the Australian aid program.

On a region-wide basis, Australia provides significant support to the University of the South Pacific ($3.47m in 1987-88). It is the only viable regional tertiary institution and contributes to the training activities of a number of regional organisations including the South Pacific Commission (SPC) and the South Pacific Forum Secretariat.

In the area of rural development, Australia supports a variety of activities in the South Pacific. Country-specific activities focus on such priority areas as outer island development, forestry or particular crops. In many country programs, Australia has been asked by the recipient government to take a lead role in aspects of rural development.
Close links are also maintained with the key research programs of regional institutions. For example, the SPC, of which we are the major supporter, is very active in rural research.

In the area of women in development, a significant amount of work is being done within AIDAB. Gender analysis is being used to identify the workload of women and their access to, and control of, goods and services. Once this is done, projects can be designed to minimise the negative effects on women or, preferably, to positively benefit women.

In the South Pacific, the role of women in development is also being addressed on a regional basis. In addition to our traditional support for programs such as the Women's Resources Bureau in SPC, the aid program recently provided funds for research by the United Nations Development Fund for Women (UNIFEM). The UNIFEM study investigated ways in which women's issues could be accommodated in the planning processes of South Pacific governments. We are currently considering Australian participation in follow-up proposals to this study.

(b) Australia does not provide bilateral aid to either Vietnam or Cambodia. The Australian Government suspended bilateral aid to Vietnam in 1979 following the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia. Therefore the Australian Government has not been in a position to undertake first hand research related to developmental needs in any sectors of these countries' economies.

However, Australia does provide support for country and regional programs of multilateral, international and non-government agencies in Vietnam and Cambodia. Australian contributions are intended to help in the health, agriculture and education sectors in these countries.

The Australian bilateral aid program in Laos is planned in consultation with the Lao Government. Agriculture and the development of basic infrastructure are areas of priority interest. Research of aid needs is limited to sectors where the Lao authorities invite Australia to provide support. AIDAB has not been asked to research or to assist in hydrology, planning support or environmental rehabilitation.
In 1988, AIDAB carried out an assessment of English language training and is currently planning a mission to identify other possible training needs that could be funded under the aid Program.

Australia has undertaken research in the livestock sector in Laos and in recent years has provided considerable support for livestock development. Support has been given for extension work and improved production and processing of local animal feed supplies.
The Government has also provided support over the last 10 years for irrigation projects. Food security has been an important component in irrigation activities.

Australia is currently examining the World Bank's Fifth Agricultural Development Project covering five Lao provinces. This study looks at options for agricultural development including crop intensification, road rehabilitation and measures to reduce environmentally damaging slash and burn cultivation.

(c) AIDAB has recently embarked on a study of ways to enhance the focus on poverty in the aid program. The study is expected to be completed early this year. Some of the findings of the study may have application in Africa. The present program in Southern Africa has a theme of food security which, in turn, has a close relationship with income levels and the incidence of poverty.

Opportunities for Australian research assistance in agriculture arise through Australia's support of the Southern African Development Co-ordination Conference (SADCC) Food Security Technical and Administration Unit based in Harare. The Unit is the SADCC sector co-ordinator for agriculture and is concerned primarily with regional food and agricultural issues. Australia currently funds 90% of the core budget of the Unit and provides the services of an Australian agricultural expert. Through the Unit, Australia contributed to an Agricultural Marketing Study covering the SADCC region, and funded a pilot study on bulk grain storage facilities in Zimbabwe with region-wide implications. AIDAB has under consideration a proposal for a regional irrigation study and for a regional food reserve.

In 1983, the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) sponsored a meeting in Kenya of 70 senior scientists from six Eastern African countries and Australia. The meeting sought to identify major agricultural and forestry problems and where Australian agricultural expertise might be applied effectively. On the basis of this meeting, ACIAR sponsored research on dryland crop and forage production in Kenya. This activity commenced as a farming systems project but is now focused on soil and water management.

Australia has undertaken a number of reviews and feasibility studies leading to projects, both research and implementation, in the forestry sector. An AIDAB review in 1986 of a World Food Program afforestation project in Southern Ethiopia, already supported by AIDAB, led to a project extension until 1989 at a cost of $12.8 million. A further review is planned this year.

Research seedlots in many African countries are provided under a global tree seed program administered by CSIRO and funded by AIDAB. A five year extension costing $2.2 million was approved in 1988. In Zimbabwe, aid worth $955,000 is being provided until 1992 for a forestry research centre. In Kenya, Australian aid worth $1.8 million is funding an FAO fuelwood afforestation project until 1990.

As a result of the agricultural and forestry priorities established at the 1983 meeting, ACIAR supported collaborative forestry research projects involving CSIRO and national institutions in Kenya and Zimbabwe with the aim of selecting fast-growing Australian trees for use as fuelwood and fodder. These agroforestry projects began in 1984 and approval was given in 1988 for a further three year program of research.
AIDAB and ACIAR have recently funded a feasibility study for a technical assistance forestry project in East Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 December 1988:

(2) What options are now available to these people in the absence of any amendments to the existing Lands Acquisition Act.
(3) Is it a fact that residents with houses in the vicinity of, but not included within the resumed area, have not been offered any compensation for injurious affection.
(4) Does the Government propose to offer any compensation to those people. If so, on what assessment basis; if not, why not.
(5) When does the Government anticipate it will finalise its purchase of land for the proposed airport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. In all cases a current market valuation is obtained from the Australian Valuation Office. At the time an offer to purchase is made by the Commonwealth the owner is given the opportunity to obtain one private valuation at the Commonwealth's expense from a valuer of his or her own choosing. While in some instances there are differences between Commonwealth offers and private valuations, my Department is committed to the payment of fair market value and deals with owners in a fair and even-handed way.

(2) My Department will reopen negotiations if so desired. While there is currently no legislative requirement many of the Law Reform Commission's recommendations recently incorporated into the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988, have been adopted in the acquisition process in an endeavour to ensure that property owners are dealt with in a fair and equitable manner.

In its report ``Aircraft Operations and the Australian Community'' the House of Representatives Select Committee on Aircraft Noise recommended that ``Compensation be paid to property owners who, because of acquisition of property for a new airport or the redevelopment of an existing airport, suffer a reduction in value of land not acquired for those purposes, provided that valuations are based on existing land use''. The Government will consider the Committee's report and respond to its recommendations in the near future. The question of payment of compensation to land owners outside the airport boundary will be resolved following the Government's consideration of the report.

(5) The Government has undertaken to provide sufficient funds to permit acquisition of the site by the end of the 1991-92 financial year. However, until required for airport development, properties are being purchased only from owners who advise of a desire to sell.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General agreed to move, at a cost of millions of dollars, the principal registry of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) from Canberra to Brisbane following the appointment of a Brisbane-based President of the Tribunal? If so:
(a) why is this costly move taking place?
(b) how much will it cost? and
(c) has it been publicly announced?
(2) Is it Government practice to move such office functions whenever a new President of the Tribunal is appointed with a different domicile from the previous President?
(3) What proportion of AAT work originates in Canberra and what proportion in Brisbane?

(4) Will the AAT's Canberra office be reduced to the status of a district registry, with 3 or 4 staff, even though the bulk of AAT matters require dealings with the central office of Commonwealth departments and their legal advisers, almost all of which are located in the ACT?
(5) What other candidates were there apart from Ms Stephanie Forgie for the position of Deputy President of the AAT?
(6) Were applications invited for the $90,000 a year position of Deputy President? and

(7) Has the appointment of Miss Forgie caused surprise in legal and bureaucratic circles because Miss Forgie, a former staffer of the Attorney-General, is claimed to have little recent litigation experience, had only recently been appointed as Registrar of the AAT on an SES Level 2 salary of about $56,000 and was therefore not of the seniority or standing in the profession that a Deputy President has hitherto commanded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) When it was in Canberra, the Principal Registry was too far removed from the AAT's main work areas and was therefore restricted in the level of positive input it could make in its supervision of work flows in the major District Registries. By being situated away from the major registries, it was hampered in performing its functions of closely monitoring the operation of the various systems in place in the AAT for processing the work flow and recommending changes and adjustments.

Relocation of the Principal Registry to one of the major cities where there is a higher workload, and thus a larger District Registry, was considered to be a more efficient use of resources because economies of scale could be applied.

After the decision to relocate the Principal Registry had been taken, attempts were made to find suitable accommodation in Sydney, the largest Registry. These attempts proved fruitless because reasonably suitable accommodation could not be obtained at a reasonable cost and at a location convenient to the AAT's existing Sydney facilities, including hearing rooms and the District Registry. The same problem existed in Melbourne.

Of the three major work locations Brisbane remained. A Brisbane location proved to be economically viable, cheaper than a move to Sydney or Melbourne, and accommodation was available in the same building in which the AAT's Brisbane operations are currently accommodated.

The President of the Tribunal has advised me that, having regard to the changes he has made to the Principal Registry's functions, which, broadly speaking, include centralisation of listing decisions and an increased emphasis on policy advice to the President, it will be able to operate as effectively and efficiently in Brisbane as it could in Sydney or Melbourne.
(b) The estimated costs of moving the Principal Registry from Canberra to Brisbane are as follows:
Fitout costs in Brisbane ...
Uplift of furniture and equipment ...
Purchase of new furniture and equipment ...
Removal expenses on transfer of staff ...
As a result of the move, the annual rental paid for accommodation for the AAT will increase by about $29,000.

(c) The decision to move the Principal Registry of the Tribunal to Brisbane has not been formally announced by me but the fact is that it has been made known in all relevant areas, including the media, for many months.

(3) In 1987-88 3.9% of AAT work originated in Canberra and 16.2% in Brisbane. However, it is not sufficient to simply consider the proportion of workload arising in each city. Regard must also be had to existing workloads and the outputs of the Registries.
The following table provides details of the comparative workloads in 1987-88 as between Canberra and Brisbane:
Lodged
Finalised
Undetermined
Preliminary
Conferences
General and Veterans Divisions
Brisbane ...
Canberra ...
Taxation Divisions
Brisbane ...
Canberra ...
It can be seen that Brisbane's workload far exceeds that of Canberra.

(4) The AAT's Canberra Registry has assumed the status of a District Registry. It will initially have a staff of 2 but the need for additional staff will be kept under review. It is incorrect to say that `the bulk of AAT matters require dealings with the central office of Commonwealth departments and their legal advisers, almost all of which are located in the ACT'. Applications before the Tribunals are, in almost all cases, heard and determined in the city or State in which they are lodged. All the necessary processing of matters is handled by the District Registry in the relevant State or Territory including any necessary dealings with officers of the relevant Commonwealth Department and their legal advisers. In some cases, those officers and legal advisers are located in Canberra. The location of such people is a matter of choice for each Department and has no bearing on which Registry handles any particular application.

(5) There were no other specific candidates for the office of a Deputy President to which Miss Forgie was appointed. It has not been the practice in recent times to advertise for a Deputy President vacancy where suitably qualified persons are known to be available for appointment.
(7) I have received no representations over Miss Forgie's appointment.
Miss Forgie is a suitably qualified lawyer who possesses the necessary skills, ability and integrity required of a Deputy President of the Tribunal.

Miss Forgie has never at any time been a member of my ministerial staff. As an officer of the Attorney-General's Department, she did work in my Parliamentary offices for a period of 2 years as the occupant of a position of Departmental Representative created by the Secretary of the Department to assist me with various matters affecting the work of my portfolio. The position is now occupied by another officer of the Department.

(2) Have the reports in (1) above been verified by Australian authorities; if so, what was the level of involvement of companies or consortia with Australian interests

(3) Has the Federal Government identified these interests, and should the claims of the Government of Nauru prove to be correct, what measures can be taken to recover that portion of the $72 million claimed by Nauru to be the cost of repairing the damage and rehabilitating the land.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes
(2) The media reports referred to the findings of the Commission of Inquiry established by the Nauru Government regarding the Rehabilitation of the Worked-out Phosphate Lands of Nauru.

The December 1988 Report states that the Commission of Inquiry found Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom responsible for the rehabilitation of phosphate land worked-out by the then British Phosphate Commissioners in the periods of the League of Nations Mandate and the United Nations Trusteeship. The estimated cost of that rehabilitation was $A72 million.

The British Phosphate Commissioners was a board of three commissioners representing respectively the Governments of Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom which was established to direct the extraction and shipment from Nauru and other islands of rock phosphate on a non-profit basis.

Australia did not make a submission to the Nauru Rehabilitation Inquiry. It informed the Government of the Republic of Nauru that it regarded the pre-independence comprehensive phosphate agreement as a just settlement that cleared the partner governments of the former British Phosphate Commissioners of any responsibility for the rehabilitation of Nauru.
The Government will consider the Report of the Nauru Rehabilitation Inquiry in consultation with the Governments of New Zealand and the United Kingdom.
(3) See (2) above.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department or portfolio has not, since 1 January 1988, sponsored or part-sponsored the overseas travel of any trade union delegates attending trade union functions overseas.

It did however meet the expenses incurred by a Federal Industrial Officer of ACOA who accompanied an Assistant Secretary of my Department on a visit to overseas posts towards the end of last year. Against specific questions asked above, the following details are provided:
(a) the purpose of the trip was to participate in a joint union/management inquiry into Office Structures Implementation (OSI) for DILGEA offices overseas;
(b) union participant was Ms Paula Kelly an Industrial Officer from the Federal Office of the ACOA;
(c) accompanying departmental participant was Mr Laurie Bugden, an Assistant Secretary in the Corporate Services Branch of my Department's Central Office;
(d) participants visited Immigration posts at Manila, Hong Kong, Tokyo, New York and London during the period 18 October-4 November 1988;
(e) trip was paid fully by the Commonwealth;
(f) the cost of Ms Kelly's trip to the Commonwealth was $8927.19;
(g) the breakdown of the cost of Ms Kelly was as follows:
Air fare, $3,997, Class-Business;
Accommodation, $3008.33;
Care hire, $NIL;
Other items, $1,921.86, T/A, (bus and taxi fares, departure tax and equipment allowance).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many farmers or farmers' spouses have had their unemployment benefits terminated in South Australia since the introduction of the assets test on unemployment benefits.
(2) How many people have lost benefits in each of the Social Security districts in South Australia since the assets test was introduced.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The number of benefits terminated in South Australia as a result of introduction of the assets test on 13 December 1987 was 220. It is not known how many of these were farmers or farmer's spouses. A breakdown by Social Security Region is not available. The number of farmers or farmers' spouses in receipt of unemployment benefit in South Australia at 30 December 1988 was estimated at 75, compared with 130 at 27 November 1987.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to existing guidelines whereby Australian servicemen may only wear medals awarded to them by the Governor-General on behalf of the Commonwealth and the current problem for Australian soldiers who served in the Sinai who have been awarded the Multi-National Force and Observers (MFO) meritorious medal but who are forbidden from wearing it because it is a foreign medal, does the Government consider that Mr Hayden's wearing of a Korean medal in 1988 sets a precedent for Australian Servicemen to wear their foreign MFOs.
(2) Does the delay in awarding the Australian Service Medal to these servicemen mean that, if they wear the MFO, they will be precluded from accepting an Australian Service Medal.
(3) Will the Government take immediate steps to correct this seemingly unfortunate anomaly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. All proposals for acceptance and wearing of foreign awards are treated on a case by case basis. The acceptance and wearing by Mr Hayden of a South Korean award was approved by The Queen under the guidelines then in place. On 6 February 1989 Australian guidelines concerning the acceptance and wearing of foreign honours or awards by Australians were gazetted. Under these guidelines, permission to accept and wear a foreign honour or award will be considered by the Governor-General for:
(a) conspicuous bravery in saving or attempting to save life, or
(b) extraordinary service to humanity at large, or
(c) outstanding service to the country wishing to confer the honour or award and/or in furthering relations between Australia and that country, or
(d) service in warlike or hazardous situations.

The guidelines will enable the Governor-General to consider granting permission for Australians to accept and wear foreign honours and awards including awards conferred by international organisations such as the MFO. I understand that this matter is currently before the Governor-General for consideration.

(2) No. The Government accepts that if two medals are to be awarded for one period of service they would be proposed and approved by two quite separate processes; one under the foreign award guidelines and the other under the Australian Service Medal regulations. In short, the approval for award of the Australian Service Medal is unrelated to MFO Medal considerations.
(3) The Government does not accept that an anomaly exists.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice, on 23 August 1988 (Hansard page 82), inter alia:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of the Eighth Canberra Dental Seminar held last week at Fiji's Shangri-La International and followed this week with a post-seminar tour involving a three-day and four-night Blue Lagoon Cruise and a two-day and three-night stay at Matamanoa Island?
(2) Are expenses incurred in travelling to such conferences tax deductible?
(3) Will the Government consider pro rata deductibitlity for the number of days spent in conference and the number of days spent in more pleasurable pursuits?
The Treasurer has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:
(1) I am aware that the Eighth Canberra Dental Seminar was held in Fiji.

(2) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that claims for the cost of travelling to seminars are considered under the general deduction provisions and the substantiation provisions contained in the income tax law. Such claims are allowable income tax deductions where they can be fully substantiated, are incurred in the gaining or producing of assessable income and are not of a capital, private or domestic nature.

(3) The Commissioner said that while each claim is determined on its own merits to see if there is the necessary connection between the expenditure and the derivation of assessable income, this particular Dental Seminar seems to have combined both business and recreational pursuits. In these circumstances the cost of travelling to the Seminar would be apportioned in calculating any income tax deduction. The extent of the apportionment would be based upon the details contained in the taxpayer's travel diary. As part of the substantiation requirements all employees and self-employed taxpayers must keep receipts and travel diaries to substantiate all claims they make for overseas travel expenses. Details such as the date, nature and duration of business activities must be recorded in the diary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday, 17 October 1988 (Hansard page 1437), Senator Bishop asked me a question without notice concerning the contribution made by volunteers to the community, the funding arrangements for volunteering under SkillShare and the cessation of Commonwealth funding for the Parramatta Office of the Volunteer Centre of New South Wales which was funded under the former Community Volunteer Program. She asked me a related question on the same matter on Thursday, 15 December 1988 (Hansard pages 4287-8). The Minister for Employment and Education Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has a high regard for the valuable contribution volunteers make to a broad range of people in the community including the important role volunteers play in the achievement of the Government's program objectives in the provision of community, health, migrant, educational, legal, consumer, sport and other services.

The Government announced in the context of the 1987/88 Budget its decision to form SkillShare by integrating the Community Volunteer Program (CVP), the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) and the Community Training Program (CTP) to achieve a more effective use of available funds and to ensure that community-based assistance is provided for structured training and employment-related support for the most disadvantaged job-seekers. SkillShare commenced on 1 January 1989.

While there is a focus on structured skills training in the new program, the SkillShare guidelines make specific provision for projects to offer a broad range of open access activities including volunteering, employment-related personal support services and personal effectiveness training to complement structured skills training.

The Parramatta Office of the Volunteer Centre of NSW was one of the two former CVP projects operated under the umbrella of the Volunteer Centre of NSW. In response to an invitation, extended to all projects funded under CVP, CYSS and CTP to apply for funding under the new SkillShare guidelines, the Centre lodged an expression of interest to provide a regional volunteer service to other SkillShare projects. This proposal was outside the guidelines and consequently was not approved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On a general basis, what is the level of protection provided by the Australian Government for citizens of this country living abroad on a temporary basis or overseas on holiday or for business reasons.

(2) In view of the Blenkinsop case in Indonesia, and the Cerqueire murder in Brazil, do Australian authorities have an input into investigations and possible subsequent trials when Australian citizens are the victims of violent trial; if so, what is the scale of that input, and how is it administered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government has the most active sympathy for Australian citizens in difficulty overseas and its policy is to provide them with the fullest possible protection within the constraints of international law and practice and available resources. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade through its consular officials is responsible for implementing this policy. The functions which may be performed by consular officials are defined in, inter alia, the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations (VCCR) to which Australia is a party. To further assist Australians travelling overseas the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade continues to examine ways of streamlining the issue of passports. These official documents are provided to Australians as a means of proof of identity and nationality. Replacement of passports lost or stolen overseas is arranged promptly through the Australian consular service.

It is probably not widely recognised that compared with other countries a very high percentage of Australians travel overseas (1.4 million departures of Australian citizens in 1987-88). Unfortunately, there is often an unrealistic expectation in the community as to the level of consular protection and services which can be provided. In fact this is limited by the resources of our overseas posts and international law and practice.

Australians who travel overseas should be aware of some of the sensible precautions they can take to facilitate their travel. Australians when travelling overseas can avoid or reduce problems by acting responsibly and prudently by considering and providing for the possible consequences of any hazardous undertakings, by obtaining adequate insurance, and by having due regard for the traditions and laws of the countries in which they travel.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has a consular information program aimed at increasing the awareness of travellers of the services which can and cannot be provided overseas. Consular services cover a wide range of statutory and non-statutory activities-welfare and whereabouts, death of Australian citizens abroad and the protection of the estate of the deceased, arrest and detention, relief and repatriation, registration of citizenship by descent, marriages and notarial acts, medical and emergency evacuations, registration of ships and assistance for seamen under the Australian Navigation Act and assistance to the Australian Electoral Commission in the conduct of elections in Australia. Many of these consular functions can be resolved simply. But there are numerous cases which are not only complex and stressful, but which may not be resolved for prolonged periods and consequently exert great pressure on the human and financial resources of the consular service.

An explanation of the general range of consular services available overseas is contained in the booklet ``Hints for Australian Travellers''. Copies of the booklet, which is updated annually, are provided with every Australian passport issued. In addition the Department publishes a quarterly consular newsletter which is distributed to the travel industry to ensure that travel agents have the latest information to pass on to their clients. The newsletter is also sent to other interested parties, including ethnic communities' councils and migrant resource centres, and is available in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade State offices.

The general level of assistance able to be provided and the limitations faced by consular officers might best be indicated by a brief look at three types of cases involving Australians in difficulty overseas-health, legal offences, and dual nationality.

Each year Australian posts handle many cases where Australians fall ill overseas, or suffer an accident. The Consul can assist with contacting family and friends in Australia and elsewhere to obtain funds to cover their needs, and if necessary assist in arranging transfer of these funds. In cases of extreme distress the Consul may authorise a small advance until money comes through from other sources.

The Government has negotiated with a number of countries reciprocal health care agreements which enable Australian citizens to obtain public medical and hospital treatment under the same conditions as citizens of those countries. Negotiations are continuing to increase the number of countries with which Australia has such agreements. Notwithstanding the existence of these agreements illness or injury occurring overseas can be very expensive.

The second type of case relates to Australians caught up in the legal processes of other countries. Australians overseas are subject to the laws, legal processes and code of punishment of the country in which they are travelling or residing. In some instances these laws, processes and punishments differ greatly from those in Australia, and may sometimes seem to be harsh and unfair. However, the Australian Government is not entitled to interfere in the internal affairs of another country, in much the same way that it would not countenance interference by another country in Australian affairs. The Government can make consular representations only when there is a basis for believing that an Australian citizen has been discriminated against in the process of the law.

When Australians are arrested in another country, consular officers will ensure access to legal representation and will provide regular consular assistance, including visits. They will ensure, so far as possible, that an arrested person receives the benefits of the same laws, administrative measures and protective rights as citizens of that country. Similarly, to the extent that it is possible, they will see that an arrested person gets no less a standard of facilities, including accommodation, diet and medical or dental treatment, as citizens of the country where the arrest took place. They will provide whatever other assistance and advice can reasonably be given. However, consular officers have no status in civil cases involving Australians beyond seeking fair treatment under the law. They cannot provide legal advice and they cannot achieve the release of an arrested person.

The matter of dual nationality often causes difficulty for those Australian travellers who also hold the citizenship of another country. In some countries dual nationals may be liable for military service, or may have restrictions placed on their movements, including being prevented from departing the country. Australians with dual nationality arrested in the country of their other nationality may sometimes be denied access by Australian consular officers. Moreover, according to international practice, a person in a third country is treated as a citizen of the country on whose passport they entered. An Australian citizen may therefore be denied access to Australian consular officers if they are travelling on their non-Australian passport.

The Australian Government has attempted to address these problems and other matters which are not covered by the VCCR by entering into negotiations for consular agreements with a number of countries. An agreement was signed with Hungary in March 1988 which regularises our consular relations together with an accompanying exchange of notes which provide that dual nationals when visiting the country of their other nationality will be treated as citizens of the country on whose passport they are travelling. Negotiations with a number of other countries are at various stages of progress.

(2) In the same way that foreign governments do not have any input into investigations and trials in Australia involving crimes of violence against foreign nationals, the Australian Government does not have any role to play in investigations and trials in cases involving Australian citizens in foreign countries.

However Australian consular officers will, wherever possible, monitor enquiries and court proceedings in such cases in order to demonstrate to the local authorities that Australia has an interest in ensuring that due legal processes are being followed. Australian consular officials will seek to ensure that the interests of Australian citizens are protected and that those citizens receive fair treatment under the local judicial system.
